MR. GASPARD CONTACTED MR. JOE HENNESSEY OF THE MMS TO DISCUSS THE INFORMATION REGARDING A REPORTED LEAK.  MR. HENNESSEY STATED THAT CHEVRON/TEXACO WAS INVESTIGATING A LEAK AND THAT A DETERMINATION HAD NOT YET BEEN MADE AS TO WHETHER THE LEAK WAS ON THE EPFS LATERAL OR CHEVRON/TEXACO SALES LINE WHICH PARALLEL EACH OTHER.  MR. GASPARD CONTACTED MR. JIM PRICE OF CHEVRON/TEXACO AT 5:05 PM THAT SAME DATE.  MR. PRICE, LOCATED AT TEXACO'S SMI 236 PLATFORM INDICATED THAT THEY HAD NOTICED A LEAK AT APPROXIMATELY 10:00AM ON THE 28TH OF FEBRUARY.  HE INDICATED GAS BUBBLES WERE VISIBLE AND THAT NO SHEEN WAS EVIDENT ON THE WATER.  HE ALSO STATED THAT THEY HAD ORDERED A DIVING CREW TO INVESTIGATE.  MR. PRICE ALSO STATED THAT HE FELT THE LEAK WAS ON THEIR LINE SINCE OUR LINE HAD BEEN OUT OF SERVICE AND THE PRESSURE GAUGE ON OUR LINE INDICATED ZERO PRESSURE ON OUR LINE.  HE ALSO NOTED THAT THE VALVES ON THE EPFS LINE WERE CLOSED AND FINALLY THAT THEY BELIEVED THEY HAD NOTICED A PRESSURE DECLINE IN THEIR SYSTEM.  FURTHERMORE, MR. PRICE CONTACTED MR. GASPARD AT APPROXIMATELY 9:05PM AND INFORMED MR. GASPARD THAT THE DIVERS HAD FOUND THE LEAK TO BE ON THE TEXACO/CHEVRON LINE.  CHEVRON/TEXACO TOOK ACTIONS TO ISOLATE THEIR LINE AND BY THE FOLLOWING MORNING, THE BUBBLES HAD STOPPED.  WEATHER CONDITIONS AND WATER CONDITIONS WERE ROUGH.  ON TUESDAY, MARCH 5, 2002 THE WEATHER CLEARED AND CHEVRON/TEXACO WAS ABLE TO SEND DOWN ANOTHER DIVING CREW.  THE DIVERS CONFIRMED THAT THE LEAK WAS ON THE EPFS LINE AND NOT ON THE CHEVRON/TEXACO LINE.  MR. GASPARD RECEIVED THIS CONFIRMATION FROM THE DIVERS AT 9:00 AM ON THE MORNING OF MARCH 5, 2002.  THE NRC WAS NOTIFIED BY JIM MCDONALD, EPFS COMPLIANCE DEPARTMENT, OF THIS INCIDENT AT 10:50 AM ON MARCH 5, 2002 AND THE INCIDENT WAS ASSIGNED CASE NUMBER 595652.  A DECISION TO PREMANENTLY ABANDON THE SMI LATERAL WAS REACHED BY EPFS AND THE ABANDONMENT WAS COMPLETED ON MARCH 13, 2002.  IN A FAX SENT BY MR. JOE HENNESSEY, MMS DATED 3/13/2002, EL PASO FIELD SERVICES RECEIVED CONFIRMATION THAT OUR ABANDONMENT PROCEDURE HAD BEEN APPROVED.  THE ABANDONMENT WAS FOR AN 8 INCH GAS PIPELINE.  SEGMENT NO 6872 ASSOCIATED WITH RIGHT OF WAY OCS-G 5941.  FINAL PROJECT COST INCLUDING ABANDONMENT FEES AND GAS LOSS TOTALED $171.342."

SEVERAL OIL AND DISTILLATE TANKS WERE DAMAGED. THE EXPLOSIVE MIXTURE WAS IGNITED WHEN IT WAS VENTED THROUGH THE LOW PRESSURE FLARE SYSTEM AND REACHED THE FLARE FLAME, WHERE IT FLASHED BACK AND BURNED AT THE DETONATION FLAME ARRESTOR OUTLET.  AFTER THE DETONATION FLAME ARRESTOR BECAME COMPROMISED, THE FUEL/AIR MIXTURE FLASHED BACK TO THE BLOWER AND INTO DRY OIL TANK #1, RESULTING IN THE EXPLOSION AND FIRE."

2002	22617	20020055		SOUTHERN STAR CENTRAL GAS PIPELINE	4700 HIGHWAY 56	OWENSBORO	DAVIESS	KY	42301	410	6/23/2002	HUTCHISON	RENO	KS	67501	181 + 1175	9553+74			N	1				NO	NO	Y	INTERSTATE	1	LEAK		3	PUNCTURE	3					0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	63885	885	60000	3000	NO	NO	NO	NO	0			0	0	6/23/2002	612709	740	900	NO	NO	YES	NO	NO	N	1	TRANSMISSION	1	BODY OF PIPE		1	STEEL		NO	NO	NO	1	PIPELINE		1948	20	0.38	52000	1950	EFW		A O SMITH	1947	4	UNDER GROUND		66	7/16/2002	9	EXCAVATION DAMAGE									NULL		NULL												3	PROFESSIONAL EXCAVATOR	2	PIPELINE		YES	6	10	2002	1	ONE-CALL SYSTEM	YES	1	FLAGS	YES	1	ACCURATE	YES																									NULL	NULL																									DAVID SINCLAIR-PIPELINE SAFETY SPECIALIST 	2708524424	DAVID.SINCLAIR@SSCGP.COM	2708525012	"ON JUNE 6, 2002 LYONS DISTRICT RECEIVED A ONE CALL ON REPLACING A GAS LINE IN SEC 31,30 OF T 23S R 5 W OF RENO CO, KS FOR KANSAS GAS SERVICE BY BRB CONTRACTORS INC OF TOPEKA, KS.  THIS WAS ON THE HUGOTON LINE ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE ARKANSAS RIVER AT HUTCHINSON, KANSAS.  JOHN DUMOND RESPONDED TO THE ONE CALL (TICKET #204363).  JOHN DUMOND MET JOHN KEENER WITH BRB CONTRACTORS OF TOPEKA, KS.  JOHN DUMOND SPOTTED ALL THREE OF OUR LINES WHICH ALL RAN AT A DEPTH OF 63"" TO 66"".  THE LINES WERE FLAGGED WITH YELLOW FLAGS THAT HAVE OUR NAME AND PHONE NUMBER ON THEM.  JOHN DUMOND WROTE THE DEPTH OF EACH LINE ON THE FLAGS AT EACH LOCATION WHERE HE SPOTTED THE LINES WITH A LINE FINDER AND PROBED EACH LOCATION WITH A SPOTTING BAR.  BRB IS THE GENERAL CONTRACTOR FOR KANSAS GAS SERVICE WHICH IS A DIVISION ON ONOEK.  A&L UNDERGROUND IS A SUB-CONTRACTOR OF BRB CONTRACTORS INC DOING THE DIRECTIONAL BORE OF THE ARKANSAS RIVER.  A&L UNDERGROUND AND BRB WERE ASKED TO EXPOSE OUR LINES TO THE BOTTOM OF EACH LINE WHERE WE COULD SEE THE DRILL STEM AND BITS WERE WELL BELOW OUR LINE. THEY SAID THAT THEY DIDN'T WANT TO DO THIS BECAUSE THEY WOULD LOSE THE CIRCULATION OF THEIR DRILLING MUD.  THE DRILL STEM WORE A HOLE IN THE BOTTOM OF THE SOUTH 20"" RIVER CROSSING. BILL WHITEHEAD WAS CALLED AT 4:10 AM SUNDAY MORNING JUNE 23, 2002, BY JOHN DUMOND, BILL CALLED OPERATIONS CONTROL ON HIS WAY TO THE LOCATION. A & L UNDERGROUND HAD CALLED JOHN.  JOHN DUMOND HAD BEEN WITH BOTH CONTRACTORS WHEN THEY STARTED TO BORE THE RIVER CROSSING, AND REPEATEDLY ASSURED JOHN DUMOND THAT THEY WERE 10' BELOW OUR LINE.  WHEN JOHN DUMOND AND BILL WHITEHEAD GOT TO THE SITE, THE BORING CREW HAD MOVED AWAY FROM THE BORING RIG AND WERE WAITING FOR THEM.  JOHN AND BILL GOT THERE ALONG WITH KANSAS GAS SERVICE.  OPERATIONS CONTROL WAS NOT SEEING ANY LOSS OF PRESSURE.  AFTER THEY DETERMINED THAT IT WAS OUR LINE, THEY STARTED SHUTTING IT IN.  DAN JASO AND MIKE HUGGANS WERE CALLED OUT TO HELP OPERATE THE GATES TO SHUT THE LINE SEGMENT IN.  THE LINE HAD 740 PSIG ON IT AT THE TIME.  THERE WAS NO FIRE, INJURIES, EMERGENCY PERSONNEL OR MEDIA INVOLVED WITH THE INCIDENT.  THE LINE WAS ALLOWED TO BLOW DOWN THROUGH THE DAMAGED SPOT BECAUSE OF THE GROUND WATER THAT SHOWED UP WHEN THEY STARTED DIGGING THE LINE OUT TO INSPECT IT.  BRB AND KANSAS AND KANSAS GAS SERVICE BROUGHT IN TRACK MOUNTED BACKHOES TO DIG THE DAMAGED LINE OUT.  GROUND WATER BECAME A MAJOR PROBLEM WHILE EXPOSING THE DAMAGED LINE.  BRB BROUGHT IN A 6"" & 8"" DITCH PUMPS WHICH ALLOWED US TO SEE THE LINE WITH THE DRILL STEM UNDER IT.  WE WERE NOT ABLE TO INSTALL A CLAMP ON THE LINE UNTIL ABOUT MIDNIGHT SUNDAY NIGHT JUNE 23, 2002.  A & L UNDERGROUND GOT THE DRILL STEM AND REAMER AWAY FROM OUR LINE AND WILLIAMS EMPLOYEES WERE ABLE TO INSTALL TWO BANDS CLAMPS TO KEEP THE WATER OUT OF THE LINE.  WE KEPT ABOUT 10-20 PSIG ON THE LINE BECAUSE OF THE WATER UNTIL THE LINE WAS READY TO REPAIR. BRB WAS HANDLING THE EXCAVATING OF THE DAMAGED LINE AND PUMPING THE WATER ALONG WITH INSTALLATION OF SAND POINTS TO DRY THE HOLE UP ENOUGH SO WE COULD MAKE THE REPAIR.  DUE TO PUMP PROBLEMS, THE PERMANENT LINE REPAIR WASN'T COMPLETED UNTIL WEDNESDAY JUNE 26 AT 9:00 AM.  RONNIE YOUNG AND PETE GARCIA, WILLIAMS GAS PIPELINE COMPANY WELDERS, INSTALLED A FULL-ENCIRCLEMENT."

ON AUGUST 5, 2002, COLUMBIA GAS TRANSMISSION CORPORATION'S (COLUMBIA) PIPELINE SM-80 LOOP (30"") RUPTURED AND IGNITED.THE PIPELINE WAS OPERATING AT 748 PSIG AT THE TIME OF THE RUPTURE.COLUMBIA'S GAS CONTROL IMMEDIATELY WAS AWARE OF THE RUPTURE DUE TO THE RAPID DROP IN PRESSURE AND COLUMBIA FIELD EMPLOYEES SAW THE FLAMES FROM A COMPRESOR STATION APPROXIMATELY ONE MILE AWAY. THE RUPTURE OCCURRED IN A RURAL AREA NEAR THE COMMUNITY OF LANHAM, WV IN PUTNAM COUNTY. NO DEATHS OR INJURIES RESULTED FROM THE INCIDENT.THE NEAREST RESIDENTIAL DWELLING WAS APPROXIMATELY 500 YARDS AWAY AND UNDAMAGED. COLUMBIA QUICKLY RESPONDED BY CLOSING VALVES ON EITHER SIDE OF THE RUPTURE TO STOP THE FLOW OF GAS TO THE DAMAGED PORTION OF PIPELINE. BY 12:45 A.M., THE LINE WAS ISOLATED AND THE FLAMES QUICKLY DIMINISHED. THE CAUSE OF THE RUPTURE IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION, HOWEVER, PRELIMINARY INDICATIONS ARE THAT EXTERNAL STRESS, IN PARTICULAR THE WEIGHT OF A HILLSIDE SLIP, MAY HAVE LED TO THE RUPTURE. BASED ON THE PRELIMINARY FINDINGS, COLUMBIA AND THE US DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION'S OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY HAVE JOINTLY DEVELOPED A PLAN OF ACTIONS COLUMBIA WILL TAKE TO SAFELY RESTORE SERVICE TO THE PIPELINE. THE PIPELINE REMAINS OUT OF SERVICE UNTIL THIS PLAN IS FULLY IMPLEMENTED.    FINAL INVESTIGATION AND REPORTING INFORMATION WAS FILED WITH THE OPS EASTERN REGION OFFICE. ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS INDICATES THAT THIS FAILURE WAS DUE TO SLOPE INSTABILITY, WHICH CREATED HIGH AXIAL STRESSES AT THE FAILURE ORIGIN AND PRODUCED BUCKLING NEAR THE ORIGIN OF FAILURE."

ON AUGUST 20 THE NAUTILUS- OPERATIONS TECHNICIAN NOTICED GAS SEEPING FROM THE BASE OF A 2"" WELD-O-LET IN NAUTILUS GARDEN CITY MANIFOLD ON THE 24"" PIPING TO THE EXXON GAS PLANT. THE GAS FLOW TO EXXON WAS IMMEDIATELY SHUTDOWN. THE AFFECTED PIPING WAS ISOLATED (DOUBLE-BLOCKED IN BY CLOSING TWO UPSTREAM VALVES AND TWO DOWNSTREAM VALVES) AND THE AFFECTED LINE SECTION (APPROXIMATELY 60 FOOT LINE) WAS BLOWN DOWN. GAS DELIVERY TO THE ADJACENT NEPTUNE PLANT WAS ABLE TO CONTINUE SAFELY. NO PUBLIC OR ENVIRONMENTAL EXPOSURE WAS CAUSED BY THIS INCIDENT. THE 2"" WELD-O-LET WAS LOCATED IN THE NAUTILUS MANIFOLD DOWNSTREAM OF THE EXXON ORIFICE METERS AND IMMEDIATELY UPSTREAM OF THE EXXON CONTROL VALVE (FV 3030). THE 2"" WELD-O-LET WAS USED FOR A SAMPLE POINT AND WAS ONE OF THREE 2"" WELD-O-LETS ON A 4 FT. LONG 24 IN DIAMETER JOINT OF PIPE. WET MAGNETIC PARTICLE TESTING CONFIRMED THAT THERE IS A CRACK IN THE PARENT PIPE EXTENDING ABOUT 2"" ALONG THE PIPE AXIS TO EITHER SIDE OF THE FILLET WELD. THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE CRACK IS UNDETERMINED AT THIS TIME. THE SPECIMEN CONTAINING THE CRACK HAS BEEN SENT TO KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES IN COLUMBUS, OHIO FOR FAILURE ANALYSIS. AT THE TIME OF THE RELEASE, IT WAS BELIEVED THAT REPAIR COSTS WOULD BE LESS THAN $50,000. A DETERMINATION WAS MADE ON AUGUST 23, 2002 THAT REPAIR COSTS WOULD EXCEED $50,000 AND THE NRC WAS NOTIFIED.   4-18-03 LABORATORY ANALYSIS OF THE FAILED SPECIMEN INDICATED THAT THE FAILURE WAS DUE TO FATIGUE CRACKING FROM VIBRATION LOADINGS.  THE CRACK INITIATED AT TOE OF FILLET WELD AT A SHARP CORNER BETWEEN THE FIRST PASS OF THE WELDMENT AND THE CARRIER PIPE BODY.  KIEFNER AND ASSOCIATES WAS CONSULTED CONCERNING THE CAUSE CLASSIFICATION OF THIS EVENT."

THE CONTRACTOR WAS MADE AWARE OF THE GAS PIPELINE LOCATION BY A VENOCO EMPLOYEE PERFORMING ROUTINE PIPELINE SYSTEM MONITORING. THE GAS PIPELINE LOCATION WAS DESCRIBED AND IDENTIFIED BY THE VENOCO EMPLOYEE TO THE CONTRACTRO SUPERVISOR ON SITE. PERMANENT PIPELINE MARKERS WERE IN PLACE IN THE IMMEDIATE AREA AND WERE POINTED OUT AS WELL AS A PIPELINE DESCRIPTION PROVIDED TO THE CONTRACTOR SUPERVISOR. FOLLOWING THE ABOVE EVENTS, THE CONTRACTOR BUILT A STAGING AREA DIRECTLY ABOVE THE VENOCO GAS PIPELINE FOR SLURRY MIXING OPERATIONS TO SUPPORT THE WATER PIPELINE PROJECT. THIS STAGING AREA WAS AWAY FROM THE TRENCHINGAND EXCAVATING ACTIVITIES DIRECTLY ASSOCIATED WITH LAYING THE WATER PIPELINE. DEVELOPMENT OF THE STAGING AREA INCLUDED TOPPIN A SMALL KNOLL WITHIN THE STAFING AREA TO ENABLE A LEVEL WORK LOCATION. THE GAS PIPELINE RAN DIAGONALLY THROUGH THE STAGING AREA FOLLOWING THE LOCAL TOPPGRAPHY. EXCAVATION BY THE CONTRACTOR OF THE ELEVATED AREA REMOVED APPROXIMATELY 9 FEET OF EARTH ABOVE AND PROTECTING THE PIPELINE. THE FINISHED ELEVATION OF THE STAGING AREA LEFT APPROXIMATELY 6"" OF EARTH PROTECTING THE HIGHEST POINT OF THE PIPELINE. APPROXIMATELY TWO WEEKS AFTER COMPLETION AND USE OF THE STAGING AREA VENOCO'S CONTRACTOR FOR HANDLING UNDERGROUND SERVICE ALERT (USA) NOTIFICATIONS RESPONDED TO A USA NOTIFICATION REGARDING A WATER LINE INSTALLATION NEAR THE VENOCO GAS PIPELINE. THE VENOCO CONTRACTOR VISTED THE USA LOCATION, BUT THE ACTUAL WATER PIPELINE WORK WAS NOT NEAR THE VENOCO GAS PIPELINE. AT THAT TIME VENOCO'S CONTRACTOR TALKED WITH THE WATER PIPELINE PROJECT SUPERVISOR ON-SITE REGARDING THE LOCATION OF THE GAS PIPELINE INCLUDING THE PIPELINE LOCATION WITHIN THE WATER PROJECT STAGING AREA. A MATERIAL PILE EXISTED IN THE STAGING AREA TO SUPPORT A PUG MIXER AND SLURRY OPERATIONS. THE MATERIAL PILE WAS LOCATED DIRECTLY ABOVE THE GAS PIPELINE. A FRONT END LOADER WAS BEING USED TO MOVE MATERIAL FROM THE PILE TO THE PUG MIXER. OVER A PERIOD OF TIME, WHILE MOVING MATERIAL TO THE PUG MIXER THE FRONT END LOADER WAS ALSO REMOVING ADDITIONAL EARTH ABOVE THE PIPELINE. EVENTUALLY, WHILE SCRAPING  THE GROUND MOVING INTO THE MATERIAL PILE FOR ANOTHER LOAD THE FRONT END LOADER BUCKET TORE A 4"" X 6"" HOLE IN THE GAS PIPELINE. THE PIPELINE AUTOMATICALLY ISOLATED ON LOW PRESSURE. THE WORKER EVACUATED THE AREA, THE AREA WAS SECURED AND ISOLATED BY THE CONTRACTOR UNTIL VENOCO RESPONDERS ARRIVED. DAMAGED SECTION WAS CUT OUT AND REPAIRED."

MS. NICOLE HOTZFIELD WAS DRIVING HER FORD RANGER PICKUP WHEN IT LEFT A RURAL TOWNSHIP ROAD STRIKING AN EIGHT-INCH VALVE SITE ON GREAT PLAINS NATURAL GAS CO.'S (GPNG'S) TRANSMISSION PIPELINE NEAR PELICAN RAPIDS, MN. THIS VALVE SITE IS THE TAKE-OFF POINT FOR A THREE-INCH DIAMETER TRANSMISSION PIPELINE THAT SERVES PELICAN RAPIDS. AFTER THE ACCIDENT, THE DRIVER CALLED FOR 911 EMERGENCY SERVICES, AND THEN LEFT THE SCENE OF HER OWN ACCORD. EMERGENCY RESPONDERS CLOSED THE COUNTY ROAD WHILE GPNG EMPLOYEES DETERMINED THE BEST METHOD TO STOP THE RELEASE OF GAS WITHOUT UNNECESSARILY ENDANGERING ANYONE. AROUND NOON ON OCTOBER 20, THE PRESSURE ON THE LINE HAD BEEN LOWERED TO APPROXIMATELY 350 PSIG AND TWO-EMPLOYEES IN PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT USED AN ""EASYOUT"" TO REMOVE A BROKEN 1/4"" DIAMETER NIPPLE FROM WHERE A PRESSURE TAP WAS BROKEN AS A RESULT OF THE ACCIDENT. A NEW NIPPLE WAS THREADED IN A VALVE IN THE OPEN POSITION INSTALLED. FINALLY, THE VALVE WAS CLOSED, STOPPING THE UNCONTROLLED RELEASE OF NATURAL GAS. AT THIS POINT IT WAS UNCLEAR THAT THE DAMAGES WOULD EXCEED $50,000 AND THERE WAS NO EVIDENCE THAT THERE WERE INJURIES REQUIRING I-PATIENT CARE. ACCORDINGLY, THE INCIDENT WAS NOT REPORTED TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER. MINNESOTA OFFICE OF PIPELINE SAFETY OFFICER SWEENEY WAS KEPT INFORMED THROUGHOUT THE EVENT. ON MONDAY, OCTOBER 21,2002,A TEAM ASSESSED THE DAMAGE AND DEVELOPED A COURSE OF ACTION TO REPLACE THE DAMAGED THREE-INCH PIPING THAT SERVES PELICAN RAPIDS AND TO MAKE THE REMAINDER OF THE VALVE SITE SAFE UNTIL THE NEXT WARM SEASON WHEN THE LINE CAN BE REMOVED FROM SERVICE WITHOUT JEOPARDIZING SERVICE TO THOUSAND OF CUSTOMERS. AT THIS TIME AN ESTIMATE WAS MADE FOR THE REPAIRS. THE TEMPORARY REPAIRS WOULD COST APPROXIMATELY $20,000 AND THE PERMANENT REPAIRS, APPROXIMATELY $40,000. THE HIGH COST IS DUE TO THE NEED FOR STOPPER FITTING AND TEMPORARY BYPASS PIPING WHILE REPAIRS ARE MADE. BASED ON THIS INFORMATION, GPNG IMMEDIATELY FIELD AN INCIDENT REPORT WITH THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER, 1730 HOURS, OCTORBER 21, 2002. ON THURSDAY, OCTOBER 24, 2002 AT APPROXIMATELY 9:30 P.M CDT, TEMPORARY REPAIRS TO THE PIPING WERE COMPLETED. GPNG WILL COMPLETE FINAL REPAIRS IN THE SPRING OF 2003."

THE FAILURE OCCURRED AFTER A LEAK HAD BEEN DETECTED AND THE LINE REPAIRED. THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED DURING A ONE-CALL RESPONSE FOR PLANNED THIRD PARTY EXCAVATION IN EARLY NOVEMBER 2002. AT THAT TIME, THE LEAK WAS ISOLATED, A SECTION OF PIPE REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH NEW PIPE. FOLLOWING THE REPAIR, THE ENTIRE PIPELINE WAS SUCCESSFULLY HYDROSTATICALLY TESTED, CLEANED AND DRIED. THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE ON NOVEMBER 23RD. THIRD PARTY EXCAVATION AROUND THE PIPELINE COMMENCED MONDAY, DECEMBER 2, 2002, BACKFILLED AND COMPLETED 1200 HOURS DECEMEBER 3, 2002.TWO HOURS AFTER BACKFILLING WAS COMPLETED, THE EVENT OCCURRED. IT IS SUSPECTED THAT FAILUE OF THE PIPELINE OCCURRED IN THE HEAT-AFFECTED ZONE OF A BUTT WELD ON THE ORIGINAL PIPE MATERIAL THAT HAD BECOME HARDENED AND SUSPECTIBLE TO SUDDEN STRESS RELIEF FAILURE. 10-28-03 A METALLURGICAL EXAMINATION OF THE FAILED WELD REVEALED THAT THIS PIPE MATERIAL HAD FAILED DUE TO THE APPLICATION OF HEAT, WHICH HARDENED AND MADE THE HIGH STRENGTH STEEL SUSCEPTIBLE TO FAILURE. WILLIAMSON THREAD - O RING FITTING.  INITIAL INVESTIGATION IDENTIFIED THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK AS A POSSIBLE FAILED GASKET THAT COULD BE REPAIRED BY PLUGGING THE TAP USING A T.D. WILLIAMSON TOOL, REMOVING THE VALVE AND FLANGE, AND INSTALLING A CAP ON THE 2"" NIPPLE.  SINCE IT WAS LATE IN THE DAY AND THE LEAK WAS SMALL AND DID NOT POSE AN IMMEDIATE OR PROBABLE HAZARD TO THE PUBLIC, IT WAS DECIDED TO SECURE THE WORK SITE AND WAIT UNTIL THE NEXT DAY TO COMPLETE THE WORK.  UPON RETURNING TO THE SITE AND WITH FURTHER INVESTIGATION, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE THREADED NIPPLE TO FLANGE JOINT WAS ACTUALLY LEAKING BUT THAT THE REPAIR COULD BE ACCOMPLISHED USING THE SAME PROCEDURE AS ORIGINALLY PLANNED TO STOP THE LEAK.  WHILE ATTEMPTING TO REMOVE THE DE-PRESSURZIED PIPING DOWNSTREAM OF THE TAP VALVE TO GAIN ACCESS TO THE VALVE FOR ATTACHMENT OF THE T.D. WILLIAMSON TOOL, A SLIGHT MOVEMENT OF THE PIPE CAUSED THE LEAK CHARACTERISTICS TO CHANGE (SOUND OF ESCAPING GAS INCREASED).  UPON RE-EVALUATION IT WAS DECIDED THAT THE THREADS OF THE NIPPLE OR FLANGE MAY BE DAMAGED AND THAT IT WOULD BE UNSAFE FOR THE EMPLOYEES TO PROCEED WITH THE INITIAL REPAIR APPROACH.  AT 12:30 PM JANUARY 10, 2003 A DECISION WAS MADE TO LOWER THE LINE PRESSURE TO ZERO BEFORE ATTEMPTING ANY FURTHER REPAIR THE LEAK.  THE COST OF THE GAS LOST DURING THE BLOW DOWN OF THE PIPELINE WOULD MAKE THE REPAIR COST EXCEED $50,000 CLASSIFYING THE LEAK AS AN INCIDENT.  AN INCIDENT REPORT WAS FILED WITH THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER AT 1:14 PM JANUARY 10, 2003. SINCE THIS LINE PROVIDES SUPPLIES TO LOCAL DISTRIBUTIONS COMPANIES, ALTERNATE GAS SUPPLIES NEEDED TO BE ARRANGED BEFORE REPAIRS COULD BEGIN.  THEREFORE, AS AN ADDITIONAL SAFETY MEASURE, A REQUEST TO GAS CONTROL TO LOWER PRESSURE TO <450PSIG AND NOT TO ALLOW FLUCTUATION WAS MADE AT 7:00 PM FRIDAY, JANUARY 10, 2003 AND THE SITE WAS ALSO BARRICADED AND TAPED OFF WITH WARNING TAPE.  STABILITY OF 440 PSIG WAS ACCOMPLISHED AT 2:00 AM SATURDAY, JANUARY 11, 2003.  THE LEAK AT THIS POINT WAS LIMITED TO APPROXIMATELY 1MCF/HR.  AT 9:00 AM SUNDAY, JANUARY 12, 2003 ALTERNATE GAS FEEDS TO LOCAL DISTRIBUTION COMPANIES WERE INITIATED AND NOTIFICATIONS WERE ALSO MADE TO LOCAL, STATE AND FEDERAL AUTHORITIES AS WELL AS AFFECTED GULF SOUTH CUSTOMERS.  AT 12:15 PM SUNDAY, JANUARY 12, 2003 THE PRESSURE IN THE PIPELINE WAS 313 PSIG AND THE BLOW DOWN OF THE PIPELINE WAS INITIATED.  UPON COMPLETION OF BLOW DOWN, THE FITTINGS WERE REMOVED FROM THE PIPELINE AND INSPECTIONS WERE MADE PRIOR TO FINAL REPAIR.  TWO THREADS OF THE NIPPLE APPEARED TO BE STRIPPED AND THE END OF THE NIPPLE WAS EGG SHAPED RESULTING IN IMPROPER SURFACE CONTACT BETWEEN THE THREADS OF THE TWO COUPLED FITTINGS.  FINAL REPAIR CONSISTED OF CUTTING THE THREADED AREA FROM THE NIPPLE AND WELDING A 2"" CAP TO THE NIPPLE OF THE TAP.  THE WELD WAS X-RAYED AND THE PREVIOUSLY INSTALLED NIPPLE AND WELD SADDLE WERE ALSO DYE PENETRANT CHECKED FOR CRACKING.  THE REPAIR WAS THEN COATED AND THE LINE PURGED AND RE-PRESSURIZED.  THE LINE AND ALL CUSTOMERS WAS RESTORED TO NORMAL SERVICE AT 9:OO PM SUNDAY, JANUARY 12, 2003."

LANDES	7132152001	BILL.R.LANDES@WILLIAMS.COM	7132152687	"INVESTIGATION OF THE INCIDENT FOUND HIGH PRESSURE GAS HAD ENTERED THE LUBE OIL SYSTEM DUE TO A FAILURE OF THE HIGH PRESSURE GAS SEAL. ONCE THE GAS ENTERED THE LUBE OIL SYSTEM, IT VENTED INTO THE BUILDING AND IGNITED. IT APPEARS THE EXPLOSION OCCURRED IN THE ROOF AREA OF THE BUILDING AND BLEW OUT SECTIONS OF WALL ON THREE SIDES. INSPECTION OF THE COMPRESSOR WHEEL REVEALED THE CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT. AT THE BOTTOM OF THE ROTOR, THERE WAS A PIECE OF METAL LODGED IN THE ROTOR. THE METAL WAS 6 TO 8 INCHES LONG AND APPROXIMATELY 1 INCH IN DIAMETER. IT APPEARS IT WAS LARGE ENOUGH TO HAVE JAMMED THE COMPRESSOR WHEEL CAUSING A CATASTROPHIC FAILURE OF THE GAS SEAL. COMPUTER PRINT OUT SHOWED ALL THE ALARMS FUNCTIONED AND INDICATED THE CHAIN OF EVENTS. BOTH ESD AND ESD II FUNCTIONED IMMEDIATELY, THUS ISOLATING THE COMPRESSOR UNIT FROM THE REST OF THE STATION. THE STATION CONTINUED TO RUN WITHOUT INTERRUPTION."

INITIAL OBSERVATIONS OF FAILURE HAVE NOT INDICATED ANY SIGNS OF CORROSION, INTERNAL OR EXTERNAL.  A DETAILED METALLURGICAL INVESTIGATION IS UNDERWAY. 4-29-03 THE FAILURE OCCURRED DUE TO THE CUMULATIVE EFFECTS OF THE NORMAL OPERATING CONDITIONS IN COMBINATION WITH THE COLD ENVIRONMENT ACTING ON A MAJOR SAG BEND PASSING UNDER A CREEK BED.  THE FAILURE INITIATED DUE TO STRESSES CONCENTRATED IN THE PIPE'S DSAW LONGITUDINAL SEAM WHICH COINCIDED WITH THE APEX OF A WRINKLE BEND.  THE AMBIENT TEMPERATURES AFFECTED THE PIPE'S MECHANICAL PROPERTIES AS WELL AS CONTRIBUTED TO PIPE CONTRACTION.  SATURATED OVERBURDEN ALSO CONTRIBUTED TO THE POTENTIAL FOR FROST HEAVE AND UPWARD BUOYANCY OF THE PIPE."

BUSH-IVIE	8326681258	ESBUSH-IVIE@AEP.COM	8326681119	"A CALL WAS RECEIVED IN HPL GAS CONTROL AT APPROXIMATELY 8:45 PM THAT A PIPELINE RUPTURE HAD OCCURRED. THE NOTICE WAS MADE BY A  PERSON FAMILIAR WITH THE PIPELINE INDUSTRY THAT HAPPENED TO BE IN A NEARBY BUSINESS AND CALLED THE EMERGENCY NUMBER ON THE NEAREST PIPELINE MARKER. MORE THAN ONE COMPANY'S PIPELINE RUNS IN THE AREA. HPL PERSONNEL WERE NOTIFIED AND HEADED TOWARD THE SITE. AT ABOUT 9:00, PER GAS CONTROL, A PRESSURE DROP ON OUR PIPELINE WAS OBSERVED. HPL PERSONNEL ARRIVED IN THE AREA ABOUT 9:15 PM AND BASED ON VISUAL OBSERVATIONS AND THE INFORMATION FROM GAS CONTROL TOOK IMMEDIATE ACTION TO SHUT THE VALVES AND ISOLATE THE LEAK. ISOLATION OCCURRED AT APPROXIMATELY 9:30 PM. NO FIRE OCCURRED AND THE GAS QUICKLY DISSIPATED. THE SITE WAS SECURED, EXCAVATED AND 16' OF PIPE WAS REPLACED. REPAIRS WERE COMPLETED AT APPROXIMATELY 8:45 AM THE NEXT MORNING, JANUARY 19, AND SERVICE WAS RESTORED TO THE DISTRIBUTION COMPANY. UPON EXCAVATION OF THE SITE IT BECAME APPARENT THAT THE CAUSE OF THE RUPTURE WAS THIRD PARTY DAMAGE THAT OCCURRED AT SOME INDETERMINATE TIME IN THE PAST. THERE ARE VISUAL, OLD NOT FRESH, TEETH MARKS AND DENTS ON THE PIPE AND DAMAGE TO THE PROTECTIVE COATING. SEVERAL 4"" PVC LINES WERE ENCOUNTERED WHEN EXCAVATING THE SITE. ONE WAS A GRAY WATER/SEWAGE LINE FROM A NEARBY RESTAURANT THAT CROSSED OVER AND WAS ONLY A FEW INCHES ABOVE THE HPL NATURAL GAS PIPELINE. A SUBSEQUENT REVIEW OF THE RECORDS DURING THE TIME OF CONSTRUCTION OF THE RESTAURANT SHOWS THAT NO ONE-CALLS WERE RECEIVED. THE RUPTURE OCCURRED IN A CLASS 3 AREA NEAR COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENTS. SEVERAL VEHICLES WERE DAMAGED. NO INJURIES WERE REPORTED OR OBSERVED AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT. SERVICE TO LOCAL DISTRIBUTION COMPANY CUSTOMERS WAS DISRUPTED. SITE CLEAN-UP WAS COMPLETED THE NEXT DAY, JANUARY 19, AND NEARBY BUSINESSES WERE ABLE TO RE-OPEN."

2003	2616	20030024		COLUMBIA GAS TRANSMISSION CORP	1700 MACORKLE AVENUE SE 	CHARLESTON	 KANAWHA	WV	25314	1330	2/19/2003	HENDERSON	MASON	WV	25550		1861+92			N	1				NO	NO	N	INTRASTATE	2	RUPTURE					1	CIRCUMFERENTIAL-SEPARATION			0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	475000	12752	462248	0	NO	NO	NO	NO	0			1	45	2/19/2003	637230	125	150	NO	YES	NO	NO	NO	N	1	TRANSMISSION	1	BODY OF PIPE		1	STEEL		NO	NO	NO	1	PIPELINE			8	0.38	API-5L-GRADE B	35000	ERW	N/A	UNKNOWN		5	UNDER WATER			3/19/2003	11	OTHER OUTSIDE FORCE DAMAGE									NULL		NULL																	NULL						NULL			NULL			NULL																									NULL	NULL																									"CHRIS LEGG, ENGINEER, PIPELINE SAFETY/SYSTEM INTEGRITY"	3043573227	CLEGG@NISOURCE.COM	3043572408	"AT APPROXIMATELY 1:30 P.M. ON FEBRUARY 19, 2003, COLUMBIA GAS TRANSMISSION CORPORATION'S (COLUMBIA) PIPELINE SM-90 (8"") WAS DISCOVERED TO BE RELEASING GAS INTO THE KANAWHA RIVER. THE GAS RELEASE WAS DISCOVERED BY A RIVER BOAT EMPLOYEE. HE WAS TRAVELING IN A TUG-BOAT THAT WAS APPROACHING SEVERAL NEAR-BY, LOADED COAL BARGES PARKED NEAR AND OVER THE SM-90 PIPELINE. DURING THIS APPROACH, HE NOTICED THE WATER ""BOILING"", AS WELL AS COLUMBIA'S RIVER CROSSING SIGN ON THE ADJANCENT RIVER BANK. HE THEN BACKED THE TUG UP AND NOTIFIED COLUMBIA. THE PIPELINE WAS OPERATING AT 125 PSIG AT THE TIME OF THE RUPTURE. THE RUPTURE OCCURRED APPROXIMATELY 25 FEET INTO THE KANAWHA RIVER BETWEEN THE CITY OF POINT PLEASANT, WV AND THE COMMUNITY OF HENDERSON, WEST VIRGINIA, BOTH IN MASON COUNTY. SM-90 CROSSES THE KANAWHA RIVER AT THE 1.1 MILE MARK, DECENDING. NO DEATHS OR INJURIES RESULTED FROM THE INCIDENT. A COLUMBIA FIELD EMPLOYEE WAS WORKING AT A NEAR-BY PIPELINE FACILITY WHEN HE NOTICED THE PRESSURE DROP AND ACTED PROMPTLY TO ISOLATE THE RUPTURED PIPELINE SECTION. THE RIVER BOAT COMPANY NOTIFIED THE U.S. COAST GUARD, WHO CLOSED THE RIVER TO BOAT-TRAVEL FROM THE ZERO MILE MARKER TO THE THREE MILE MARKER. THEY ALSO ISSUED A ""PROCEED WITH CAUTION"" ORDER FOR THE OHIO RIVER. BY 3:15 P.M., THE LINE WAS ISOLATED AND THE RIVER WAS RE-OPENED FOR TRAVEL. THE CAUSE OF THE RUPTURE IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION AND IS STILL UNKNOWN. COLUMBIA CUT AND CAPPED SM-90 NEAR THE RIVER CROSSING ON ONE SIDE SEVERAL DAYS AFTER THE INCIDENT. THE OPPOSITE SIDE IS ISOLATED BY A VALVE, WHICH IS CHAINED AND LOCKED. THE PIPELINE WILL REMAIN OUT OF SERVICE UNTIL ARRANGEMENT ARE MADE TO INVESTIGATE THE CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT AND REPAIR OR REPLACE THE DAMAGED PIPELINE SECTION.6-14-04 FAILURE ANALYSIS COLUMBIA UTILIZED THE SERVICES OF CROFTON DIVING CORPORATION (CROFTON) TO PROVIDE PROFESSIONAL ASSISTANCE DURING THE PIPELINE RUPTURE INVESTIGATION.  ON APRIL 29, 2003, CROFTON CONDUCTED AND UNDERWATER INVESTIGATION.  IN THEIR MAY 6, 2003 UNDERWATER ASSESSMENT REPORT, CROFTON RECORDED THEIR OBSERVATIONS OF THE PIPELINE AND RIVER BOTTOM CONDITION.  (SEE ATTACHMENTS A, B, AND C FROM THIS REPORT).  THEY FOUND THE PIPELINE  TO BE EXPOSED FROM 2.5' TO 24.5' FROM THE EDGE OF WATER (22'IN TOTAL LENGTH).  IN ADDITION, THE PIPELINE HAD BEEN COMPLETELY SERVERED AND HAD SUFFERED OTHER EXTENSIVE DAMAGE. THEY NOTED THE TOP OF THE PIPE HAD BEEN DISTORTED OR FLATTENED TO VARIED DEGREES WITH THE MAXIMUM DEPTH OF DEPRESSION APPROXIMATELY 4"".  THEY ALSO REPORTED NUMEROUS FRESH SCRAPE MARKS TO THE PIPELINE AND IT'S COATING (COAL TAR) IN THIS SECTION INDICATING RECENT BARGE-RELATED DAMAGE DUE TO THEIR BARGE GROUNDING ACTIVITIES.  THE RIVER BOTTOM TOPOGRAPHY HAD REPORTEDLY BEEN ALTERED DUE TO OUTSIDE FORCES RESULTING IN THE 22' OF EXPOSED PIPELINE.  THIS SECTION WAS NOT EXPOSED ON OCTOBER 8, 2202, WHEN CROFTON PERFORMED THEIR ROUTINELY SCHEDULED PIPELINE RIVER CROSSING SURVEY.  BASED ON THE EVIDENCE AND SUPPORTED BY CROFTON'S UNDERWATER CONDITION ASSESSMENT, COLUMBIA HAS CONCLUDED THE CAUSE OF INCIDENT WAS OBIVIOUSLY A STRIKE FROM A RIVER BARGE THAT HAD BEEN GROUNDED INTO RIVER BOTTOM SLOPE AND OUR PIPELINE.  FURTHERMORE, SCOURING OF THE RIVER BOTTOM HAD OCCURRED EITHER PRIOR TO OR DURING THE MOST RECENT GROUNDING EVENT.  THE PIPELINE WAS REPAIRED BY REPLACING THE DAMAGED PIPE SECTION, BACKFILLING WITH SELECT MATERIAL AND THEN PLACING A FLEXIBLE CONCRETE ARTICULATING MAT OVER THE REPAIR AREA.  THIS MAT IS INTENDED PROTECT THE PIPELINE FORM FUTURE UNDERMINING AND DAMAGE. (SEE ATTACHMENT D AND E FROM THIS REPORT) COLUMBIA HAS CONTACTED THE US COAST GUARD ABOUT THE UNSAFE GROUNDING PRACTICES THAT HAVE OCCURRED AT OUR PIPELINE CROSSING LOCATION.  COLUMBIA IS ALSO IN THE PROCESS OF CONTACTING THE TUGBOAT COMPANY(S) TO INFORM THEM OF THE DANGERS AND LIABILITIES OF THESE GROUNDING ACTIVITIES IN CLOSE PROXIMITY TO GAS PIPELINE FACILITIES."

THE CONTRACTOR WAS DRAINING ON TANK AND WHILE THAT TANK WAS DRAINING HE ATTEMPTED TO USE A PROPANE TORCH TO THAW A VALVE IN PREPARATION FOR DRAINING ANOTHER TANK.  THE CONTRACTOR HAD NOT HOOKED HIS DRAIN HOSE TO THE SECOND TANK AS IT WAS BEING USED AT THE OTHER TANK.  A KINDER MORGAN EMPLOYEE WITNESSED FLAMES ERUPT FROM A 3"" DRAIN VALVE DURING THE THAWING PROCESS.  THE FIRE OCCURRED AS A RESULT OF THE CONTRACTOR OPENING THE VALVE ON THE TANK WHILE USING THE TORCH.  THIS ALLOWED A PATH FOR AN IGNITION SOURCE TO ENTER THE TANK AND ALSO CAUSED A SMALL RELEASE OF LIQUID WHICH WAS IGNITED BY THE TORCH.  FAILING TO HOOK UP THE HOSE TO THE SECOND TANK BEFORE ATTEMPTING TO THAW THE VALVE IS AGAINST ACCEPTED PRACTICE.  AND OPENING UP THE VALVE WHILE USING THE TORCH IS A VIOLATION AGAINST THE PROCEDURE SET OUT IN OM 103 - HOT WORK AND AGAINST PROCEDURES REVIEWED IN THE KINDER MORGAN CONTRACTOR SAFETY PROGRAM.  UPON EXTINGUISHING THE FIRE AT THE VALVE, THE CONTRACTOR CLAIMS THAT HE HEARD A RUMBLING INSIDE THE TANK, AND HE CLIMBED THE LADDER AND OPENED THE THIEF HATCH TO INVESTIGATE.  THE CONTRACTOR WAS BURNED AFTER HE OPENED THE THEIF HATCH AND WAS EXPOSED TO THE INTENSE HEAT BUILT UP FROM PROBABLE TANK FIRE.  THIS HEAT ESCAPED FROM THE HATCH AND CAUSED 1ST AND 2ND DEGREE BURNS ON HIS FACE AND LEFT HAND.  THE DRIVER WAS ADMITTED TO A LOCAL HOSPITAL FOR OBSERVANCE AND MEDICATED FOR PAIN."

MCDONALD	8326765459	JIM.MCDONALD@ELPASO.COM	8326761782	"ON MARCH 2, 2003, AT 11:52 AM, A LEAK REPORT WAS CALLED INTO THE NRC IN BLOCK HIA 555. DURING A ROUTINE FLYOVER, OUR HELICOPTER PILOT HAD NOTICED BUBBLING AT THE OCEAN SURGACE OVER OUR HIOS PIPELINE.  EL PASO FIELD SERVICES OPERATES SEVERAL PIPELINES IN THE AREA OF THE LEAK.  FURTHER INVESTIGATION IDENTIFIED THE AREA AS A LOCATION WHERE OUR HIA 531 LATERAL AND OUR HIA 557 LATERAL INTERCONNECT WITH OUR HIA 20"" PIPELINE.  WE PROCEEDED TO SHUT IN PRODUCTION ON THE HIA 557 LATERAL TO DETERMINE IF PRESSURE ON THE LATERAL SYSTEM WOULD DROP.  IT DID NOT.  ON MARCH 3, 2003 WE PROCEEDED TO SHUT IN ALL OTHER PRODUCTION IN THE AREA TO PREVENT THE CONTINUANCE OF GAS LOSS.  THIS WAS COMPLETED BY 4:00 PM.  A DIVE VESSEL WITH AN ROV WAS MADE AVAILABLE ON MARCH 5, 2003.  THE DIVE TEAM IDENTIFIED TWO LEAKS AT THE SUBSEA TIE IN.  ONE WAS A STEM LEAK ON THE HIOS 20"" CHECK VALVE WHICH WE REPAIRED AND THE OTHER WAS A GASKET LEAK ON 20"" RTJ 900 SERIES SWIVEL FLANGE ON THE HIA 531 INTERCONNECT WHERE WE FOUND THAT THE FLANGE HAD BEEN IMPROPERLY TORQUED.  WE MADE THE NECESSARY REPAIRS AND RETURNED THE PIPELINES TO SERVICE ON MARCH 5, 2003 AT 10:00 PM.  THE GAS LOSS AND THE DAMAGE TO MATERIAL WAS MINIMAL.  HOWEVER, THE COST TO MAKE THE SUBSEA REPAIR WAS $208.000."

VON MCALLISTER	8015846851	VON.MCALLISTER@KERNRIVERGAS.COM	8015846330	"ON APRIL 3, 2003 AT 1710 HRS, AN INTENTIONAL EMERGENCY SHUT DOWN (ESD) WAS INITIATED AT THE MUDDY CREEK COMPRESSOR STATION ""B"" PLANT, DURRING THE COMMISSIONING PROCESS. THIS IS A NEW STATION, CURRENTLY UNDER CONSTRUCTION, WHICH IS NOT YET IN SERVICE. THE ESD SYSTEM WAS USED TO BLOW DOWN THE STATION PIPING AT THE END OF THE WORK DAY. THE GAS DISCHARGING FROM THE VENT STACK IGNITED APPROXIMATLY 5 SECONDS INTO THE BLOW DOWN. THE FLAME WAS OBSERVED TO EMERGE FROM WITHIN THE STACK. THE GAS CONTINUED TO VENT AND BURN FOR APPROXIMATELY 15 MINUTES. THE WIND WAS VERY STRONG, AND KEPT THE GAS FIRE CLOSE TO THE GROUND, AND DIRECTED TO THE EAST. THE FIRE CONSUMED OR DAMAGED A MAN-LIFT CRANE, TWO TRASH DUMPSTERS, AND SOME VALVES AND OTHER MATERIALS STORED ON PALLETS. A SMALL GRASS AND BRUSH FIRE WAS ALSO STARTED.    THE IGNITION IS BELIEVED TO HAVE BEEN CAUSED BY STATIC ELECTRICITY. THE STATIC BUILD UP MIGHT HAVE BEEN PREVENTED IF THE GROUNDING OF THE BLOW DOWN STACK HAD BEEN COMPLETED."

AT APPROXIMATELY, 1:50 AM MAY 21, 2003, CONFIRMATION WAS MADE THAT THE RUPTURE HAD OCCURRED ON THE HOUSTON PIPE LINE TEXOMA 30"" LINE.  IDENTIFICATION OF THE RUPTURED LINE WAS NOT POSSIBLE EARLIER DUE TO SITE LOGISTICS AND BECAUSE OF SEVERAL PIPELINES IN THE VICINITY OF THE RUPTURE SITE.  AN UPSTREAM RAPID FLOW DROP DEVICE CLOSED AND OTHER VALVES ON THE SYSTEM WERE MANUALLY CLOSED.  THE FIRE BURNED ITSELF OUT ABOUT 3 AM.  THE RUPTURE AND FIRE DAMAGED NEARBY ELECTRIC LINES AND SEVERAL UNOCCUPIED BUILDINGS THAT WERE PART OF THE SUNOCO TERMINAL FACILITY.  NO INJURIES OR DEATHS WERE REPORTED.  INVESTIGATION AS TO THE CAUSE AND ORIGIN OF THE INCIDENT IS ONGOING; HOWEVER, IT APPEARS THAT INTERNAL CORROSION MAY HAVE PLAYED A PART.  AFTER THE INVESTIGATION IS COMPLETED, HPL WILL FILE A SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT.  THE RUPTURE OF THE LINE OCCURRED AT A LATERAL AT THE FARTHEST END OF THE LINE, WHICH CONTAINED CUSHION GAS.  THAT LATERAL SECTION WILL NOT BE REPLACED.  THE LINE WILL NOW TERMINATE AT STATION 765,  THE PIPE WAS INSPECTED AT ALL POST-RUPTURE CUTS OF THE PIPE FOR INTERNAL CORROSION.  NO CORROSION WAS IDENTIFIED IN ANY OF THE PIPE THAT HAD BEEN IN CONTINUOUS SERVICE.  AN IN-LINE INSPECTION TOOL (""SMART"" PIG) WAS RUN FROM THE NEW TERMINUS OF THE 30"" PIPE (STATION 765), THROUGH THE RIVER CROSSING AND UPSTREAM TO A TEMPORARY RECEIVER AT STATION 9794, A TOTAL OF 9029' - OR 1.71 MILES.  THE FOCUS OF THE RUN WAS THE RIVER CROSSING UNDER THE NECHES RIVER.  NO CORROSION OR OTHER ANOMALIES WERE IDENTIFIED.  THE NECHES RIVER CROSSING IS TYPICAL OF OTHER RIVER CROSSING ON THE TEXOMA PIPELINE.  IN FACT, THE ELEVATION AND SLOPE CHANGE IS MOST SIGNIFICANT AT THIS SITE DUE TO THE DEPTH OF THE CHANNEL FOR SHIPPING.  THERE, HPL, IS CONFIDENT THAT OTHER RIVER CROSSINGS ARE IN SIMILARLY GOOD SHAPE.  THE PIPELINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE ON JUNE 6, 2003. 10-15-04 - CORROSION APPEARED TO HAVE OCCURRED DUE TO STANDING WATER IN LOW SPOT OF A DEAD LEG.  THE PIPE HAD BEEN CLEANED AND PIGGED DURING CONVERSION FROM LIQUID TO GAS TRANSMISSION IN THE LATE 1980'S.  IT IS BELIEVE THE WATER REMAINED FROM THAT OPERATION.  NO OTHER CORROSION MECHANISM WAS IDENTIFIED.  PUBLIC/PRIVATE PROPERTY DAMAGE INCLUDES INTERRUPTION OF BUSINESS AT THE SUNOCO MARINE TERMINAL."

LIQUIDS WERE BEING REMOVED FROM THE SYSTEM AND TRANSFERRED TO TEMPORARY STORAGE TANKS ON THE RIGHT-OF-WAY.VACUUM / TRANSPORT TRUCKS WERE REMOVING LIQUIDS FROM THE TANKS WHEN A APPARENT MALFUNCTION ON ONE OF THE TRUCKS SPARKED CAUSING A FLASH FIRE. THE ACTUAL CAUSE OF THE FIRE IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION. LOCAL EMERGENCY PERSONNEL IN CONJUNCTION WITH HPL DECIDED TO LET THE FIRE BURN UNTIL IT COULD BE MORE EASILY EXTINGUISHED. NO INJURIES WERE REPORTED IN THE FIRE AND NO DEATHS OCCURRED. A VOLUNTEER FIREMAN WAS TREATED FOR HEAT EXHAUSTION. BELL HOLES WERE EXCAVATED TO EXAMINE THE PIPELINE FOR POSSIBLE HEAT EFFECTS. NONE WERE DETECTED. NO PIPELINE VALVES OR OTHER SURFACE EQUIPMENT WAS DAMAGED. FOLLOWING EXTINGUISHMENT OF THE FIRE, THE PIGGING OPERATION WAS FINISHED AND THE PIPELINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE. NO GAS WAS LOST OR VENTED DUE TO THE FIRE.    FINAL UPDATE...AUGUST 07, 2009    THIS INCIDENT OCCURRED DURING A PIGGING OPERATION OF AN INTRASTATE PIPELINE. PIPELINE PRESSURE WAS EVACUATED DURING THIS LIQUID REMOVAL PROCESS, WITH THE EXCEPTION OF 50 PSIG OF NATURAL GAS, USED TO PUSH THE MAINTENANCE PIG. FINAL INVESTIGATION CONCLUDED THAT A TRANSPORT TRUCK, USED TO HAUL THE CONDENSATE FROM THIS SITE, EXPERIENCED A MALFUNCTION OF A SAFETY SWITCH ON THE DIESEL ENGINE, RESULTING IN IGNITION OF THE VAPORS OFF THE FRAC TANKS.  THE ONLY PRODUCT LOSS DURING THIS INCIDENT WAS THE LIQUID CONDENSATE DURING THE FIRE. PROPERTY DAMAGES WERE LIMITED TO THE FRAC TANKS AND DIESEL TRUCKS OWNED BY THE THIRD PARTY CONTRACTOR. THERE WERE NO ADDITIONAL DAMAGES TO COMPANY FACILITIES OR PROPERTY."

GULF SOUTH PERSONNEL RETURNED THE FOLLOWING MORNING AND REMOVED DAMAGED GASKET AND REPLACED WITH NEW ONE. UPON ARRIVING AT THE LOCATION, HE WAS WAVED DOWN BY A CREW (3 MEN) WITH A BACKHOE.  OUR EMPLOYEES ASKED THE EXCAVATION CREW ABOUT THE LEAK, BUT THEY SAID THEY DIDN'T KNOW ANYTHING ABOUT A LEAK.  THE EXCAVATION CREW SAID THAT THEY JUST WANTED THE PIPELINE LOCATED SO THEY COULD DO SOME DIGGING TO LOCATE A WATER LEAK.  OUR EMPLOYEE FLAGGED AND PAINTED THE LOCATION OF THE PIPELINE.  THE EXCAVATION CREW ALSO WANTED TO KNOW THE DEPTH OF THE LINE.  OUR EMPLOYEE INFORMED THE EXCAVATOR THAT DUE TO THE PRESENT OF A LAYER OF STEEL SLAG IN THE GROUND THEY WOULD HAVE TO REMOVE THE SLAG BEFORE AN ACCURATE DEPTH PROBE COULD BE CONDUCTED.  AT THAT POINT THE EXCAVATION CREW SAID THEY COULD NOT BE WORKING TOWARD THE LINE, BUT WOULD BE DIGGING AWAY FROM THE PIPELINE AND THAT WOULD NOT BE NECESSARY.  THE EMPLOYEE GAVE THE CREW LEADER A BUSINESS CARD AND TOLD HIM TO CALL IF ANY CHANGES WERE MADE IN THE PLANS THAT WOULD CAUSE THEM TO DIG BACK TOWARD THE PIPELINE. THE COMPANY'S EMPLOYEE RETURNED TO HIS REGULAR WORK DUTIES.  AT ABOUT 16:30 THE SAME DAY OUR EMPLOYEE RECEIVED A CALL THE EXCAVATOR REPORTING THAT A PIPELINE HAD BLEW AND HE THOUGHT STREAM WAS COMING OUT OF THE PIPELINE.  OUR COMPANY'S EMPLOYEE INFORMED THE EXCAVATOR TO EVACUATE THE WORKING AREA. WHEN OUR COMPANY'S EMPLOYEE WAS ON THE WAY TO THE WORK SITE HE RECEIVED A CALL FROM UNITED STATES STEEL COMPANY CONFIRMING THAT THE COMPANY'S PIPELINE WAS LEAKING.  FIRE AND LOCAL POLICE HAD THE LOCATION SECURED WHEN THE COMPANY'S FIELD EMPLOYEE.  THE PIPELINE HAD A GOUGE AT 9.5"" X 4.0"" THAT APPEARED TO MATCH THE TEETH ON THE BACKHOE.  THE EXCAVATION CREW DID NOT ADMIT TO HITTING THE LINE.  THE PIPELINE WAS REPAIRED WITH PRE-TESTED PIPE. ALL WELDS X-RAYED, AND THE PIPELINE SECTION WAS PRESSURE TESTED FOR 30 MINUTES PER DOT REQUEST.  THE PIPELINE WAS PUT BACK INTO NORMAL SERVICE AT 11:35 ON 8/27/03."

DAN WILLIAMS AND POLING AND BACON CONSTRUCTION COMPANY.  MR. WILLIAMS, WELDER'S HELPER, WAS HOLDING AND ALIGNING AN 8-INCH WELD END CAP TO AN EXISTING 20 X 8 INCH TEE.  WHEN THE CONTRACT WELDER STRUCK AN ARC TO BEGIN THE WELDING OPERATION, A FLASH FIRE OCCURRED. AN UNANTICIPATED COMBUSTIBLE GAS MIXTURE HAD DEVELOPED WITHIN THE NORTHERN END OF THE ABOVE GRADE LINE 1278 HEADER WITHIN THE EAGLE COMPRESSOR STATION YARD.  THIS COMBUSTIBLE MIXTURE WAS BELIEVED TO BE PRINCIPALLY ATTRIBUTED TO VALVE L-7208 LEAKING AND NOT BEING ABLE TO ACHIEVE ADEQUATE SHUT OFF AND THE REMOVAL OF THE PRIMARY FRESH AIR SOURCE.  ALIGNING THE WELD CAP OVER THE LAST SIGNIFICANT SOURCE OF FRESH AIR CHANGE THE FLOW DYNAMICS THAT HAD MAINTAINED NON-COMBUSTIBLE LIMITS JUST MOMENTS BEFORE.  TWO AIR MOVERS LOCATED AT BOTH ENDS OF THIS HEADER SYSTEM WERE EVACUATING THE PIPING AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT.  COLUMBIA WILL FILE A SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT WITH A MORE DETAILED ACCOUNT AND PHOTOGRAPHS. 12-11-03 THE INVESTIGATION RESTRICTED ITSELF TO THE EVENTS DIRECTLY CONNECTED TO THE SINGLE SUBJECT WELD ON THE SOUTHERN END OF THE LINE 1278 ABOVE GRADE HEADER. ON TUESDAY NIGHT, SEPTEMBER 9, 2003, COLUMBIA PERSONNEL BEGAN AN OVERSIGHT PROCESS TO BLOW DOWN LINE 1278 FROM SHELMIRE VALVE SETTING TO EAGLE COMPRESSOR STATION (A DISTANCE OF 4.26), THE 20-INCH LINE 1278 DISCHARGE HEADER INSIDE THE COMPRESSOR STATION FIRE VALVES, THE ABOVE GRADE LINE 1278 HEADER FEEDING NORTH, AND PARTS OF LINE 1556.  THE PURPOSE OF THIS BLOW DOWN WAS TO FACILITATE TIE-IN OF NEW LINE 1896 20-INCH PIPELINE AND MAKE MODIFICATIONS TO EXISTING PIPING.  SPECIFICALLY, THESE MODIFICATIONS CONSISTED OF THE REMOVAL OF EXISTING PIPING AND REGULATORS FABRICATED BETWEEN THE BLOW OFFS ON LINES 1278, 1804, AND 1896 AND THE SOUTHERN END OF THE LINE 1278 HEADER.  THESE BLOW OFFS ARE IMMEDIATELY WEST OF THE ABOVE GRADE LINE 1278 HEADER (SEE ATTAHCED PHOTOS) NIGHT WORK WAS UNDERTAKEN TO FACILITATE A SERIES OF OTHER CONSTRUCTION OUTAGES SCHEDULED FOR THE FOLLOWING DAY IN OTHER PARTS OF COLUMBIA'S PIPELINE SYSTEM.  AFTER THE INITIAL BLOW DOWN WAS COMPLETED AND AFTER OTHER TIE IN WORK WAS PERFORMED, A SMALL ONSITE CREW SET OUT TO WELD ON 8-INCH WELD END CAP IN A LOCATION WHERE PREVIOUS 10-INCH PIPING HAD BEEN CONNECTED WITH A 10 X 8 INCH REDUCER ON THE SOUTHERN END OF THE LINE 1278 HEADER SEE PHOTO P1 AND FIGURE 1."

THE DENT, WHICH WAS LOCATED ON THE BODY OF THE PIPE AT APPROXIMATELY THE 6 O'CLOCK POSITION, WAS THEORIZED TO BE CAUSED OVER TIME BY A ROCK SITUATED UNDER THE PIPE.  THE DENT DEPTH TO DIAMETER RATIO WAS 2.5% AND THE MAXIMUM AXIAL STRAIN IN THE DENT WAS APPROXIMATELY 22%.  THE CRACK WAS ORIENTED AT AN ANGLE OF APPROXIMATELY 55 DEGREES WITH RESPECT TO THE AXIS OF THE PIPE AND HAD A LENGTH OF APPROXIMATELY 1.25 INCHES.  IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE CRACK INITIATED ON THE ID PIPE SURFACE.  THE CRACK IS NOT A PUNCTURE FROM A ROCK SINCE A PUNCTURE WOULD INITIATE ON THE OD SURFACE.  THE INITIATION OF CRACKING WAS LIKELY ASSOCIATED WITH DUCTILE TEARING, BASED ON THE HIGH TENSILE STRAINS AT THE DENT APEX ON THE ID SURFACE AND THE 45 DEGREE ANGLE OF THE CRACK WITH RESPECT TO THE PIPE WALL.  THERE WAS NO EVIDENCE THAT THE CRACKING WAS ASSOCIATED WITH ANY METALLURGICAL DEFICIENCY IN THE PIPE.  THE MECHANICAL PROPERTIES OF THE STEEL MEET THE SPECIFICATIONS FOR API 5L X-65 LINE PIPE AND THE MICROSTRUCTURE IS TYPICAL OF THIS VINTAGE AND GRADE OF PIPE STEEL.  IN GENERAL, THE CHEMISTRY OF THE STEEL ALSO MEETS SPECIFICATIONS."

LINE PRESSURE GOT ABOVE 900 PSI AND CAUSED RELIEF VALVE TO RELIEVE TO ATMOSPHERE.  THERE WAS A MISCOMMUNICATION BETWEEN FIELD OPERATIONS AND GAS CONTROL REGARDING THE APPROPRIATE PRESSURE TO OPERATE THE PIPELINE.  FIELD OPERATIONS HAD INSTALLED AND SET THE RELIEF VALVE AT A CONSERVATIVE LEVEL BASED UPON HISTORICAL MOP AND THE CENTRAL GAS CONTROL DID NOT HAVE THIS INFORMATION.  THIS RESULTED IN THEIR DECISION TO INCREASE THE LINE PRESSURE TO A LEVEL THAT WAS STILL BELOW THE MAOP BUT ABOVE THE SET PRESSURE OF THE RELIEF VALVE, CAUSING IT TO TRIGGER AND RELIEVE GAS TO THE ATMOSPHERE."

AN O & M TECH WAS CALLED OUT THE STATION.  UPON ARRIVING THE TECH NOTICED A SMALL FIRE LOCATED IN THE ""V"" OF THE ENGINE COMING FROM THE SPEED CONTROL ACTUATOR AND EXTINGUISHED THE FIRE.  INSPECTION OF THE ENGINE SHOWED THAT A FAN SHAFT WAS BROKEN IN HALF.  DUE TO INCORRECT WIRING FROM A PREVIOUS REPAIR, THE ENGINE DID NOT SHUT DOWN AND OVERHEATED.  THE HEAT FROM THE ENGINE BLOCK MELTED THE INSULATION ON THE #10 IGNITION WIRE CAUSING THE SPARK WHICH IGNITED LEAKING CONTROL GAS TO THE ACTUATOR.  IT COULD NOT BE DETERMINE WHETHER THE CONTROL GAS LEAK FROM THE ACTUATOR WAS LEAKING PREVIOUSLY OR THE HEAT FROM THE OVERHEATED ENGINE AFFECTED THE INTEGRITY OF THE DIAPHRAGM IN THE CONTROLLER CAUSING THE LEAK."

OTHER PARTY UNKNOWN."			MIKE LEGER	3372338945	MLEGER@AEP.COM	3372372554	"CAUSE OF INCIDENT AND TYPE IS UNKNOWN AS OF THIS INITIAL REPORT.  INCIDENT OCCURRED IN 25 - 30 FEET OF WATER ON THE WEST SIDE OF BELLE PASS IN THE GULF OF MEXICO + - 1.8 MILES SOUTH OF THE BANK LINE ROCK JETTY.  ON THE MORNING OF THE INCIDENT (9/5/02), THE 12"" PIPELINE WAS ISOLATED FROM THE COMPANY'S PIPELINE SYSTEM AND FROM ALL PRODUCTION IN TO THE 12"" PIPELINE.  PIPELINE REMAINS DEPRESSURIZED AND ISOLATED AS OF 9/5/02.  A FULL INVESTIGATION, VISUAL INSPECTION, EXAMINATION, TESTING, AND REPAIR OF THE PIPELINE SECTION HAS BEEN RESTRICTED DUE TO WATER DEPTH, WEATHER CIRCUMSTANCES, AND MARINE CONDITIONS.  SCHEDULING OF REPAIRS REMAINS CONTINGENT UPON WEATHER AND MARINE CONDITIONS.  UPON COMMENCEMENT OF FIELD REPAIRS ON LOCATION, ALL RETRIEVABLE EVIDENCE WILL BE COLLECTED AND THE INVESTIGATION WILL CONTINUE TO DETERMINE INCIDENT TYPE AND POSSIBLE CAUSE.  A SUPPLEMENT REPORT WILL BE REQUIRED TO FORWARD INFORMATION NOT COMPLETED IN THE INITAL REPORT OF 10/3/04.  12-29-03 ON 9/11/02 A SIDE SCAN SONAR/SUB BOTTOM PROFILER SURVEY WAS PERFORMED AT THE PIPELINE INCIDENT BY T. BAKER SMITH & SONS INC.  THE DATA CAPTURED BY THE SURVEY WAS PLOTTED AND REVIEWED ON 9/12/02.  THE INTERPRETATION OF THE DATA BY THE SURVEY COMPANY PROJECT MANAGER WAS THAT THE INCIDENT OCCURRED AT THE APPROXIMATE LOCATION INDICATED ON THE ATTACHED MAP IN ABOUT 26 FEET OF WATER.  THE CRATER DIMENSIONS MEASURED + - 117 FEET IN LENGTH, + - 1 - 2 FEET IN DEPTH, AND VARIED APPROXIMATELY 1 FOOT TO 15 FEET IN WIDTH.  IT APPEARS THAT THERE IS A GAP BETWEEN THE TWO ENDS OF THE PIPE IN THE CRATER MEASURING + - 13.5 FEET. ON 10/7/-2, THREE DAYS AFTER HURRICAN LILI, ANOTHER SIDE SCAN SONAR/ SUB BOTTOM PROFILER SURVEY WAS PERFORMED AT THE PIPELINE INCIDENT BY T. BAKER SMITH & SONS INC.  THE DATA CAPTURED BY THIS SURVEY WAS PLOTTED AND REVIEWED ON 10/9/02.  THE INTERPRETATION OF THIS DATA BY THE SURVEY COMPANY PROJECT MANAGER INDICATED THAT THE WATER DEPTH OVER THE INCIDENT CHANGED BY ABOUT 2 FEET TO 28 FEET.  THE + -13.5 FEET GAP BETWEEN TWO ENDS OF THE PIPE REMAINED THE SAME IN THE CRATER.  IT DID APPEAR THAT THE STORM DID CAUSE A SIGNIFICANT CHANGE IN THE SUB-SEAN TERRAIN SURROUNDING THE PIPELINE AND THE CRATER.  ON 11/16/2002, THE 12"" PIPELINE WAS CUT AT THE LAND PORTION ON THE WEST SIDE OF THE BELLE PASS TO SEPARATE AND SEGMENT THE PIPELINE (SEE ATTACHED MAP). A 10 - 15 FOOT SECTION OF PIPE WAS REMOVED FROM THE LINE.  A VISUAL INSPECTION OF THE PIPE SECTION REMOVED AND THE END OF THE NORTH SEGMENT PERFORMED AND THERE WERE NO APPARENT DEFECTS INTERNALLY OR EXTERNALLY ON THE STEEL PIPE OR ON THE COATING.  ALSO, THERE WAS NO APPARENT WALL LOSS ON EACH PIECE INSPECTED.  A 12"" PIPELINE RISER WITH A LOR FLANGE AND BLIND WAS INSTALLED ON THE NORTH SECTION  AND THEN WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE. THE SECTION HAD NOT BEEN IN SERVICE SINCE THE 9/5/02 INCIDENT.  THE SOUTH SECTION WAS CAPPED AND REMAINED DEPRESSURIZED.  DISCUSSIONS ARE ON GOING BETWEEN LIGC AS OPERATOR/OWNER OF THE LINE AND THE CUSTOMER ON A SOLUTION TO RESOLVE THE CURRENT STATUS AND CONDTION OF THE SOUTH SEGMENT OF THE PIPELINE THAT INCURRED THE INCIDENT.  SCHEDULING OF RETRIEVING SUB-SEA PHYSICAL EVIDENCE FOR FURTHER INVESTIGATION IS CURRENTLY CONTINGENT UPON A RESOLUTION BETWEEN LIGC AND THE CUSTOMER AND ALSO UPON FAVORABLE WEATHER AND MARINE CONDITIONS.  AN ADDITIONAL REPORT WILL BE REQUIRED TO FORWARD INFORMATION NOT COMPLETED IN THIS SUPPLEMENT REPORT OF 11/14/02 UPDATING STATUS AND INFORMATION AND AFTER EVIDENCE IS RECOVERED, EXAMINED, AND TESTED. 12-23-03(FINAL) FOUND AND RETRIEVED LARGE SEA ANCHOR ATTACHED TO PIPELINE AT INCIDENT LOCATION.  ANCHOR PLACED THE PIPELINE IN STRESS CAUSING THE INCIDENT.  ANCHOR WAS ABANDON IN PLACE ON 12"" PIPELINE BY OTHER PARTY.  OTHER PARTY IDENTIFICATION UNKNOWN WAS OF THE DATE OF THIS REPORT."

THE PIPELINE WAS TOTALLY SEVERED, CAUGHT FIRE AND BURNED FOR ALMOST AN HOUR.  AT THE TIME OF THE RUPTURE THE PIPELINE WAS OPERATING AT 915 PSI AND HAD AND ESTIMATED 16,451 BBLS OF CONDENSATE AND 1,936 MCF OF NATURAL GAS IN THE 11 MILE SECTION.  THE CHECK VALVE THAT IS AT THE EUGENE ISLAND BLOCK # 32 PLATFORM CLOSED AND THE LINE WAS SHUT-IN INSTANTANEOUSLY.  GULF SOUTH NOTIFIED IT'S SPILL RESPONSE CONTRACTOR IMMEDIATELY TO RESPOND.  BY DAYLIGHT WHEN THE FIRST FLY OVER WAS MADE WITH THE U.S. COAST GUARD ON BOARD THEIR WAS NO SIGNIFICANT ENVIRONMENTAL DAMAGE AND THE COAST GUARD REQUIRED NO FURTHER RESPONSE.  IN THE MEANTIME WE HAD ALREADY SET CONTRACTORS (DIVERS, VESSELS AND EQUIPMENT) TO THE RUPTURE LOCATION. ON NOVEMBER 24TH GULF SOUTH WAS NOTIFIED BY TELEPHONE FROM THE CONTRACTOR (WEEKS MARINE) OF THE DREDGE CROSSING THE PIPELINE.  ON NOVEMBER 26TH THE PIPELINE WAS SURVEYED AND MARKED BY A LICENSED SURVEYOR WERE IT CROSSED THE CHANNEL.  THE SURVEY INFOMRMATION WAS FAXED TO THE DREDGE BARGE TOM JAMES AND ARRANGEMENTS WERE MADE WITH WEEKS MARINE FOR A GULF SOUTH EMPLOYEE TO PICKED UP AND BROUGHT TO THE DREDGE AT 6:00 AM ON DECEMBER 2ND TO MAKE THE CROSSING.  APPROXIMATELY 12:15 AM ON DECEMBER 2ND THE DREDGE STRUCK AND RUPTURED THE PIPELINE.   RISERS REMOVED AND 1,664 FEET OF PIPE REMOVED FROM SHIPPING CHANNEL.  REMAINER ABANDONED IN PLACE ON MAY 31, 2009."

THE COMPRESSOR STATION ESD WAS ACTIVATED, WHICH RESULTED IN DEPRIVATION OF A FUEL SOURCE TO THE FIRE AND THE FIRE QUICKLY BURNED ITSELF OUT."

MAUREEN BALL	6076890195	MBALL@CNYOG.COM	6076890385	"TWO CNYOG OPERATORS WERE PERFORMING A ROUTINE MAINTENANCE OPERATION TO CLEAN A STRAINER BASKET IN THE GAS LINE ON A STRAINER SKID WHICH IS INTEGRATED INTO THE SURFACE FACILITIES OF ONE OF THE COMPANY'S TEN NATURAL GAS STORAGE WELLS.  THE SURFACE FACILITIES FOR THE WELL ARE LOCATED IN A PROTECTIVE METAL BUILDING SPACE WITH AN ELECTRICAL CLASSIFICATION OF CLASS I DIVISION I. THE OPERATORS CLOSED THE TWO ISOLATION VALVES AT THE PERIMETER OF THE BUILDING AND OPENED THE LARGE ROLL-UP DOOR AND PERSONNEL DOOR AT ONE END OF THE SPACE, THE DOUBLE PERSONNEL DOOR AT THE OTHER END OF THE SPACE, AND THE FOUR 4' X 4' VENTS ON THE SIDE OF THE BUILDING (TWO ON EACH SIDE) FOR VENTILATION DURING THE VENTING PROCESS.  THEY STARTED THE VENTING PROCESS BY PARTIALLY OPENING TWO SMALL BALL VALVES AND THEN BOTH WALKED OUTSIDE THE BUILDING TO AWAIT COMPLETION OF THE VENTING PROCESS IN ACCORDING WITH THE ESTABLISHED PRACTICE.  AN UNKNOWN IGNITION SOURCE IGNITED THE GAS IN THE SPACE.  SMALL FIRES AT THE TWO VENTING VALVES BURNED FOR 10-15 MINUTES UNTIL THEY WERE EXTINGUISHED BY A FIRE EXTINGUISHER JUST BEFORE THEY BURNED OUT.  THERE WAS NO APPARENT DAMAGE TO ANY OF THE SURFACE EQUIPMENT OR GAS PIPING EXCEPT FOR DAMAGE TO INSTRUMENTATION AND ELECTRICAL CONDUIT AND FOR SOME POSSIBLE HEAT RELATED DAMAGE TO ONE SECTION  OF PIPING."

THERE HAS BEEN RECENTLY LOGGING AND UNAUTHORIZED GRADING WITHIN THE RIGHT-OF-WAY OF THIS PIPE.  ATLANTA GAS LIGHT COMPANY'S RIGHT-OF-WAY SURVEYOR, WHO HAD WALKED THIS LINE A WEEK BEFORE THE INCIDENT, REPORTED SIGNIFICANT LANDSCAPE AND GRADING CHANGES.  ATLANTA GAS LIGHT COMPANY WAS MADE AWARE OF THE PIPELINE FAILURE THROUGH MONITORING PRESSURE LOGS AT JESUP AND BELLE VISTA, DOWNSTREAM OF THE FAILURE. 6-28-04 ON SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 2004 AT APPROXIMATELY 1:30 AM, A SECTION OF THE BRUNSWICK LATERAL 7.5 MILES SOUTH OF THE DOCTORTOWN (JESUP) MAINLINE VALVE (MLV) FAILED.  THE PRESSURE DROP WAS FIRST NOTED BY ATLANTA GAS LIGHT COMPANY PERSONNEL AT 1:35AM. THIS LINE IS LOCATED ON AN EASEMENT OWNED BY AGLC.  IN THE WEEK PRIOR TO THE INCIDENT, THE RIGHT-OF-WAY WAS INSPECTED BY AGLC PERSONNEL AND THE GRASS WAS MOWED.  AT THE TIME OF THAT INSPECTION, NO UNUSAL CONDITIONS WERE NOTED.  CONVERSELY, IN THE POST-INCIDENT INSPECTION THE FOLLOWING FACTS WERE MOTED: 1. HEAVY MACHINERY USED IN CONSTRUCTION AND GRADING ACTIVITIES WAS FOUND PARKED IN THE RIGHT-OF-WAY.  2. A DIRT PATH HAD BEEN ESTABLISHED ROUGHLY PERPENDICULAR TO THE PIPE ACROSS THE RIGHT-OF-WAY.  TIRE TRACKS WERE NOTED, INDICATING THAT THE HEAVY MACHINERY HAD CROSSED THE PIPE AT THIS LOCATION.  3.  A DRAINAGE CULVERT HAD BEEN INSTALLED ROUGHLY PERPENDICULAR TO AND UNDER THE PIPE ACROSS THE RIGHT-OF-WAY.  VISUAL INSPECTION OF THE RUPTURED PIPE AND FRAGMENTS FOUND ON-SITE SHOWED A GOUGE IN THE PIPE.  THE RUPTURE OCCURRED AT THE CULVERT WHERE THE SOIL WAS SATURATED.  SUBSEQUENT LABORATORY ANALYSIS INDICATED THAT THE GOUGE CONTAINED FRAGMENTS OF FOREIGN METALS, INDICATING DAMAGE BY A METALLIC OBJECT-MOST LIKELY THE HEAVY CONSTRUCTION EQUIPMENT SEEN ON-SITE.  IT WAS DETERMINED THAT EMBRITTLEMENT DUE TO HYDROGEN STRESS CRACKING OCCURRED AT THE SITE OF THE GOUGE.  THIS CRACKING WAS ACCELERATED DUE TO THE HIGH MOISTURE CONTENT OF THE SURROUNDING SOIL, AND ULTIMATELY LED TO THE FAILURE OF THE PIPE."

PIPELINE SAFETY SPECIALIST"	4023987494	JOHN.GORMLEY@NNGCO.COM	4023987606	"AN ADDITIONAL ESD ACTIVATION STATION WAS INSTALLED AT THE GARNER LNG FACILITY SOMETIME DURING 2003.  THE POOR DESIGN ALLOWED MOISTURE TO ENTER THE CONDUIT AND EXPLOSION PROOF BOX THAT HOUSED THE ESD ACTIVATION SWITCH.  THE WIRES CORRODED AND WHEN THE BOX FILLED WITH ENOUGH WATER TO BECOME THE CONNECTION, THE ESD WAS ACTIVATED.  NO INJURIES OR PROPERTY DAMAGE RESULTED FROM THE STATION SHUTDOWN.  GARNER LNG WAS LIQUIFYING NATURAL GAS WHEN THE ESD ACTIVATED SO THERE WAS NO RELEASE OR SPILL. A SMALL AMOUNT OF NATURAL GAS IS VENTED DURING THE RE-START.  THE PLANT WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE LATER THE SAME DAY.  THIS IS BEING REPORTED BECAUSE OF COMPANY OPERATING PROCEDURE 180.109 THAT SAYS A REPORTABLE INCIDENT IS ONE WHICH RESULTS IN A UNPLANNED ESD OF A LNG FACILITY (3.1.2.).  IT IS ALSO REQUIRED BY 49 CFR 191.3 AND 191.5."

2003	31304	20040058		DEVON GAS SERVICES LP	415 PR 3502	BRIDGEPORT	WISE	TX	76426	1855	5/28/2003	NEW FAIRFAX (DECATUR) 	WISE	TX	76234	STATION B-117 COMPRESSOR 	NO. N/A	N 33  08.986	W 97 29.667	N	1				NO	NO	N	INTRASTATE	4	OTHER	"1/2"" NIPPLE BROKE"								0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	1378460	100	0	1378360	NO	YES	NO	NO	0				30	5/28/2003	646291	120		NO	NO	NO	NO	NO	N	2	GATHERING	5	OTHER	"1/2"" NIPPLE ON A COMPRESSOR STARTING SYSTEM"	1	STEEL		NO	NO	NO	3	COMPRESSOR		2002									3	ABOVE GROUND			5/28/2003	21	EQUIPMENT									NULL		NULL																	NULL						NULL			NULL			NULL																									NULL	NULL												1	NIPPLES												MARK GRINNELL - SUPERINTENDENT OF PIPELINE OPERATIONS	9406836055	MARK.GRINNELL@DVN.COM	9406836051	"THE INCIDENT WAS REPORTED INITIALLY BY TELEPHONE AT THAT TIME THE EXTENT OF DAMAGE WAS UNKNOWN.  DEVON DETERMINED ITS LOSS TO BE $100.00  IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THIS DOLLAR VALUE DID NOT TRIGGER THE LEVEL DICTATING A REPORT BE FILED FOR THE INCIDENT.  AFTER IDENTIFYING THE DAMAGE THAT OCCURRED TO THE COMPRESSION RENTAL COMPANY, (HANOVER COMPANY) WE REEVALUATED AND ARE NOW SUBMITTING A REPORT.  HANOVER PROVIDED THE ATTACHED REPORT MARKED ATTACHMENT 1 CONCERNING THEIR FIRE AT OUR B-117 STATION.    ATTACHMENT 1  1. It id believed that at some point between 10:45 and 18:55, a ?"" nipple supplying the pre/post lube system fractured. This nipple is located on the starting system supply manifold with 120 lb pressure of continuous natural gas flow (it is normal for start systems to have no safety shut-off protection).The nipple was downstream of a 1 1/2"" tee bushed down to a 1 1/2"" and connected to the pre/post lube regular.   2. There is no evidence of gas accumulation and any explosion. It is believed that the leaking gas ignited immediately with the failure of the ?"" nipple.  3. We believed this leaking nipple and ensuing fire created a torching effect to the area above this 1 1/2"" nipple thus potentially    torching the ignition system and /or any surrounding wiring and probably causing unit shutdown. (Note - Fire severely destroyed the unit's safety panel, so exact determination of what actually caused unit to shut down is unknown.)  4. We also believe the 1/2"" nipple completely separated at rapid rate. With full separation there was a stream of 1/2"" 120 psi gas supplying the fire.  5. There are signs of natural gas ""blowing against the coupling guard. (Unlit gas left the separated nipple at 120 psi and ignited after striking the coupling guard 18"" away. The fact that the coupling guard was not distorted and molten aluminum was everywhere but in that area leads us to this conclusion.)  6. This ricocheting flame created heat stress on two cast aluminum starter relay valves (SRV's) and other parts of the unit in the surrounding area.  7. Heat continued and the SRV's failed due to heat distortion thus allowing both 1 1/2"" starter supplies (120 psi) to fuel the fire.  8. At some point in this process, heat distorted the GSOV thus releasing another 1 1/2"" line at 45 psi to fuel the fire. (Note: This was the auto shut-off valve for fuel gas supply to the engine.)  9. Other gas leaks from process cylinder valve cap o-rings and packing probably occurred as the fire continued.  10. The fire continued to burn until discovered and was shut off with the inlet valve to the station by Jeff Murphy (Devon employee)."

PIPELINE SAFETY SPECIALIST"	2708524424	DAVID.SINCLAIR@SSCGP.COM	2708525012	"FROM THE STATION EVENT LOG, IT APPEARS THAT DUE TO A LIGHTNING STRIKE NEAR THE CONTROL BUILDING, THE ESD SOLENOID TRIPPED OUT INITIATING ESD.  NORMALLY THE ESD  SOLENOID IS HELD ENERGIZED BY BOTH THE FIRE AND GAS DETECTION SYSTEMS AS WELL AS SOME MANUAL PUSH BUTTONS.  ALL OF THESE THINGS HAVE INDIVIDUAL ANNUNCIATION ATTACHED TO THEM AND NOTHING WAS ANNUCIATED BY SCADA.  IT WOULD APPEAR THAT THE LIGHTNING GENERATED A CHANGE IN VOLTAGE ON THE ESD DC VOLTAGE SYSTEM CAUSING THE ESD TO TRIP. AT 2:00 AM, GAS CONTROL NOTIFIED ANDREW BUCHANON THAT THE STATION HAD ESDED.  WHEN THE OPERATORS ARRIVED AT THE STATION, THE BLOWOFFS WERE STILL BLOWING.  THE BLOWOFFS WERE CLOSED WHEN THE OPERATORS DETERMINED IT WAS SAFE TO CLOSE THEM.  THE REASON THE ESD BLOWOFFS WERE STILL BLOWING WAS BECAUSE GATE NUMBER 55 HAD FAILED TO CLOSE AS IT SHOULD HAVE DURING A NORMAL ESD.  IT WAS DETERMINED THE REASON VALVE 55 DID NOT CLOSE WAS A RUSTED ACTUATOR PISTON ON THE OPERATOR.  THE ACUTATOR WAS REPAIRED AND THE GATE RETURNED TO SERVICE."

HE INSERTED A NEW FLANGE GASKET BETWEEN THE COMPRESSOR CYLINDER AND THE FLANGE OF THE PULSATION BOTTLE.  THE GASKET USED WAS LISTED AS APPROVED IN THE COMPANY PROCEDURES FOR THAT PRESSURE AND APPLICATION.  THE CONTRACTOR TORQUED THE BOLTS ACCORDING TO THE TORQUE VALUE GIVEN TO HIM.  DURING THE INVESTIGATION, IT WAS FOUND THAT THE TORQUE VALUES GIVEN TO THE CONTRACTOR WERE TAKEN FROM THE INCORRECT TORQUE VALUE TABLE.  A CONTRIBUTING FACTOR WAS THAT THE ACTUAL PRESSURE RATING OF THE GASKET USED WAS LOWER THAN THE RANGE SPECIFIED IN THE COMPANY PROCEDURES.  PRIMARY CAUSE WAS DETERMINED TO BE THE INCORRECTLY TORQUED BOLTS WITH A CONTRIBUTING FACTOR OF INADEQUATE PRESSURE RATING FOR THE GASKET ALLOWED BY THE COMPANY PROCEDURES."

2004	13750	20040082		NORTHERN NATURAL GAS CO	1111 SOUTH 103RD STREET	OMAHA	DOUGLAS	NE	68124-1000	2345	9/6/2004	PERRYTOWN	OCHILTREE	TX	79070	65.906 TXM10302		36.3	-100.7997	N	1				NO	NO	Y	INTERSTATE	4	OTHER	COMPRESSOR PART FAILURE								0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	250000	175000	75000	0	NO	NO	YES	NO	0			3	15	9/7/2004	734270		860	YES	NO	NO	NO	NO	N	1	TRANSMISSION	5	OTHER	COMPRESSOR UNIT DISCHARGE VALVE CAP JACK BOLT	1	STEEL		NO	NO	NO	3	COMPRESSOR	 	1950									6	INSIDE/UNDER BUILDING			9/22/2004	15	MATERIAL AND/OR WELD FAILURES									NULL		NULL																	NULL						NULL			NULL			NULL						5	OTHER	COMPRESSOR VALVE JACK BOLT													2	MATERIAL DEFECT			NO	NO																									"JOHN A GORMLEY, SR PIPELINE SAFETY SPECIALIST"	4023987494	JOHN.GORMLEY@NNGCO.COM	4023987606	"AT 11:45 PM ON SEPTEMBER 6, 2004 NORTHERNS GAS CONTROL RECEIVED NOTIFICATION THAT THE NORTHRUP COMPRESSOR STATION  HAD EXPERIENCED AN ESD.  GAS CONTROL HAD ALSO RECEIVED ALARM SIGNALS FROM BOTH THE GAS AND FIRE DETECTION SYSTEMS.  AT 12:02 AM ON SEPTEMBER 7, 2004 NORTHERNS OPERATIONS COMMUNICATION CENTER (OCC) RECEIVED A CALL FROM THE OCHILTREE COUNTY, TX SHERIFF'S DEPARTMENT REPORTING AN EXPLOSION AND FIRE AT THE NORTHRUP COMPRESSOR STATION.  THE STATION WAS UNMANNED AT THE TIME AND NO INJURIES WERE REPORTED.  THE NORTHRUP COMPRESSOR STATION IS LOCATED 6 MILES SOUTH OF PERRYTOWN, TX ON US HIGHWAY 83.  THE STATION HAS TWO NATURAL GAS COMPRESSOR UNITS AND A STATION DEHYDRATION UNIT, AND COMPRESSES GAS RECEIVED FROM GATHERING FIELDS INTO THE TEXAS A-LINE (TXM10301) UPSTREAM OF THE BEAVER COMPRESSOR STATION.  THE STATION WAS FLOWING 27 MMCF/D AT THE TIME OF THE ESD.  THE CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT WAS A JACK BOLT ON THE OUTBOUND DISCHARGE VALVE CAP ON COMPRESSOR CYLINDER FOUR OF UNIT ONE CAME LOOSE AND ALLOWED GAS TO ESCAPE INTO THE ENGINE ROOM.  A JACK BOLT IS A VERY LONG BOLT THAT THREADS THROUGH THE CENTER OF THE COMPRESSOR VALVE CAP.  ITS PURPOSE IS TOE PUSH THE VALVE TO THE POINT THAT IT COMPRESSES THE GASKET WHEN THE VALVE IS INSTALLED, THUS FORMING A NECESSARY SEAL.  THE JACK BOLT PROTRUDES OUT OF THE AP COMPLETELY AND HAS A LOCK NUT THAT IS TIGHTENED AGAINST THE CAP.  GAS LEAKING FROM THE MISSING JACK BOLT WAS MOST LIKELY IGNITED BY DEBRIS EXITING THE LEAK AND STRIKING STRUCTURAL STEEL ADJACENT TO THE UNIT. THE RESULTING EXPLOSION CAUSED EXTENSIVE DAMAGE TO THE BUILDING SKIN, DOORS, WINDOWS AND LIGHTER SUPPORT PURLINS.  FIRE DAMAGE WAS LIMITED AND MINIMAL.  IN ORDER TO COME LOOSE THE JACK BOLT WOULD HAVE HAD TO LOSE PRELOAD.  PRELOAD COULD HAVE BEEN LOST DUE TO GASKET FAILURE, VALVE FAILURE, IMPROPER TORQUEING, OR IMPROPER VALVE ASSEMBLY.  AN AUGUST 25, 2004 COMPRESSOR ANALYSIS SHOWED NO INDICATION OF IMPROPER VALVE ASSEMBLY.  THERE ARE NO FINDINGS THAT PROVIDE AN ABSOLUTE DETERMINATION OF THE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE.  IT MAY HAVE BEEN A COMBINATION OF THE FACTORS ABOVE OR IT MAY HAVE BEEN A FACTOR NOT YET CONSIDERED."

NEWMAN	3043572869	MNEWMAN@NISOURCE.COM	3043573804	"BACKGROUND    AT APPROXIMATELY 11:05 PM ON SEPTEMBER 16, 2004 THE UNLOADER BOTTLE ON COMPRESSOR CYLINDER #5 OF UNIT #4, A CLARK TLA-10, AT LUCAS COMPRESSOR STATION FAILED CAUSING A STATION BLOW-DOWN, WHICH TRIGGERED THE ESD SYSTEM. DURING THE STATION BLOW-DOWN, FIRE GATES ON SL-3054 AND SL-3136 FAILED TO CLOSE RESULTING IN A GAS LOST OF 11,758 MCF. THE TOTAL COST FOR THIS INCIDENT WAS $69,907.     FAILURE ANALYSIS     COOK MANLEY CONDUCTED A FAILURE ANALYSIS ON THE UNLOADER BOTTLE (SEE ATTACHED REPORT) AND DETERMINED THAT THE ROOT CAUSE OF THIS FAILURE WAS A DATA ENTRY ERROR IN THE BOLT SIZING PROGRAM. COOK MANLEY ALSO INVESTIGATED ALL OTHER UNLOADER BOTTLES INSTALLED ON COMPRESSOR UNITS FOR THE LAST FIVE YEARS AND HAVE CONFIRMED THAT CALCULATIONS FOR ALL OTHER ASSEMBLIES ARE CORRECT.    COLUMBIA CONDUCTED A ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS FOR THE ESD FAILURE AND DETERMINED THAT THE 1"" COMPRESSED AIR ESD SUPPLY LINE HAD PLUGGED OFF DUE TO BLACK POWDER LIKE MATERIAL. THE SYSTEM WAS CLEANED AND THE ESD WAS RE-TESTED AND PERFORMED TO SATISFACTION.    REMEDIAL ACTION    COOK MANLEY WILL REPLACE THE AFFECTED ASSEMBLIES. COLUMBIA HAS REQUESTED THAT COOK MANLEY SUPPLY 0.750 INCH BOLTS WITH 16 THREADS PER INCH TO SECURE THE ACTUATOR TO THE VALVE CAP. THIS STUD SIZE IS IN EXCESS OF WHAT IS REQUIRED HOWEVER IT WILL SERVE TO FURTHER BOLSTER THE SAFETY FACTOR ON THIS UNIT.   COOK MANLEY WILL ALSO TAKE THE FOLLOWING CORRECTIVE ACTION TO FURTHER REDUCE THE CHANCES OF SUCH AN ERROR FROM HAPPENING AGAIN:    1) THE COMPUTER PROGRAM WILL BE REVISED TO INCLUDE A NOTE, REMINDING DESIGNERS OF THE IMPLICATIONS AND IMPORTANCE OF USING SUCTION PRESSURE INSTEAD OF AMBIENT PRESSURE.   2) A FUTURE REVISION TO THE PROGRAM WILL REQUIRE THE DESIGNER TO SELECT THE PROPER ASSEMBLY AND THEN PROMPT THE USER FOR THE CORRECT PRESSURE.   3) COOK MANLEY IS REVIEWING ALL OF THE CRITICAL CALCULATIONS IN OUR DESIGNS AND VERIFYING THE RESULTS AUTOMATED CALCULATIONS. THE PURPOSE IS TO IDENTIFY AREAS WHERE A DESIGN ERROR COULD RESULT IN THE RELEASE OF GAS. A LIST OF THESE CALCULATIONS/DECISIONS WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO AN ENGINEERING STANDARD. PROCEDURES WILL BE PUT INTO PLACE REQUIRING THE DRAWING ROOM CHECKER TO REVIEW AND INITIAL A COPY OF THE ENGINEERING STANDARD CERTIFYING THAT THE LIST OF CALCULATIONS WAS CRITICALLY REVIEWED."

THE TIME OF ACTUAL LEAK OCCURRENCE IS UNKNOWN. AT THE TIME OF DISCOVERY OF THE LEAK WAS CLASSIFIED AS A GRADE 2 REQUIRING SCHEDULED REPAIR ACTION.  A 20% REDUCTION OF PRESSURE ON THE PIPELINE PRIOR TO EXCAVATING THE LEAK WAS INITIATED ON 10-5-04 AND WAS ACHIEVED BY 10-8-04.  HOWEVER BECAUSE THE REDUCTION IN PRESSURE DID NOT SIGNIFICANTLY CHANGE IN THE LEAKAGE RATE THE DECISION WAS MADE TO REDUCE THE LINE PRESSURE TO ZERO TO PROVIDE EMPLOYEE SAFETY DURING THE EXCAVATION.  A COMPRESSOR WAS BROUGHT IN TO REDUCE THE AMOUNT OF GAS THAT WOULD BE RELEASED TO ATMOSPHERE TO REMOVE THE PIPELINE FROM SERVICE.  ON 10-12-04 AT 8:30 AM AN EVALUATION OF THE ESTIMATED COST OF REPAIR AND GAS LOST WAS DETERMINE THAT THE THRESHOLD OF $50,000 MIGHT BE MET AND THEREFORE A TELEPHONIC REPORT WAS MADE TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER AT 10:15 AM.  AT 11:30 AM 10-12-04 THE REDUCTION TO ZERO PRESSURE WAS INITIATED AND COMPLETED AT 6:14 AM ON 10-14-04.  THE TAP WAS EXCAVATED ON 10-14-04 AND THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE A CRACK IN A 2"" WELD NECK FLANGE.  IT APPEARS A SUMMER DRAUGHT MAY HAVE CAUSED SETTLING OF THE SOIL AROUND THE TAP VALVE ASSEMBLY THUS PUTTING UNDUE PRESSURE ON THE COMPONENT CAUSING IT TO CRACK.  THE CRACKED FLANGE WAS REMOVED AND A NEW ONE INSTALLED ON 10-14-04."

IN ORDER TO FIND THE LEAK, LEATECH WAS SPRAYED AROUND THE EDGES OF THE SPLIT SLEEVE.  SMALL BUBBLES SHOWED GAS WAS LEAKING FROM THE OUTER EDGED OF THE SLEEVE. THE REMAINING PIPELINE PRESSURE WAS THEN BLOWN TO ATMOSPHERE AT THE 200C50 VALVE SITE BLOWOFF VALVE - B-2 ON 11/10/2004.  THE 20 INCH HOT TAP AND 42-INCH PIPING IMMEDIATELY SURROUNDING THE HOT TAP WAS CUT OUT AND SENT AWAY FOR FURTHER ANALYSIS.  A NEW, HYDROSTATICALLY TESTED SECTION OF 42 INCH PIPELINE WAS PUT INTO PLACE AD NON-DESTRUCTIVELY TESTED AT THE WELDS.  THE 5-MILE SECTION OF 42 INCH PIPELINE WAS PURGED OF AIR, PACKED, AND PLACED INTO FULL SERVICE ON 11/12/2004.  MATERIALS TO PERFORM A NEW 20 INCH TAP ARRIVED ON SITE 11/15/04. A NEW 20 INCH X 42 INCH HOT TAP CONNECTION WITH SUPPORT SADDLE WAS INSTALLED, AND THE HOT TAP NIPPLE WAS NON-DESTRUCTIVELY TESTED.  A 20 INCH HOT TAP WAS PERFORMED ON THE NEW SECTION OF 42 INCH TRUCK PIPING, AND THE 20 INCH PIPELINE WAS RECONNECTED AT FLANGES.  THE LATERAL PIPING WAS PURGED OF AIR, AND THE METER STATION RETURNED TO FULL SERVICE ON 11/17/04."

THE WELD OPENED FROM ABOUT THE 9:00 O'CLOCK POSITION ACROSS THE TOP TO THE 3:00 O'CLOCK POSITION. NORTHERN CONDUCTED METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS OF SOME UNDAMAGED WELDS, SMART PIGGED THE ENTIRE VALVE SECTION AND HYDROSTATICALLY TESTED THE ENTIRE VALVE SECTION PRIOR TO RETURNING THE PIPELINE TO SERVICE. THE COMPANY ALSO REINFORCED WELDS NEAR US HIGHWAY 24.   OPS WAS UPDATED THROUGHOUT THE ENTIRE PROCESS."

PIPE SENT TO METALLURGICAL LABORATORY NOVEMBER 30, 2004 AND FINAL REPORT IS EXPECTED TO BE DELIVERED THE WEEK OF DECEMBER 21, 2004.  TIME OF INCIDENT IS THE TIME THAT GULF SOUTH RECEIVED FIRST INDICATION, A ROD LOAD ALARM ON LONGVIEW COMPRESSOR STATION #2 UNITS 2 AND 3 WHICH WERE RUNNING AT THE TIME.  OPERATOR WAS WORKING ON UNIT 1 AND WAS ATTEMPTING TO PUT INTO SERVICE WHEN ALARM ACTIVATED.  OPERATOR OBSERVED THAT SUCTION PRESSURE ON INDEX 8 AT 240 PSIG AT APPROXIMATELY 9:35 PM AND NOTIFIED GAS CONTROL.  GAS CONTROLLER DISPATCHED FIRST RESPONDERS AT 9:40 PM.  THE LOW ALARM ON THE SCADA, SET AT 170 PSIG ACTIVATED AT 9:45PM.  A REVIEW OF THE PRESSURE DATA INDICATES THAT THE ACTUAL RUPTURE PROBABLY OCCURRED BETWEEN 8:53PM AND 8:58PM.  THE ELAPSED TIME UNTIL AREA WAS MADE SAFE IS BASED ON THE TIME THAT THE PRODUCTION THAT FEEDS INTO THE LINE WAS SHUT IN AND ALL ISOLATING VALVES WERE CLOSED.  THE NEAREST DWELLING WAS APPROXIMATELY 2,000 FEET FROM THE RUPTURE SITE.  THEREFORE, THE AREA WAS ACTUALLY SAFE ONCE THE SITE HAD BEEN SECURED UPON ARRIVAL BY THE FIRST RESPONDERS. 1-24-05 METALURGICAL ANALYSIS OF THE FAILED SECTION OF PIPE DETERMINED THAT THE RUPTURE WAS CAUSED BY PITTING CORROSION ON THE INSIDE OF THE PIPE ALONG THE BOTTOM OF THE PIPELINE, WHERE THE SEAM WELD WAS LOCATED.  THE APPEARANCE OF THE CORROSION INDICATED IT WAS MOST LIKELY DUE TO MICROBIOLOGICALLY INDUCED CORROSION (MIC) AND THERE WAS NO INDICATION THAT THE FAILURE INITIATED IN THE WELD, BUT THE PROPERTIES OF THE WELD PROBABLY ACCOUNT FOR FRACTURE PROPAGATION BEYOND THE PITTED AREA."

BURNLEY	6077210112	SBURNLEY@NISOURCE.COM	6077731510	"A CRACK FORMED BETWEEN THE BALL VALVES BODY AND ONE OF ITS FLANGES.  THE CRACK WAS APPROXIMATELY 12 INCHES LONG AS MEASURED CIRCUMFERENTIALLY.  THE FAILED VALVE IS BEING SENT TO AN INDEPENDENT LAB FOR CRACK MORPHOLOGY AND ANALYSIS.  BECAUSE THE PIPELINE WAS A SOLE MARKET FEED, THE VALVE COULD NOT BE READILY ISOLATED.  THIS RESULTED IN BLOWING GAS BEING MANAGED WHILE A STOPPLED BYPASS COULD BE FABRICATED, THUS RESULTING IN COSTS EXCEEDING $50K.    SYNOPSIS OF MARCH 21, 2005, EDISON WELDING INSTITUTE REPORT EWI PROJECT NO. 48804CSP:  THE LIKELY CAUSE OF FAILURE WAS CRACK INITIATION FROM A VOID TYPE CASTING DEFECT.  STRESS IMPARTED FROM THE CONNECTED PIPING CONTRIBUTED TO SUBSEQUENT CRACK GROWTH.  THE CRACK PROPAGATED FROM THE OUTSIDE SURFACE OF THE BALL VALVE AS EVIDENT BY THE INCREASED CORROSION PRODUCTS FOUND ACROSS THE FRACTURE SURFACE.  MICROSTRUCTURE LIKELY PLAYED A ROLE IN THE CRACK PROPAGATION TOO.  THE PRESENCE OF GRAPHITE FLAKES WITHIN THE MATRIX IS INDICATIVE OF A WEAKER MICROSTRUCTURE.  SEM EXAMINATION OF THE FRACTURE SURFACE INDICATED BRITTLE-LIKE PROPAGATION OF THE CRACK.  THE CHEMICAL ANALYSIS CONFIRMS THAT THE MATERIAL IS A CAST IRON, WITH A CARBON COMPOSITION OF 3 PERCENT."

THE PIPE REPLACEMENT REPAIR METHOD CAUSED THE REPAIR COST TO EXCEED THE REPORTING THRESHOLD. THEREFORE, THE INCIDENT WAS REPORTED TO THE NRC AT 11:15 HOURS."

2004	19270	20050015		TEXAS GAS TRANSMISSION LLC	3800 FREDERICA STREET	OWENSBORO	DAVIESS	KY	42301	1000	12/25/2004		TERREBONNE	LA		6.8087(MP) TEXAS GAS VALV	NA	29-12'-188 N	90- 52'-217 W	N	1				NO	NO	Y	INTERSTATE	2	RUPTURE					1	CIRCUMFERENTIAL-SEPARATION			0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	984000	28000	956000	0	NO	YES	NO	NO	0			2	0	12/25/2004	745282	936	1440	YES	NO	NO	NO	NO	N	1	TRANSMISSION	1	BODY OF PIPE		1	STEEL		NO	NO	NO	1	PIPELINE		1963	8	0.38	API 5LX	42000	SEAMLESS WELD	NA	YOUNGSTOWN SHEET AND TUBE COMPANY	1963	3	ABOVE GROUND			2/1/2005	10	OTHER OUTSIDE FORCE DAMAGE									NULL		NULL																	NULL						NULL			NULL			NULL	2	NATURAL																							NULL	NULL																									"BRETT K KIGHT, SENIOR ENGINEER, PIPELINE SAFETY & INTEGRITY"	2706886372	BRETT.K.KIGHT@TXGT.COM	2706886327	"ON THE EVENING OF DECEMBER 24, 2004 AT 10:30 PM (CST) TEXAS GAS' GAS CONTROL DEPT RECEIVED NOTIFICATION FROM A GAUGER.  MR. GENE GILES [PHONE NO (985)232-9830], WITH HILCORP ENGINEERING THAT OUR TEXACO-DOG LAKE (METER NO 9836) FACILITIES WERE ON FIRE.  THIS METER FACILITY IS ON A SMALL CONCRETE PLATFORM IN THE LOUISIANA MARSH.  HILCORP ENGINEERING OPERATES PRODUCTION IN THE DOG LAKE AREA.  TEXAS GAS WAS RECEIVING APPROXIMATELY 17 MMCF/D RATE AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT.      THE INCIDENT WAS REPORTED TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER BY 12:30 A.M. (CST) DECEMBER 25TH.  AFTER THE INITIAL CALL FROM MR. GILES, GAS CONTROL IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED THE YOUNGSVILLE-MORGAN CITY DISTRICT ONE-CALL PERSON WHO MOBILIZED WITH THREE EMPLOYEES FROM THE MORGAN CITY DISTRICT WHO ARRIVED BY CONTRACTED CREW BOAT AT THE AREA OF THE PLATFORM BY 1:30 A.M. AND FOUND THAT OUR PLATFORM WAS NOT ON FIRE, BUT PIPING 10- TO 15- FEET FROM THE PLATFORM WAS.  THEY PROCEEDED TO ISOLATE THE TEXAS GAS PIPING DOWNSTREAM OF THE AFFECTED FACILITIES.  HILCORP THEN SHUT IN THEIR PRODUCTION AND THERE WERE NO ACTIVE METERS UPSTREAM.  SINCE TRANSCO HAS AN ""INACTIVE"" RISER AND SIDE VALVE INTERCONNECT (NO 8122) ON THE PLATFORM, WE NOTIFIED THEIR GAS CONTROL DEPT PROMPTLY.      AFTER OUR PIPELINE WAS ISOLATED, THE FIRE CONTINUED AT THE SAME RATE.  OUR EMPLOYEES REPORTED THAT THE FIRE APPEARED TO BE ORIGINATING FROM THE TRANSCO PIPELINE AREA.  WE REPORTED THIS TO TRANSCO WHO THEN BEGAN MOBILIZING THEIR EMPLOYEES WHO ARRIVED ONSITE THE MORNING OF DECEMBER 25.  THEY ISOLATED BOTH THEIR 6-INCH GAS PIPELINE AND A 3-INCH LIQUIDS PIPELINE WITH NO IMPACT TO THE FLAME.      AT APPROXIMATELY 10:00 A.M.  DECEMBER 25, AS REPORTED TO US BY A HILCORP ENGINEERING REPRESENTATIVE, THE FLAME GREATLY INTENSIFIED.  TEXAS GAS BELIEVES THAT THIS GREATLY INTENSIFIED FLAME INDICATES THE RUPTURE OF OUR CBD 8"" PIPELINE IN THE RISER LEAVING THE PLATFORM, DUE TO THE HEAT FROM THE FIRE.  AT ABOUT THIS TIME, 10:00 A.M. DECEMBER 25, 2004, HILCORP ENGINEERING BEGAN MANUALLY SHUTTING-IN THEIR PRODUCTION LINES.  THE FIRE DIMINISHED AND SUBSIDED OVER THE NEXT 2 TO 3 HOURS.  WE HAD NO EMPLOYEES AT THE SITE WHEN THIS EVENT OCCURRED AS WE WERE IN THE PROCESS OF CHANGING CREWS AND REFUELING THE BOAT.  THIS INFORMATIONS WAS RELAYED FROM THE HILCORP CREW BOAT THAT WAS ALSO MONITORING THE SITUATION.      TEXAS GAS BELIEVES THAT THE INITIAL FIRE WAS CAUSED BY THE FAILURE AND IGNITION OF A PRODUCTION LINE OWNED BY HILCORP ENGINEERING.  THE HEAT FORM THIS INITIAL FIRE CAUSED TEXAS GAS' CBD 8"" PIPELINE TO RUPTURE.    HILCORP REIMBURSED TEXAS GAS FOR THE MAJORITY OF THE LOSS.  TEXAS GAS REPAIRED THE FACILITY ON PROJECT 46867."

AFTER COMPLETING THE WORK AT THE END OF THE LINE, THE EMPLOYEES RETURNED TO THE GATE VALVE LOCATION AND WERE IN THE PROCESS OF REMOVING THE CLAPPER FROM A CHECK VALVE THAT WAS LOCATED FIVE FEET DOWN STREAM OF THE GATE VALVE. AN EMPLOYEE HAD LOOSENED SIX OF THE EIGHT BOLTS AND REMOVED TWO OF THE BOLTS.  AS THE EMPLOYEES LOOSEN THE REMAINING TWO TIGHTEN BOLTS PRESSURE IN THE LINE BLOWOUT THE O-RING BLOWING DIRT INTO TWO OF THE EMPLOYEES EYES. COMPANY EMPLOYEES RESPONDED TO MAKE THE LOCATION SAFE WITHIN 45 MINUTES.  TWO EMPLOYEES WITH THE DIRT THEIR EYES WERE TAKEN TO A HOSPITAL TO HAVE THEIR EYES CHECKED AND IRRIGATED.  THEY WERE BOTH RELEASED WITHOUT INJURIES.  THE GATE VALVE AND CHECK VALVE WERE REMOVED AND REPLACE WITH A BALL VALVE.  THE OLD GATE VALVE WAS FOUND TO BE DEFECTIVE, HAVING RUST GALLING AT THE BOTTOM OF THE STEM THREADS THAT HAD PREVENTED IT COMPLETE CLOSURE AND ALLOW LINE PRESSURE TO BE PRESENT AT THE CHECK VALVE WHILE THE EMPLOYEES WERE TRYING TO REMOVE THE CLAPPER."

AT THAT TIME A LEAK WAS DETECTED.  ONCE CONFIRMED THE OPERATOR CALLED THE DISTRICT MANAGER TO LOCATION FOR VERIFICATION.  UPON VERIFICATION THE DISTRICT MANAGER CALLED GAS CONTROL AND OTHER COMPANY OFFICIALS OF THE SITUATION.  AT THAT POINT IN TIME THE SSCGP OPERATOR'S CONTINUED THEIR INVESTIGATION AND DISCOVERED THAT THE LEAK AREA WAS CONFINED TO THE CASING UNDER THE ROAD CROSSING AND NO FARTHER AWAY THAN FIVE FEET FROM THE NORTH END OF THE CASING. CENTRAL REGION OPS WAS ADVISED BECAUSE HIGHWAY 400 WAS INVOLVED AND THEY ADVISED MONITORING THE LEAK AS A PRECAUTION.  TEST HOLES WERE ESTABLISHED AND WERE CHECKED THREE TIMES PER DAY AS ADVISED BY THE OPS.  ON JANUARY 25TH THE DAY WAS SPENT FILLING OUT PAPERWORK AND CALLING IN ONE CALLS TO ESTABLISH WHERE THE OTHER UTILITIES WERE IN THE AREA.  ALSO, ON THIS DAY, UNDER THE ADVISE OF THE OPS, WE WERE ASKED TO LOWER THE LINE PRESSURE FROM 253# TO 200#.   THIS FUNCTION WAS PERFORMED.  ON JANUARY 26TH SSCGP EMPLOYEES SHOWED UP ON SITE TO PERFORM EXCAVATION TO SEE IF THE LEAK COULD BE FOUND.  UPON EXCAVATION A LEAK WAS FOUND OUTSIDE OF THE END OF THE CASING ON THE NORTH SIDE OF THE HIGHWAY.  SSCGP EMPLOYEES INSTALLED A MECHANICAL SPLIT REPAIR SLEEVE AND STOPPED THE LEAK.  AT THE TIME THE LEAK WAS THOUGHT TO BE CONTAINED AND SSCGP EMPLOYEES WOULD COME BACK WHEN WEATHER PERMITTED AND REPLACE THE PIPE.  UPON COMPLETION OF BACKFILLING OF THE LEAK AREA THE DISTRICT MANAGER ASKED THE OPERATOR TO CHECK THE CASING VENT ONCE AGAIN FOR LEAKAGE.  AT THE TIME IT WAS THOUGHT THAT MAYBE THE SATURATED SOIL WAS STILL SETTING OFF THE LEAK DETECTOR.  THE DISTRICT MANAGER ADVISED THE OPERATOR TO RELEASE NITROGEN IN THE VENT MARKER IN HOPES THAT THIS WOULD NEUTRALIZE THE SOIL OR CONTENTS OF THE CASING THAT MIGHT BE SATURATED WITH NATURAL GAS. THE OPERATORS DID SO AND WAITED APPROXIMATELY 20 MINUTES.  USING THE PRAGMATICS THE CASING VENT WAS CHECKED ONCE AGAIN. GAS LEAKAGE WAS DETECTED.  LINE PRESSURE WAS LEFT AT 200# AND MONITORING FOR LEAKAGE WAS CONTINUED.  ON JANUARY 25TH SSCGP EMPLOYEES MET WITH CONTRACT EMPLOYEES AND IMMEDIATELY STARTED THE PROCESS FOR THE REPLACEMENT OF THE 400/77 HIGHWAY CROSSING.  WORKED CONTINUED THROUGH FEBRUARY 1ST UPON COMPLETION OF REPLACEMENT OF PIPE.  FOR THE DURATION OF THIS PROJECT SSCGP EMPLOYEES MONITORED THE LEAK AS REQUESTED BY THE OPS.  THE OPERATING PRESSURE OF 253# WAS RE-ESTABLISHED ON LINE AK FEBRUARY 2ND."

THE WORTHINGTON BRANCH LINE HAD BEEN BLOWN DOWN UPSTREAM OF THIS VALVE TO A STOPPLE FITTING DOWNSTREAM DURING THE CONSTRUCTION PROJECT.  THE PIPELINE WAS BEING PURGED ON THE DAY OF THE INCIDENT FROM THE TAKE-OFF VALVE TO THIS BLOCK VALVE.  THEN THE PIPELINE WAS PURGED FROM THIS BLOCK VALVE TO THE STOPPLE FITTING DOWNSTREAM.  DURING THE PURGING PROCESS THE NORTHERN EMPLOYEE APPROACHED THE VALVE FROM TWO DIFFERENT DIRECTIONS.  THE VALVE HAD NOT BEEN COMPLETELY BACKFILLED SO THE VALVE OPERATOR AND INDICATOR WAS OVER HIS HEAD.  WHEN THE PIPELINE PURGING WAS COMPLETED THE NORTHERN EMPLOYEE INADVERTENTLY CLOSED THE BLOCK VALVE AYA06 THINKING THAT HE WAS OPENING IT AND LEFT FOR THE DAY.  LATER THAT SAME EVENING AQUILA (THE LOCAL DISTRIBUTION COMPANY) CONTACTED NORTHERN TO REPORT A LOSS OF GAS SERVICE TO THE TOWN OF JACKSON, MN.  APPROXIMATELY 1500 CUSTOMERS WERE WITHOUT NATURAL GAS.  NORTHERN OPENED THE BLOCK VALVE AYA06 AND PURGED THE 4.5 MILES OF WORTHINGTON 6"" BRANCH LINE AND 1600' OF JACKSON (MNB87201) BRANCH LINE.  AQUILA BEGAN RE-LIGHTING CUSTOMERS THE MORNING OF APRIL 7.  THERE WAS NO NATURAL GAS LEAK AND NO KNOWN THREAT TO PUBLIC SAFETY.  JACKSON HAD FAIR SKIES WITH A HIGH TEMPERATURE ON APRIL 6 OF 54F AND A LOW OF 39F."

2005	2616	20050043		COLUMBIA GAS TRANSMISSION 	1700 MACCORKLE AVE SE	CHARLESTON	   KANAWHA	WV	25325	530	4/4/2005	SENECA ROCKS	PENDLETON	WV	26884	SENECA COMPRESSOR STATION				N	1				NO	NO	Y	INTERSTATE	3	N/A									0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	493200	493200	0	0	NO	NO	NO	NO	0			2	15	4/4/2005	754698	700	1000	NO	NO	YES	NO	NO	N	1	TRANSMISSION							NO	NO	NO	3	COMPRESSOR		1953									7	OTHER	COMPRESSOR STATION		4/29/2005	20	EQUIPMENT									NULL		NULL																	NULL						NULL			NULL			NULL																									NULL	NULL									4	OTHER	COMPRESSOR ESD SYSTEM														MARY S. FRIEND	3043572475	MFRIEND@NISOURCE.COM	3043573804	"COMPRESSOR STATION WAS NOT MANNED DURING THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT.  THE STATION ESD SYSTEM IS A PRESSURIZED SYSTEM USING BOTH COMPRESSED GAS AND PIPELINE PRESSURE TO DRIVE THE VALVE ACTUATORS.  DURING HIGH WINDS, THE STATION LOST ONE PHASE OF COMMERCIAL ELECTRICAL POWER.  DURING THE LOSS OF POWER, THERE WAS A SLOW LEAK ON THE COMPRESSED AIR SYSTEM.  WHEN THE AIR PRESSURE FELL BELOW 75 PSI, THE ESD VENT VALVES POWERED BY PIPELINE GAS ACTIVATED.  THERE WAS NOT ENOUGH REMAINING PRESSURE TO CLOSE THE FIRE VALVES.  ALL THE FIRE VALVES WERE MANUALLY CLOSED APPROXIMATELY 2 HOURS AFTER THE ESD SYSTEM ACTIVATED."

THIS LEAD TO CATASTROPHIC FAILURE OF THE REACTION TURBINE.			MARY S. FRIEND	3043572475	MFRIEND@NISOURCE.COM	3043573804	"UNIT HAD GONE DOWN ON ALARM.  COMPANY RESPONDER CLEARNED ALARMS, AND STARTED UNIT.  UNIT WENT THROUGH WARM UP, AND WENT ON LINE TO MAINTAIN LINE PRESSURE.  COMPANY PERSON PLACED UNIT IN AUTOMATIC START MODE, AND WAS LEAVING BUILDING WHEN THE UNIT POWER TURBINE FAILED.  TURBINE FAILURE RESULTED IN DAMAGE TO UNIT AND ADJOINING UNIT.  FAILED UNIT CAUGHT FIRE.  COMPANY PERSON HIT ESD FOR APPROPRIATE ENGINE BLOCKS.       INVESTIGATION REVEALED A SEGMENT OF THE FIRST STAGE REACTION TURBINE DISK BROKE AWAY CAUSING THE ROTOR TO BECOME SEVERALLY OUT OF BALANCE.  THIS SITUATION RESULTED IN THE COMPLETE CATASTROPHIC FAILURE OF THE REACTION TURBINE.      THE INITIAL CAUSE OF THE ROTOR DISK FAILURE WAS SHOWN TO BE DUE TO A LOW CYCLE FATIGUE CRACK RESULTING OVER SEVERAL CYCLES.  THIS CRACK WAS INITIATED BY THE FAILURE OF ONE OF THE LOWER SEAL RING SEGMENTS, WHICH CAME UNFASTENED AND RUBBED AGAINST THE ROTOR DISK.  THE ROOT CAUSE OF THIS FAILURE HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE THE RELEASE OF ONE OF THE LOWER SEAL RING SEGMENTS FROM ITS FASTENERS.  NO DEFINITIVE REASON CAN BE DETERMINED FOR THE RELEASE OF THESE FASTENERS."

THE PIPELINE IS 20"" IN DIAMETER AT THE SITE OF THE FAILURE AND REDUCES TO 16"" APPROXIMATELY 400' ON THE FIELD SIDE OF THE FAILURE.  ONCE NOTIFIED OF THE PIPELINE FAILURE OPERATIONS PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO CLOSE ISOLATION VALVES ON BOTH ENDS OF THE 20"" PIPELINE SECTION AS WELL AS VALVES ON THREE BRANCH LINES THAT TIE IN TO TL-414 WITHIN THE DAMAGED SECTION OF PIPELINE. THE FINAL VALVE REQUIRED TO TOTALY ISOLATE THE SEGMENT OF DAMAGED LINE WAS CLOSED AT 5:57 PM.  AS A RESULT OF THE FAILURE A SIGNIFICANT HOLE WAS BLOWN IN THE GROUND SURROUNDING THE PIPLINE ENDS BY THE ESCAPING GAS.  A SEGMENT OF PIPE APPROXIMATELY 4 TO 5 FEET IN LEGTH WAS FOUND AFTER THE FAILURE ABOUT 234 FEET FROM THE LINE IN A WOODED AND BRUSHY AREA ADJACENT TO THE RIGHT OF WAY. THE FAILURE OCCURRED IN AN AREA THAT HAS BEEN PRONE TO GROUND MOVEMENT (SLIPS) FOR SEVERAL YEARS.  SEVERAL ATTEMPTS HAVE BEEN MADE TO REPAIR SLIPS IN THE AREA WITH SOME LIMITED SUCCESS, HOWEVER WHEN THE MOST RECENT SLIP WAS IDENTIFIED IN LATE 2004 PLANS WERE MADE TO RELOCATE LINE TL-414 TO ANOTHER LOCATION IN AN ATTEMPT TO ELIMINATE THE RECURRING PROBLEM.  WORK WAS SCHEDULED TO START ON THE RELOCATION PROJECT IN AUGUST 22, 2005."
