JEFF KOSKIE	2132443283	WKOSKIE@SEMPRAUTILITIES.COM	2132448155	"NEWBERRY STATION  IVESTIGATION REPORT  DOT/CPUC REPORTABLE 7/13/2005    SEQUENCE OF EVENTS    AT APPROXIMATELY 6:00 PM, GAS CONTROL REPORTED THAT STARTING AIR PRESSURE AT NEWBERRY STATION WAS LOW, SETTING INTO MOTION RESPONSE AND INVESTIGATION.    THE AIR DRYER WAS ISOLATED AND AIR PRESSURE BUILT BACK UP, AND THE GAS VENT VALVES CLOSED.  THE AIR SYSTEMS PRESSURE DROPPED DUE TO THE AIR LINE HOSE FAILURE, BUT THE AIR COMPRESSURE CONTINEUED TO SUPPLY AIR, ULTIMATELY HOLDING A PRESSURE OF 35# IN TEH AIR SYTEM.  ONCE THE AIR DRYER WAS ISOLATED, AIR PRESSURE BUILT BACK UP AND THE GAS VENT VALVES CLOSED.    MAINTAINING THE 35# EQUILIBRIUM RESULTED IN A PRESSURE LOW ENOUGH TO TRIP THE GAS VENTING VALVES (65# DESIGNED SET  POINT) TO ATMPOSPHERE BUT NOT LOWE ENOUGH TO CLOSE THE BLOCK VALVLES (30# DESIGNED SET POINT) WHICH WOULD HAVE ISOLATED TRANSMISSION LINES 235 AND 3000 FROM THE STATION.    UPON DISCOVERY OF THE HOSE FAILURE, THE AIR DRYER WAS BYPASSED AND REMOVED FROM SERVICE.  STATION PERSONNEL REMAINED AT THE STATION THROUGH THE NIGHT OT MONITOR OPERATIONS.    THE STATION WAS PLACED BACK ONLINE AT APPROXIMATELY 8:45 PM.    DUE TO QUICK ACTION BY GAS OPERATIONS TO MAINTAIN THE GAS SYSTEM AND BY PUTTING STORAGE ON WITHDRAWAL, THERE WAS NO LOSS OF SERVICE OR CUSTOMER IMPACT.    NOTE:  THE VENTING OF GAS TO ATMOSPHERE WAS NOT THE RESULT OF ANY MALFUCTION OF THE ESD SYSTEM NOR A TRIGGER OF THE ESD SYSTEM.  DURING THIS INCIDENT, THE ESD SYSTEM COULD HAVE BEEN ACTUATED BY A NUMBER OF SAFETY-TRIGGERED CONDITIONS, AND THIS WOULD HAVE RESULTED IN A COMPLETE ISOLATION AND BLOW-DOWN OF THE STATION.    IMMEDIATE MITIGATION EFFORTS    UNTIL COMPLETEION OF COMPREHENSIVE ENGINEERING ANALYSIS, THE AIR DRYER WILL REMAIN OUT OF SERVICE.    A NITROGEN SUPPLY SYSTEM TO PROVIDE BACK-UP PRESSURE TO THE ESD SYSTEM NOT INSTALLED ON FRIDAY JULY 15, 2005.  THE SYTEM IS SET TO PROVIDE CONSTANT 80# OF NITROGEN FEED TO THE ESD SYSTEM, SHOULD THE EXISTING SYSTEM PRESSURE DROP BELOW 80#.  THE NITROGEN FEED IS SUPPLIED THROUGH A CHECK VALVE AND ORIFICE SO AS TO NOT IMPACT OR AFFECT NORMAL OPERATION OF THE ESD SYSTEM, IF ACTUATED.    ON GOING ENGINEERING REVIEW OF CURRENT AIR SYSTEMS AT NEW BETTER STATION (STARTING AIR, UTILITY AIR, AND INSTRUMENT AIR), AND WILL IMPLEMENT ANY MODIFICATIONS IDENTIFIED FROM ENGINEERING REVIEW DEEMED NECESSARY.    PLEASE CONTACT JEFF KOSKIE AT (213) 244-3283 IF YOU HAVE ANY QUESTIONS OR NEED ADDITIONAL INFORMATION."

A TEE STRAINER WAS INSTALLED UPSTREAM OF THE METER TO PREVENT REOCCURRANCE."

DIDIA	3132356921	DIDIAJ@DTEENERGY.COM	3133258500	"ON SEPTEMBER 27, 2005, MICHCON RECEIVED A NOTICE THROUGH THE MICHIGAN ONE-CALL CENTER (MISS DIG SYSTEMS, INC.) OF EXCAVATION OPERATIONS TO BE CONDUCTED BY DEWITT TRENCHING CONTRACTORS, INC. (DEWITT) ON THE SOUTHEAST, SOUTHWEST, AND NORTHWEST CORNERS OF THE INTERSECTION OF 44TH STREET S.E. AND ROGER B CHAFFEE BOULEVARD IN THE CITY OF WYOMING, MICHIGAN.  IN RESPONSE TO THIS NOTICE, A MICHCON REPRESENTATIVE VISITED THE SITE ON SEPTEMBER 29, 2005, AND PROVIDED TEMPORARY MARKINGS CONSISTING OF FLAGS AND PAINT IN THE AREA REQUESTED.  MICHCON'S REPRESENTATIVE CONTACTED DEWITT'S REPRESENTATIVE AT THE SITE AND DISCUSSED THE LIMITS OF THE WORK AND THE METHODS TO BE USED.  DEWITT'S REPRESENTATIVE WAS VERBALLY MADE AWARE OF THE PRESENCE OF A 22"" 300 PSI PIPELINE UNDER THE WESTBOUND LANES OF 44TH STREET, BUT BECAUSE OF HEAVY VEHICLE TRAFFIC IN THE AREA PAINT MARKS WOULD BE HAZARDOUS TO MAKE AND WOULD NOT LAST FROM VEHICLE WEAR.  DEWITT'S REPRESENTATIVE STATED TO MICHCON'S REPRESENTATIVE THAT HE WOULD NOT NEED STAKING ON TEH NORTHWEST CORNER BECAUSE PLASTIC CONDUITS HAD ALREADY BEEN RUN UNDERNEATH THE NEW ROADWAY ON THE NORTH SIDE AND THAT THE BORING WORK WOULD NOT EXTEND TO THE NORTHWEST CORNER, SO MARKINGS FOR THE 22"" PIPELINE WERE NOT NECESSARY.    ON OCTOBER 4, 2004 AT APPROXIMATELY 10:50 AM MICHCON RECEIVED A REPORT THAT A PIPLINE HAD BEEN STRUCK BY AN EXCAVATOR AT THE CORNER OF 44TH STREET SE AND ROGER B CHAFFEE BOULEVARD.  RESPONDING TO THAT REPORT, MICHCON ARRIVED AT THE SITE AT 11:03 AM AND FOUND THAT THE 22"" 300 PSI PIPELINE HAD BEEN STRUCK BY A BORING MACHINE OPERATED BY DEWITT.  THE 2-INCH BORING HEAD HAD PUNCTURED THE 22"" PIPE AT A DEPTH OF APPROXIMATELY 41 INCHES FROM STREET GRADE; THE TOP OF THE 22"" PIPE WAS FOUND AT 36 INCHES BELOW STREET GRADE.  DEWITT'S REPRESENTATIVE STATED TO MICHCON THAT HE KNEW THE PIPELINE WAS THERE BUT THAT HE DECIDED TO BORE IN THE AREA OF THE 22"" PIPELINE ANYWAY, AND THAT HE THOUGH THE 22"" PIPELINE SHOULD HAVE BEEN DEEPER AT THAT LOCATION.    NOTE: ALTHOUGH MISS DIGS WAS NOTIFIED AND RESPONDED AND RESPONDED TO THE AREA, THERE WERE NO MISS DIGS MARKS AT THE LOCATION OF THE DAMAGE.  I QUESTIONED THE CONTRACTOR AS TO WHY HE DIDN'T CALL FOR ADDITIONAL STAKING AND HE REPLIED, ""I KNEW THE MAIN WAS THERE."""

CAVITT	3184293606	JOHNNY.CAVITT@CENTERPOINTENERGY.COM	3184293927	"AT 3:30 AM, DECEMBER 13, 2005 SYSTEM CONTROL NOTICES A LOSS OF PRESSURE ON MRT SYSTEM AT BIGGERS COMPRESSOR STATION.  SYSTEM CONTROL NOTIFIES FIELD PERSONNEL TO INVESTIGATE. THE FIELD PERSONNEL ARRIVED AT THE STATION AT 3:40 AM AND FOUND THE 6 STATION ESD SUCTION BLOW DOWN OPEN AND VENTING.  A SURVEY OF THE STATION YARD VALVES DISCOVERED ML2 STATION SUCTION VALVE AND DISCHARGE VALVE CLOSED, ML3 STATION SUCTION AND DISCHARGE VALVE OPEN, AND THE ESD STATION DISCHARGE BLOW DOWN VALVE CLOSED.  THE ML3 STATION DISCHARGE VALVE WAS CLOSED AT 4:18 AM, THEN THE ML3 STATION SUCTION VALVE WAS CLOSED AT 4:19 AM.  THIS ISOLATED THE STATION FROM THE MAIN LINES, WHICH WOULD ALLOW THE STATION PIPING TO BLOW DOWN.  INVESTIGATION SHOWED THAT A NICKED O RING WAS FOUND IN THE SENSOR ON ML2 DISCHARGE OPERATOR, AND THE NEEDLE VALVE ORIFICES WERE OUT OF ADJUSTMENT ON ML3 STATION SUCTION VALVE AND ML3 STATION DISCHARGE VALVE.  REPLACEMENT OF THE O-RING  AND A NEEDLE VALVE ADJUSTMENT OF THE ML3 VALVES OPERATOR WAS PERFORMED, AND UPON SUBSEQUENT ESD TEST, THE VALVES OPERATED PROPERLY.  ESTIMATED LOSS OF GAS WAS 15,950 MCF."

GORMLEY	4023987494	JOHN.GORMELY@NNGCO.COM	4023987606	"ON DED.19, A SERVICE TO THREE AQUILA COMMUNITIES WAS INTERRUPTED WHEN A BRANCHLINE REGULATOR, OWNED BY NORTHERN NATURAL GAS, FAILED TO OPERATE CORRECTLY AND PRESSURES DROPPED TO CRITICAL LEVELS AT THE DELIVERY POINTS TO THE COMMUNITIES. AQUILA EXPERIENCED LOSS OF SERVICE TO A PORTION OF THEIR CUSTOMERS IN THE COMMUNITIES OF PINE ISLAND, WANAMINGO AND ZUMBROTA,MN. APPROX 250 HOMES AND BUSINESSES LOST NATURAL GAS SERVICE IN THE THREE COMMUNITIES.    THE ZUMBROTA AREA HAD EXPERIENCED SEVERE WINTER WEATHER TEMPERATURES PRIOR TO THE INCIDENT. THE EVENING OF THE INCIDENT TEMPERATURES WERE IN THE SINGLE DIGITS WITH WIND CHILL BELOW ZERO. THE LACK OF PILOT GAS HEAT ALLOWED THE TEMPERATURES IN THE PILOT GAS LINE TO DROP TO AMBIENT TEMPERATURES, WHICH WERE AS LOW AS 8 DEGREES FAHRENHEIT. THE LOW GAS TEMPERATURES, COUPLED WITH THE  TEMPERATURE DROP THROUGH THE PILOT REGULATOR, DROPPED THE  TEMPERATURE OF THE GAS TO A POINT THAT MATCHED OR EXCEEDED THE DEW POINT OF THE GAS STREAM. WATER DROPPED OUT IN THE ORIFICE OF THE PILOT GAS REGULATOR AND FROZE, THUS IMPEDING FULL OPERATION OF THE REGULATOR.    NORTHERN IS FILING THIS INCIDENT REPORT BECAUSE IT CONSIDERS THIS AS A SIGNIFICANT EVENT UNDER 191.3.  THIS REPORT IS BEING SUBMITTED LATE AS THERE WAS AN OVERSIGHT IN FOLLOW-UP DUE TO THE FACT THAT THE INCIDENT DID NOT MEET THE $50,000 DOLLAR REQUIREMENT, THERE WERE NO INJURIES AND NO RELEASE OF PRODUCT."

CAVITT	3184293606	JOHNNY.CAVITT@CENTERPOINTENERGY.COM	3184293927	"SYSTEM CONTROL NOTICED A REDUCTION IN THE NORMAL INLET PRESSURE TO THE A-194 METER STATION EARLY IN THE MORNING OF FEBRUARY 6, 2006. THE FIELD PERSONNEL VERIFIED THAT THE INLET PRESSURE WAS BEING RESTRICTED BY THE 2"" WKM TAP VALVE FOR THE A-194 LINE. HE CALLED IN A CREW TO DIG UP AND DETERMINE WHAT WAS CAUSING THIS PROBLEM. AFTER THEY DUG UP THE VALVE, THEY REMOVED THE VALVE HANDLE EXTENSION. THE STEM IN THE VALVE BROKE AND BLEW OUT OF THE VALVE AFTER THE EXTENSION WAS REMOVED, CAUSING GAS TO START EXCAPING FROM THE VALVE. THEY ATTEMPTED TO REINSTALL THE STEM BUT COULD NOT GET THE GAS TO STOP LEAKING. WHEN THE STEM BROKE APPARENTLY THE GATE ON THE 2"" WKM VALVE BECAME ALMOST COMPLETELY CLOSED RESULTING IN THE LOSS OF GAS SERVICE TO THE A-194 CUSTOMER. IN ORDER TO REPLACE THIS FAULTY VALVE WE HAD TO BLOWDOWN OUR A-151 AND A-183 LINES, WHICH RESULTED IN THE LOSS OF SERVICE TO THE CUSTOMERS ON THOSE LINES ALSO. WE INSTALLED A NEW 2"" ORBIT VALVE TO REPLACE THE WKM VALVE."

HANSEN	8013243645	JEFF.HANSEN@QUESTAR.COM	8013243816	"THIS PIPE RUPTURED AT OR NEAR THE SITE WHERE A CORROSION PIT HAD BEEN REPAIRED BY FILLING WITH WELD MATERIAL.  CONSTRUCTION RECORDS INDICATE THAT THIS REPAIR WAS MADE PRIOR TO INSTALLING THE PIPE IN 1955.  A METALLURGICAL INVESTIGATION BY EWI WORKING IN CONJUNCTION WITH AMERICAN METALLURGICAL SERVICES CONCLUDED THAT ""THE FEEDER-LINE 18 FAILURE ORIGIN WAS IN A WELD REGION NEAR THE BOTTOM OF THE PIPELINE.""  THE INVESTIGATION FOUND NO EVIDENCE OF ACTIVE CORROSION, FATIGUE CRACKING, HYDROGEN STRESS CRACKING, OR STRESS CORROSION CRACKING.    FURTHER, THE METALLURGICAL INVESTIGATION FOUND THAT ""THE ORIENTATION OF THE FRACTURE AND THE DISTINCT DOG-LEG APPEARANCE OF THE REMOVED PIPELINE SECTION WOULD SUGGEST AN EXTERNAL LOAD MAY HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO THE FRACTURE.""  AN INVESTIGATION OF POTENTIAL EXTERNAL LOADING DID FIND THAT ADDITIONAL THIRD-PARTY FILL HAD BEEN PLACED OVER THE PIPELINE IN THE REGION OF THE FRACTURE, AND THAT OTHER UTILITIES HAD BEEN INSTALLED UNDER THE PIPELINE IN THIS SAME AREA.  HOWEVER, IT COULD NOT BE CONCLUDED THAT THESE FACTORS OR OTHER FACTORS INCLUDING NATURALLY OCCURRING OUTSIDE FORCES ALONE PROVIDED SUFFICIENT EXTERNAL LOADING TO HAVE CAUSED THIS FAILURE."

CAVITT	3184293606	JOHNNY.CAVITT@CENTERPOINTENERGY.COM	3184293927	"A CALL WAS RECEIVED AT OUR EL DORADO FIELD OFFICE ABOUT GAS ODOR AND A POSSIBLE GAS LEAK NEAR APPLE ST.CAMDEN AR. AT APPROXIMATELY 0830, FEB 13, 2006.  FIELD PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO THE AREA, AND AT FIRST SUSPECTED A MINOR LEAK ON LINE K-NORTH.  UPON EXCAVATION IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE LEAK INVOLVED A DEFECTIVE BOLTED CLAMP COUPLING THAT HAD ALLOWED THE PIPE TO PULL OUT ABOUT 2.75 INCHES.  IT WAS DETERMINED THE REPAIR WOULD PROBABLY EXCEED $50,000 AND A CALL WAS PLACE TO THE SYSTEM CONTROL, WHO IN TURNED INITIATED OUR INCIDENT REPORTING PROCEDURE AND MADE TELEPHONIC NOTIFICATIONS TO THE APPROPRIATE AGENCIES.  ABOUT A 500 FOOT SECTION OF THE PIPELINE WAS ISOLATED AND BLOWN DOWN.  THE LEAKING COUPLING WAS REPAIRED BY INSTALLING A 220 WELDOVER SLEEVE.  NO CUSTOMERS WERE LOST DURING THE REPAIR. THIS INCIDENT DID NOT INITIALLY MEET CPUC/DOT REPORTING CRITERIA.  CLEANUP WAS COMPLETED TO INITIAL DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME PARAMETERS AT A TOTAL COST THAT DID NOT EXCEED $50,000.  IT WAS NOT UNTIL MARCH 1 THAT A SUBSEQUENT SITE VISIT BY THE DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME EXPANDED THE MITIGATION SCOPE TO AND TOTAL ESTIMATE COST THAT WOULD EXCEED $50,000.  AS A RESULT, THIS INCIDENT WAS REPORTED ON MARCH 1, 2006."

2006	12462	20060064		ENBRIDGE PIPELINES (MIDLA) L.L.C.	1100 LOUISIANA SUITE 3300	HOUSTON	HARRIS	TX	77002	1450	4/5/2006	VIDALIA	CONCORDIA	LA	71373	MP 4764 + 52		N31 32.785	W91 28.307	N	1				NO	NO	Y	INTERSTATE	4	OTHER	COUPLING SEPARATION								0	0	0	0	1	0	0	1	990500	19500	34000	937000	NO	NO	YES	NO	0			3	0	4/5/2006	793117	160	204	YES	NO	NO	NO	NO	N	1	TRANSMISSION	4	COMPONENT		1	STEEL		NO	NO	NO	1	PIPELINE		1926	18	0.38		35000	LAP WELD	GATE	UNKNOWN		4	UNDER GROUND		48	5/4/2006	25	OTHER									NULL		NULL																	NULL						NULL			NULL			NULL																									NULL	NULL																							1	INVESTIGATION COMPLETE	TERRY MCMILLIN	7133535670	TERRY.MCMILLIN@ENBRIDGE.COM	7133535620	"04/16/2014 -     FAILED COUPLING CAUSED BY VIBRATION & PRESSURE ON PIPING.     LESLIE STEVENS  COMPLIANCE COORDINATOR  832-214-1649  LESLIE.STEVENS@ENBRIDGE.COM    THE FOLLOWING IS BASED ON INFORMATION OBTAINED FROM THE CONTRACTOR AND ITS EMPLOYEES AND THE ONE ENBRIDGE EMPLOYEE AT THE SITE. THE INITIAL OPERATION INVOLVED THE REPLACEMENT OF A 20 LOOP LINE VALVE LOCATED ON THE 20 LOOP LINE.  PARALLEL TO THE 20 LOOP LINE IS ENBRIDGES 22 MAIN LINE.  THE LOOP LINE AND MAIN LINE ARE CONNECTED BY AN 18 CROSSOVER LINE.  THE 18 CROSSOVER LINE VALVE HAD BEEN CLOSED AND THE 20 LOOP LINE SEGMENT HAD BEEN ISOLATED AT THE MAIN HEADER SOUTH OF THE 20 LOOP LINE VALVE TO BE REPLACED AND AT ANOTHER LOOP LINE VALVE LOCATED TO THE NORTH OF THE EXCAVATED SITE.  THE ISOLATED SEGMENT WAS BLED DOWN TO ATMOSPHERE AT THIS POINT.  THE 18 CROSSOVER LINE VALVE HAD BEEN SKIDDED OR SUPPORTED WITH BLOCKS SO THERE WOULD BE NO MOVEMENT WHEN THE 18 CROSSOVER LINE WOULD BE CUT DOWNSTREAM OF THE 18 CROSSOVER LINE VALVE.  CUTS ONE, TWO AND THREE WERE THEN MADE. THE NOW FREE TEE SECTION WAS REMOVED FROM THE EXCAVATION AS WAS THE WEST CONCRETE WALL OF THE 18 CROSSOVER LINE VALVE BOX.  THE SKIDDED 18 CROSSOVER LINE VALVE REMAINED STABLE AND UNMOVED AFTER THE CUTS WERE MADE.  THE PORTION OF THE 20 LOOP LINE CONTAINING THE 20 LOOP LINE VALVE TO BE REPLACED, EXPOSED IN THE EXCAVATION, WAS CUT AGAIN (CUT 4) ON THE NORTH SIDE OF THE 20 LOOP LINE VALVE.  THIS LEFT THE 20 LOOP LINE VALVE FREE TO BE REMOVED FOR REPLACEMENT.  BECAUSE THE 20 LOOP LINE SEGMENT HAD A HUGE BLOCK OF CONCRETE POURED AROUND IT FOR SUPPORT WHEN ORIGINALLY LAID, THE BLOCK OF CONCRETE HAD TO BE BROKEN UP IN ORDER FOR THE 20 LOOP LINE VALVE AND 20 LOOP LINE CUT SEGMENT TO BE LIFTED OUT OF THE EXCAVATION.  CONTRACTORS CREWS BEGAN JACK HAMMERING ON THE BLOCK OF CONCRETE AND WITHIN 30 MINUTES TO AN HOUR THE GAS RELEASE OCCURRED.  LATER IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT A COUPLING  ON THE 18 CROSSOVER LINE BETWEEN THE 18CROSSOVER LINE VALVE AND THE 22 MAIN LINE, WHICH WAS STILL UNDER PRESSURE, HAD UNCOUPLED.   ALSO PRESENT BETWEEN THE EXCAVATION AND THE COUPLING ON THE 18 CROSSOVER LINE WAS AN OLD ABANDON UNEXPOSED CISTERN.  IT IS POSSIBLE THAT THESE WERE THE THREE MAIN CONTRIBUTING FACTORS TO THE RELEASE EVENT.  IT IS BELIEVED THAT THE CROSSOVER COUPLING PROVIDED MINIMAL STRENGTH, TO THE HORIZONTAL PRESSURE CREATED WHEN THE 18 CROSSOVER LINE WAS CUT AND REMOVED FROM THE 20 LOOP LINE AND THAT THE ABANDON CISTERN PROVIDED REDUCED SOIL COMPACTION, VOLUME AND STRENGTH HOLDING CAPACITIES AFTER THE CUT AND REMOVAL WERE MADE.  FINALLY, THE JACK HAMMERING ON THE CONCRETE POURED OVER THE CUT 20 LOOP LINE PROVIDED EXTERNAL VIBRATION TO THE REDUCED VOLUME OF UNDISTURBED, COMPACTED SOIL CREATED BY THE CISTERN. A SKETCH OF THE INCIDENT AREA WAS NOT ATTACHED BECAUSE OF LIMITATIONS REGARDING THE OPS ONLINE DATA ENTRY AND OPERATOR REGISTRATION SYSTEM, HOWEVER A SKETCH CAN BE PROVIDED UPON REQUEST."

MIKE REED	4055584685	REEDMD@OGE.COM	4055578618	"INSTRUMENT AIR IS USED TO SUPPLY CONTROL PRESSURE TO A FAIL-OPEN ACTUATED BLOWDOWN VALVE LOCATED IN THE NATURAL GAS COMPRESSOR'S DISCHARGE PIPING. JEFF KOSKIE	2132443283	WKOSKIE@SEMPRAUTILITIES.COM	2132448155	"ON MAY 4, 2006, WHILE PERFORMING A LEAK INVESTIGATION ON A 12 HIGH PRESSURE SUPPLY LINE, A CRACK WAS DISCOVERED AT A MAIN-TO-MAIN CONNECTION.  REPAIR COSTS WERE ESTIMATED TO EXCEED $50,000, AND AS A RESULT, THE INCIDENT WAS REPORTED TO DOT AND CPUC.    FURTHER INVESTIGATION DETERMINED THAT THE CRACK WAS THE RESULT OF CUMULATIVE LOAD UPON THE FAILED WELD.  ANY POTENTIAL THIRD PARTY CONTRIBUTION TO THIS FAILURE IS BEING INVESTIGATED BY SOCALGAS CLAIMS DEPARTMENT.      ALL REPAIRS HAVE BEEN COMPLETED, AND LINES PUT BACK INTO NORMAL OPERATING PRESSURE. EXCAVATION WORK WAS PERFORMED WITH EARTH MOVING EQUIPMENT (BELLY DUMP SCRAPERS). DURING EXCAVATION OVER THE PIPELINE, THE SCRAPER PUNCTURED THRU THE PIPE AND CREATED ~6""X3"" TEAR WHICH ALLOWED GAS TO VENT TO ATMOSPHERE. AT APPROXIMATELY 10:15 AM MST A KMI RETAIL EMPLOYEE REPORTED A HIGH PRESSURE GAS RELEASE WEST OF THE ROARING FORK RIVER EAST OF THE GLENWOOD INTERCONNECT ON THE ROW FOR THE 12"" MAINLINE. KMI RETAIL AND TRANSMISSION PERSONNEL WORKING WITH LKW GAS CONTROL DETERMINED THE DAMAGE WAS ON THE 12"" AND MOBILIZED TO THE GLENWOOD SPRINGS INTERCONNECT AND SUBSTATION MAINLINE BLOCK VALVE TO ISOLATE THE AFFECTED SEGMENT. THE SEGMENT WAS ISOLATED (~5 MILES OF PIPELINE) AT 11:10 AM MST AND ALLOWED TO BLOW DOWN THRU THE PUNCTURE. COUNTY ROADS 109 (WEST SIDE), AND 154 (EAST SIDE) WERE CLOSED. RESIDENTIAL AND COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS WERE EVACUATED (50-100 PEOPLE) IN THE IMMEDIATE AREA DUE TO THE NATURAL GAS PLUME. EMERGENCY RESPONSE SUPPORT WAS PROVIDED BY THE CARBONDALE FIRE DEPARTMENT, COUNTY SHERIFF, AND STATE PATROL. THE AREA WAS DETERMINED TO BE SAFE AT APPROXIMATELY 2:30 PM, ROADS OPENED AND THE EVACUATION LIFTED. AFTER COMPLETING REPAIRS TO AN ADJACENT 4"" RETAIL PE LINE THE TRANSMISSION PIPE WAS REPAIRED (7' REPLACED) AND RETURNED TO SERVICE ~7:45 PM. NO FIRE OR PERSONAL INJURIES AS A RESULT OF THE INCIDENT."

WOOD	4023987396	BYRON.WOOD@NNGCO.COM	4033987606	"NORTHERN NATURAL GAS HAD INSTALLED A 2 INCH BYPASS HOSE AT THE BUFFALO, MN # 1 TBS TO ENABLE CENTERPOINT ENERGY TO BE ABLE TO COMPLETE MODIFICATIONS/UPGRADING ON THEIR FACILITIES. COLD WEATHER RESULTED IN GAS CONSUMPTION INCREASING AND THE 2 INCH BYPASS HOSE REACHED CRITICAL FLOW AS IT WAS INSUFFICENT IN SIZE AND CAPACITY TO SUPPLY THE REQUIRED PRESSURES AND FLOWS. GAS CONSUMPTION BY END USERS PULLED THE UTILITIES PRESSURES DOWN TO A POINT THAT DUE TO CONCERN OF POTENTIALLY PULLING AIR INTO THEIR DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM, CENTERPOINT ENERGY CLOSED THEIR VALVE TO THE CITIES DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM. APPROXIMATELY 5,500 METER SETTINGS, WITHIN THE CITY HAD TO BE PURGED AND RELIT.      SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT: THE CAUSE OF THE OUTAGE WAS HUMAN ERROR ON THE PART OF NORTHERN NATURAL GAS COMPANY PERSONNEL, RESULTING IN INADEQUATE TEMPORARY FACILITIES BEING INSTALLED TO FACILITATE ROUTINE MAINTENANCE ON THE TOWN BORDER STATION THAT SERVES AS THE NATURAL GAS TRANSFER POINT FROM NORTHERN NATURAL GAS COMPANY TO CENTERPOINT ENERGY. THERE WAS NO RELEASE OF GAS TO ATMOSPHERE, NO PUBLIC OR PRIVATE PROPERTY DAMAGE. ESTIMATED COST INCURRED WAS RELATED TO THE ACTIONS AND ACTIVIITES REQUIRED IN RE-ESTABLISHING GAS SERVICE AND RELIGHTING OF THE APPROXIMATE 5,500 METER SETTINGS."

CAVITT	3184293606	JOHNNY.CAVITT@CENTERPOINTENERGY.COM	3184293927	"DURING EXCAVATION FOR AN ECDA DIG, THE CREW DISCOVERED A LEAK. UPON FURTHER INVESTIGATION IT APPEARED THAT THE THREADS ONA PIPE NIPPLE UNDER A 1 VALVE WERE CRACKED. AFTER WE WERE ABLE TO REMOVE THE GAS FROM THE PIPE, IT WAS DISCOVERED TO BE ONLY A LOOSE VALVE ON THE NIPPLE. THERE WAS A CABLE THAT HAD APPARENTLY BEEN USED TO ALIGNED UP THE PIPE ON INSTALLATION. THE CABLE WAS LEFT WRAPPED AROUND THE PIPE AND ALSO THE 1 NIPPLE AND VALVE. WHEN THE EXCAVATION WAS PERFORMED THE CREW APPARENTLY GRABBED THE CABLE AND BENT OVER THE NIPPLE, LOOSENING THE VALVE SCREWED INTO THE NIPPLE AND CREATED THE LEAK.   LINE PRESSUE WAS LOWERED FROM 270 PSIG TO 110 PSIG. EMERGENCY RESPONSE ACTIONS WERE TAKEN.  A STOPPLE JOB WAS PERFORMED, THE VALVE REMOVED, AND THE LINE WAS REPAIRED AND RETURNED TO NORMAL OPERATIONS."

SMITH COMPLIANCE SPECIALIST	6148182110	RRSMITH@NISOURCE.COM	6148182151	"COLUMBIA GAS OF OHIO INC. WAS RESTORING GAS PRESSURE TO A PARTIALLY REPLACED GAS DISTRIBUTION TRANSMISSION PIPELINE ON DENUNE AVE. IN COLUMBUS OHIO WHEN AN UNEXCAVATED MECHANICAL JOINT COUPLING SEPARATED.  THE SEPARATION OF THE COUPLING CAUSED A RELEASE OF GAS THAT LIFTED A STREET PLATE AND DEBRIS INTO OVERHEAD POWERLINES THAT CAUSED AN ELECTRIC SERVICE DISRUPTION. THE DEBRIS ALSO CAUSED DAMAGE TO SEVERAL NEARBY HOMES AND VEHICLES.  THE GAS WAS PROMPTLY SHUT DOWN AND THE SITUATION MADE SAFE.  THE UNEXCAVATED MECHANICAL JOINT COUPLING THAT SEPARATED WAS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 11 FEET OUTSIDE ON OF THE TIE-IN HOLES FOR THE PIPELINE REPLACEMENT.    PLEASE NOTE: THIS INCIDENT DOES NOT MEET THE CRITERIA OF A ""HIGH CONSEQUENCE AREA"" BASED ON 49CFR PART 192 SUBPAR ""O-PIPELINE INTEGRITY MANAGEMENT.""  COLUMBIA GAS OF OHIO INC. PROMPTLY REPLACED THE 18"" BARE STEEL PIPE AND REPLACED IT WITH 1378 FEET OF NEW WELD TREATED STEEL MAIN. RYAN	8154675412	JIM_R_RYAN@PRAXAIR.COM	8154675643	"THE OPERATORS INVOLVED HAD BEGUN WORK TO PURGE A NEW 6"" LINE INTO SERVICE, BY BRINGING H2 INTO THE 6"" LINE FROM AN ADJACENT 8"" LINE, WHICH WAS ALREADY IN SERVICE.  THE REQUIRED PRE-WORK HAD BEEN COMPLETED, AND ONE OPERATOR WAS AT THE BELTWAY 8 AND HWY 225 VALVE STATION PREPARING TO SLOWLY LET H2 INTO THE LINE.  THE SECOND OPERATOR WAS AT THE LHR PARKING LOT VALVE STATION VENT TO MONITOR PURGE GAS FLOW AND PURITY.  THE SECOND OPERATOR MISTAKENLY THOUGHT THAT THE PURGE HAD STARTED, AND HE THOUGHT THAT THERE WAS INSUFFICIENT PURGE FLOW AT THE VENT.  HE DECIDED TO OPEN THE ISOLATION VALVE TO THE PRESSURIZED 8"" LINE AT HIS END.  HE OPENED THE VALVE, CAUSING A HIGH-VOLUME FLOW OF HYDROGEN THROUGH THE ADJACENT VENT PIPE, WHICH IGNITED. THERE WAS A FIRE AND EXPLOSION, AND ONE FATALITY RESULTED FOLLOWING THE INCIDENT.      ** AFTER EXCAVATION BY KINDER MORGAN CONTRACTOR AND SUBSEQUENT RUPTURE, PIPELINE COVER WAS MEASURED AT 26.40 INCHES.    AFTER COMPLETING THE INTERNAL INVESTIGATION, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THIS INCIDENT WAS CAUSED BY A CONFLUENCE OF EVENTS BY A VARIETY OF ACTIONS, AND MORE SPECIFICALLY THAT:    1. CONSTRUCTIONG PARTY DID NOT LOCATE AND MARK THE LOCATION OF WIC'S PIPELINE PRIOR TO STARTING CONSTRUCTION AS REQUIRED BY ITS FERC CERTIFICATE OF PUBLIC CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY.    2. SURVEY COMPANIES DID NOT PHYSICALLY LOCATE NEARBY EXISTING UNDERGROUND FACILITIES, INCLUDING THE WIC PIPELINE, WHEN CREATING SURVEYS USED IN THE REX PROJECT.  WHEN STAKING THE EDGE OF REX'S TEMPORARY CONSTRUCTION RIGHT-OF-WAY, SURVEY COMPANIES REPEATEDLY PLACED STAKES NEAR, ON AND TO THE NORTH OF THE WIC PIPELINE.  THE CONSTRUCTION INSPECTION COMPANY DID NOT DETECT AND/OR CORRECT THE DEFICIENCIES IN THE SURVEY OR THE STAKING OF THE RIGHT-OF-WAY.    3. CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTOR DID NOT PHYSICALLY LOCATE OR MARK EXISTING UNDERGROUND FACILITIES, INCLUDING THE WIC PIPELINE, WHEN THOSE FACILITIES WERE PARALLEL TO THE NEW PIPELINE BEING CONSTRUCTED (REX) NOR DID CONSTRUCTION USE POTHOLING TO DISCOVER THE LOCATION OF THE PARALLEL WIC PIPELINE ONCE THE ENCROACHMENTS BY THE REX TEMPORARY CONSTRUCTION RIGHT-OF-WAY HAD BEGUN TO OCCUR.  CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTOR DID NOT UNDERTAKE EFFORTS PRIOR TO INVESTIGATE THE NATURE OF THE HARD SUBSURFACE MATERIAL ENCOUNTERED IN THE AREA OF THE RUPTURE.    4. DECEASED EMPLOYEE OF CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTOR WAS PROBABLY UNAWARE OF THE LOCATION OF THE WIC PIPELINE WHILE USING THE BULLDOZER TO RIP THE GROUND BETWEEN THE WESTERN AND EASTERN PERMANENT WIC PIPELINE MARKERS OF THE RUPTURE SITE.    5. EMPLOYEE OF CONTRACTOR HIRED TO LOCATE, AND WHEN NECESSARY FLAG THE LOCATION OF THE WIC PIPELINE DID NOT FLAG THE LOCATION OF THE PIPELINE BETWEEN THE WESTERN AND EASTERN PERMANENT WIC PIPELINE MARKERS NEAR THE RUPTURE SITE."

SCHRIEVER PERSONNEL CONTACTED INDIVIDUAL, WHO REPORTED THE LOCATION AS THE VALVE SETTING ALONG HIGHWAY 18. PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED FROM SCHRIEVER TO INVESTIGATE. PERSONNEL DISCOVERED A GAS LEAKING FROM UNDERGROUND AND VISIBLE AT THE SURFACE UNDER THE DEPARTING PIG LAUNCHER. PERSONNEL ISOLATED THE VALVE SETTING HEADER AND CROSSOVER PIPING AND BLEW DOWN THE GAS AND THE LEAK STOPPED. THE LEAK WAS ORIGINALLY JUDGED TO BE NON-REPORTABLE. COST ESTIMATES FOR THE REPAIR LATER REVEALED  IT DID MEET REPORTABLE CRITERIA. THE DOT SW REGION DIRECTOR, ROD SEELEY, WAS NOTIFIED. NO REGULATORY ENFORCEMENT ACTION WAS RECOMMENDED.   THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE IN A 36"" HEADER AND THE HEADER WAS EXCAVATED IN THE VICINITY OF THE LEAK.  THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO HAVE BEEN CAUSED BY SIGNIFICANT INTERNAL CORROSION IN THE 6 O'CLOCK POSITION AT THE WELD CAP ON THE WEST END OF THE HEADER.  THE HEADER ADJACENT TO THE LEAK WAS INTERNALLY INSPECTED AND ALL PIPE WITH SIGNIFICANT INTERNAL CORROSION WAS REMOVED BY CUTTING PIPE FROM THE END OF THE HEADER.  REPAIR WAS COMPLETED BY WELDING A CAP ONTO THE CUT END.  THE OPPOSITE END OF THE HEADER WAS EXCAVATED AND EXAMINED BY X-RAY AND ULTRASONIC MEANS TO VERIFY ITS INTEGRITY.  THE REPAIRED HEADER WAS HYDROSTATICALLY TESTED BEFORE RETURNING THE HEADER TO SERVICE."

MCDONALD	7133812494	JMCDONALD@EPROD.COM	7133818790	"LEAK WAS REPORTED ON OUR WEBB COUNTY 20"" PIPELINE ON NOVEMBER 25, 2006.  THE LEAK WAS AT THE LOCATION OF A NEW HOT TAP INSTALLATION WE HAD MADE ON THIS PIPELINE EARLIER IN 2006 AND THE LEAK RATE WAS MINIMAL.  AFTER INITIAL REVIEW, A DECISION WAS MADE TO TAKE THE PIPELINE OUT OF SERVICE SO IT COULD BE FURTHER EVALUATED.  THIS ACTION WAS THE INITIAL ACTION THAT MADE THE INCIDENT REPORTABLE TO THE RAILROAD COMMISSION OF TEXAS.  THE NOTIFICATION TO THE STATE OCCURED WITHIN TWO HOURS OF THAT DECISION AND WAS MADE ON NOVEMBER 25, 2006 BY DOUG MENKE, OPERATIONS SUPERVISOR.  OUR INITIAL ASSUMPTION WAS PROVEN TO BE CORRECT IN THAT WE CONFIRMED THAT WE HAD A LEAKING HOT TAP CLAMP.  THE CLAMP VENDOR TRAVELLED TO THE LOCATION TO INJECT SEALANT IN THE HOT TAP FITTING TO TRY AND STOP THE LEAK.  IT WAS CONFIRMED AT THAT TIME THAT THE PIPE WAS ALSO LEAKING AND THAT A REPAIR OF A LEAKING SEAL WOULD NOT HANDLE THE REPAIR.  A DECISION WAS MADE THAT WE WOULD HAVE TO CUT OUT PIPE AND REPLACE THE HOT TAP ASSEMBLY AND LEAKING PIPE.  THIS DECISION CAUSED THE REPAIR COST ESTIMATE TO NOW EXCEED THE $50,000 REPORTING THRESHOLD.  OPERATIONS NOTIFED COMPLIANCE OF THIS DECISION VIA AN EMAIL ON THE MORNING OF DECEMBER 11, 2006.  BASED ON THIS NEW INFORMATION NOTIFICATION OF THIS BEING A REPORTABLE INCIDENT WAS MADE TO THE NRC.  THE FITTING ASSEMBLY AND PIPE WERE SENT TO A METALLURGIST FOR EXAMINATION.  THE METALLUGICAL ANALYSIS REPORTED THAT ONE OF THE SEALS ON THE HOT TAP CLAMP DID NOT SEAT PROPERLY AND OVER A PERIOD OF TIME BEGAN TO LEAK GAS INTO THE CAVITY BETWEEN THE PRIMARY AND SECONDARY SEAL.  IN TIME, THE SECONDARY SEAL FAILED AND GAS BEGAN JETTING TOWARD THE BODY OF THE PIPE UNTIL SUCH TIME THAT THE MAIN 20"" PIPELINE WAS CUT AND STARTED TO LEAK.  THE VENDOR REPORTED THAT THIS WAS THE FIRST FAILURE OF ITS TYPE ON THIS TYPE OF HOT TAP CLAMP INSTALLATION AND IS TAKING ACTIONS TO IMPROVE THEIR SEAL DESIGN. THE PIPELINE WAS PLACED BACK INTO SERVICE AFTER A TEE WAS WELDED INTO THE PIPELINE ELIMINATING THE NEED FOR A BOLT ON CLAMP AT THIS TIE IN CONNECTION."

LOYD, SPECIALIST COMPLIANCE"	7023652080	HOLLY.LOYD@SWGAS.COM	7022214116	"ON 12/6/06 A SOUTHWEST GAS CREW WAS EXCVATING AROUND PIPELINE FACILITIES LOACTED IN TROPICANA AVE, 645 FEET EAST OF FRANK SINATRA DRIVE, LAS VEGAS.  THE WORK INCLUDED INVESTIGATION OF A GRADE 3 LEAK AND ABANDONING TWO 4-INCH STEEL SUBS, ONE OF WHICH INCLUDED A 2-INCH STEEL SIDE-TAP VALVE.  BOTH STUBS WERE WELDED TO A 16-INCH STEEL TRANSMISSION PIPELINE.    AT 23:28 ON 12/6/06, WHILE THE SOUTHWEST GAS CREW WAS REMOVING DIRT, DAMAGE OCCURED ON THE 16-INCH PIPE NEAR THE FILLET WELD FOR THE 2-INCH SIDE-TAP VALVE STUB, CAUSING LEAKAGE TO OCCUR.  SOUTHWEST IMMEDIATELY IMPLEMENTED THE INCIDENT MANAGEMENT SYSTEM.  ATMOSPHERIC GAS DETECTED IN THE PARKING GARAGE AT THE NEW YORK-NEW YORK HOTEL DURING THE INITIAL PERIMETER SURVEY RESULTED IN CLOSURE OF THE GARAGE.  THE INCIDENT PERIMETER WAS SECURED AT 01:15 ON 12/07/06.  THE PERIMETER WAS LATER EXPANDED AT 03:20 ON 12/7/06 DUE TO SHIFTING WINDS.  CONTINUAL SURVEILLANCE OF THE AFFECTED AREA CONFIRMED THAT NO UNDERGROUND LEAK MIGRATION WAS OCCURRING.    ATTEMPTS TO MAINTAIN THE LINE PRESSURE IN THE 16-INCH PIPELINE WHILE REPAIRING THE DAMAGE FAILED SO SOUTHWEST CREWS CLOSED VALVES TO ISOLATE THE AFFECTED AREA.  SOUTHWEST COMPLETED BLOW-DOWN OF THE AFFECTED LINES ON 12/7/06 AT 08:57 AND BEGAN REPAIRS.  THE DAMAGE TO THE 16-INCH STEEL LINE WAS REPAIRED BY REMOVING THE 2-INCH SIDE-TAP VALVE SUB AND BOLTING ON A 16-INCH REPAIR CLAMP.  ON 12/7/06, SOUTHWEST COMPLETED THE REPAIRS AT 14:50 AND THE RELIGHTS AT 23:45.    THE INVESTIGATION OF THE DAMAGED 16-INCH BY 2-INCH CONNECTION INDICATES EARTH MOVEMENT DURING EXCAVATION NEAR THE 2-INCH SIDE TAP VALVE STUB CAUSED A CRACK TO OCCUR ON THE 16-INCH PIPE NEAR THE 2-INCH FILLET WELD TO THE 16-INCH PIPELINE.  A PRESSURE TEST OF THE 4-INCH PIPE INCLUDING THE 2-INCH VALVE CONFIRMED THAT THE GRADE 3 LEAK WAS ON THE 2-INCH SIDE TAP VALVE AND WAS UNRELATED TO THE FAILURE.    THIS INCIDENT AFFECTED 66 CUSTOMERS.  GAS LOSS INCLUDED 27873 THERMS.  ESCAPING GAS DID NOT IGNITE.  NO INJURIES OR FATALITIES RESULTED FROM THE INCIDENT."

WOOD	4023987396	BYRON.WOOD@NNGCO.COM	4023987606	"ON JANUARY 1, 2007, AT APROXIMATELY 1200, SERVICE TO THE TOWN OF SATANTA, KANSAS WAS INTERRUPTED DUE TO THE FORMATION OF A HYDRATE FREEZE IN THE 4-INCH INLET SUPPLY LINE TO THE SATANTA TOWN BORDER STATION. THE HYDRATE FREEZE WAS FOUND TO HAVE DEVELOPED DOWNSTREAM OF THE HASKELL COUNTY DEHYDRATION UNIT AND UPSTREAM OF THE SATANTA TBS. THE DEHYDRATION UNIT AND THE TBS ARE OWNED AND OPERATED BY NORTHERN NATURAL GAS AND DELIVER TO THE LOCAL DISTRIBUTION COMPANY, AQUILA, INC. AQUILA PROVIDES GAS SERVICE TO APPROXIMATELY 500 HOMES AND BUSINESS IN SATANTA, WHICH WERE IMPACTED BY THE LOSS OF SERVICE. AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT THE STATE OF KANSAS WAS INCURRING A VERY SEVERE WINTER STORM WHICH PRODUCED LOW TEMPERATURES AND A SIGNIFICANT AMOUNT OF ICE WHICH RESULTED IN A BUILDUP OF ICE ON POWER LINES AND POWER POLES RESULTING IN MANY POLES AND LINES BREAKING DUE TO EXCESS WEIGHT CREATING WIDESPREAD POWER OUTAGES.   SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT - THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE SERVICE INTERRUPTION TO THE TOWN OF SATANTA,KS IS DETERMINED TO BE FROM A HYDRATE FREEZE IN THE GAS LINE.THE HYDRATE FREEZE WAS DETERMINED TO BE CAUSED BY SEVERAL CONTRIBUTING FACTORS. WATER SATURATED GAS IN COMBINATION WITH HYDROCARBON LIQUIDS, MULTIPLE SYSTEM CONFIGURATIONS, MULTIPLE ELECTRICAL POWER OUTAGES WHICH SHUTDOWN THE TBS HEATER AND THE BYPASS OF THE DEHYDRATION UNIT ON 1/1/2007 GENERATED THE CONDITIONS REQUIRED TO FORM A HYDRATE FREEZE.  THE FORMATION OF THE HYDRATE FREEZE BLOCKED OFF THE GAS FLOW TO THE TOWN OF SATANTA, KS, RESULTING IN A LOSS OF NATURAL GAS SERVICE TO THE TOWN."

THE LEAK WAS CONFIRMED BY SSCGP PERSONNEL AT 6:25 PM. THE LOCAL DISTRICT MANAGER CALLED IN TANK TRUCKS TO SUPPLY GAS TO THE CITIES OF PARTRIDGE AND HEADING. THE HUTCHINSON FRACTIONALIZATION PLANT WAS NOTIFIED THEY WOULD LOSE THEIR GAS. THE RENO COUNTY SHERIFF'S DEPARTMENT ASKED BNSF RAILROAD TO SHUT DOWN OPERATIONS IN THE AREA OF THE LEAK. THE TANK TRUCKS BEGAN HOLDING UP THE TWO CITIES AT 1:00 AM ON FEBRUARY SIXTH AND THE FRACTIONALIZATION PLANT WAS SHUT IN. THE MAIN LINE GATES WERE CLOSED AND THE BLOW DOWN BEGAN. THE RAILROAD TRACKS WERE RE-OPENED AT 4:45 AM. THE LINE WAS DUG UP AND IT WAS DETERMINED THAT A CRACKED WELD WAS THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK. THE LINE WAS CAPPED ON THE NORTH SIDE OF THE BNSP RAILROAD TRACKS AND ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF HIGHWAY 50 LEAVING THE SECTION UNDER THE RAILROAD TRACKS AND HIGHWAYS ISOLATED FOR MORE INSPECTIONS.  3/12/08 A SUPPLEMENTAL AND FINAL REPORT OF THIS INCIDENT IS BEING MADE TO CHANGE THE COST OF GAS LOSS ONLY. THE COST IS BEING RAISED FROM $500,000 TO $6,118,217. ON REVIEW OF SYSTEM BALANCE DATA, IT WAS DISCOVERED GAS LOSSES BEGAN ON JANUARY 22ND AND CONTINUED UNTIL THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED ON FEBRUARY 5TH. THIS GAS COST IS BASED ON ACTUAL GAS LOSSES AT A SYSTEM AVERAGE COST OF $5.50/MCF IN JANUARY 2007 AND $7.01/MCF IN FEBRUARY 2007. THIS UNDETECTABLE LEAK RESULTED FROM A FAILED GIRTH WELD WHICH CREATED A NARROW CRACK-LIKE OPENING ON THE BOTTOM OF THE PIPE LOCATED IN A REMOTE AREA.  THE GAS ESCAPED INTO THE ATMOSPHERE THROUGH NUMEROUS SMALL HOLES AND CRACKS IN THE GROUND. THE PRESSURES MONITORED UP AND DOWN STREAM OF THE LEAK VIA THE SCADA SYSTEM ALSO DID NOT INDICATE THAT ANYTHING WAS ABNORMAL ON THAT LINE. THE LEAK REMAINED UNDETECTED UNTIL A VOLUNTEER FIREMAN NOTICED FROM HIS TRUCK TRAVELING ON A NEARBY HIGHWAY (WHEN ATMOSPHERIC CONDITIONS WERE RIGHT) A VISIBLE CONDENSATION IN THE CLEAR GASES ESCAPING FROM THE GROUND. THE COMPANY HAS INSTITUTED A NEW REAL-TIME MODELING APPLICATION TO ASSIST IN REVIEWING OVERALL PIPELINE EFFICIENCIES, INCLUDING RECEIPT AND DELIVERY VOLUMES AND PRESSURES WHICH SHOULD ASSIST IN BEING ABLE TO IDENTIFY SIMILAR SITUATIONS EARLIER."

THEY REPORTED THAT A VEHICLE HAD LEFT THE ROAD AND STRUCK A FARMTAP SETTING NORTH OF HIGHWAY 122/18 ON HICKORY AVENUE. THIS IS SECTION 5, TOWNSHIP 96N, RANGE 22W OF CERRO GORDO COUNTY. THE VEHICLE LEFT THE RAOD AND STRUCK THE FARM TAP SETTING, RESULTING IN BLOWING GAS TO ATMOSPHERE. THERE WAS NO INJURIES OR FIRE. THE CLEAR LAKE POLICE DEPARTMENT AND THE CERRO GORDO COUNTY SHERIFF'S DEPARTMENT RESPONDED TO THE   SITE. THE AREA IS NOT DENSELY POPULATED, HOWEVER PUBLIC OFFICIALS DID BLOCK OFF THE ROAD. NORTHERN PERSONNEL ISOLATED A PORTION OF THE LINE (IAB7002)AND BLEW THE PRESSURE DOWN TO ENABLE EXCAVATION AND REPAIR. UPON EXCAVATION IT WAS FOUND THAT THE UNDERGROUND PLUG VALVE WAS NOT DAMAGED. THE VALVE WAS CLOSED, A NEW ONE INCH PRESSURE TESTED RISER WAS INSTALLED.THE AREA WAS BACKFILLED, THE LINE WAS RE-PRESSURIZED, A NEW FARM TAP SETTING AND FENCE WAS INSTALLED, GAS SERVICE WAS RESTORED TO THE DAMAGED FARMTAP CUSTOMER (DAVID MCDEVITT). THERE WERE NO OTHER SERVICE INTERRUPTIONS. WEATHER CONDITIONS AT THE TIME WERE 2 DEGREES FARENHIT, WITH A WIND OF 2 MPH OUT OF THE NORTH/NORTHEAST. THE ROAD CONDITION WAS SNOW PACKED.  SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT. THE COST OF THE INCIDENT WAS UPDATED AS MORE ACCURATE FIGURES WERE OBTAINED. 9/18/2012 ADDED INCIDENT COORDINATES AS PER REQUEST OF JIM BUNN PHMSA."

BYRON H. WOOD	4023987396	BYRON.WOOD@NNGCO.COM	4023987606	"A TRUCK HAULING A LARGE VESSEL, TRAVELING ON HIGHWAY FM 119, WHICH GOES BY THE COMPRESSOR STATION, STRUCK THE ELECTRICAL POWER LINE, WHICH SUPPLIES ELECTRICAL POWER TO THE COMPRESSOR STATION, RESULTED IN A LOSE OF ELECTRICAL POWER TO THE STATION. THE SUCTION PRESSURE TO THE STATION, COMING FROM EL PASO AND CIG WAS CLOSE TO 500 PSIG. AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT THERE WAS ABOUT 354 MMCF OF GAS GOING THROUGH THE SUNRAY PLANT, 224 MMCF FROM CIG, 100 MMCF FROM EL PASO AND 30 MMCF FROM BP. THE POWER LOSE CAUSED ALL COMPRESSOR ENGINES TO SHUT DOWN. NORTHERN'S GAS CONTROL IMMEDIATELY NOTIFED ALL THREE CUSTOMERS (CIG, EL PASO AND BP)REQUESTING THEY REDUCE HORSEPOWER AND FLOW DELIVERIES UNTIL THE SUNRAY COMPRESSOR STATION COULD BE PLACED BACK IN SERVICE. THE TXM-15701 SUCTION PRESSURE VERY QUICKLY REACHED 572 PSIG, WHICH IS THE SET POINT OF THE RELIEF VALVE FOR THAT PIPELINE. THE RELIEF VALVE STAYED OPEN, BLOWING GAS TO ATMOSPHERE, FOR APPROXIMATELY 26 MINUTES UNTIL EL PASO AND CIG WERE ABLE TO REDUCE FLOW ENOUGH TO ALLOW IT TO CLOSE. ELECTRICAL POWER WAS RESTORED BY EXEL ENERGY AT 1327 AND THE SUNRAY COMPRESSOR UNITS WERE PUT BACK IN SERVICE. THE RELIEF VALVE FUNCTIONED PROPERLY. THE DOT, TCEQ AND NRC WERE NOTIFIED OF THE GAS RELEASE. A RSPA 7100.2 INCIDENT REPORT IS BEING FILED AS THE GAS LOSS WAS ESTIMATED AT 9,979 MCF AND BASED ON A $5.85 PER MCF THE VALUE OF THE GAS RELEASE EXCEEDED THE REQUIRED $50,000 REPORTING LIMIT.  A SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT IS BEING FILED TO CLARIFY THAT THE PART OF THE SYSTEM INVOLVED IN THE INCIDENT (RELIEF VALVE) IS CONSIDERED PIPELINE INSTEAD OF COMPRESSOR STATION.  SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT - NO FURTHER ACTIONS OR REQUIRED. THIS INCIDENT REPORT IS CONSIDERED COMPLETE AND CLOSED."

WOOD	4023987396	BYRON.WOOD@NNGCO.COM	4023987606	"ON MARCH 26, 2007 AT APPROXIMATELY 12:28 A.M. BLOWING GAS AND DUST WAS REPORTED BY A PASSERBY LOCATED IN SECTION 25, T27S, RANGE 19W IN KIOWA, COUNTY, KANSAS. IT WAS DETERMINED BY NORTHERN PERSONNEL THAT THE GAS LEAK WAS ON THE M670C KSM20603)PIPELINE. THE LINE WAS REMOVED FROM SERVICE AND THE LEAK AREA WAS INSPECTED WITH THE DETERMINATION THAT THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS A CRACK IN THE GIRTH WELD. ANALYSIS AND REPAIR OF THE PIPELINE IS IN PROGRESS. ADDITONAL INFORMATION AND FINDINGS FROM THE ANALYSIS AND REPAIRS WILL BE REPORTED IN SUPPLEMENTAL REPORTS.  SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT: PRELIMINARY MILE POST INDICATED WAS CORRECTED WITH MORE PRECISE MILE POST.    SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT: REPAIRS WERE MADE BY REPLACING APPROXIMATELY 40 FEET OF PIPE WITH NEW 26 INCH, .375, DSAW, API5L, X65 PIPE AND INSTALLATION OF A 26 INCH X 36 INCH PLIDCO SLEEVE. A FINAL COST OF REPAIR WAS CALCULATED AT $120,455. THE CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT WAS DUE TO A LACK OF FUSION IN THE ROOT PASS DURING CONSTRUCTION. THE LACK OF FUSION CRACKED INTO THE FILL PASSES AND EVENTUALLY PENETRATED THE CAP PASS TO BECOME A LEAK. THE ROOT CAUSE HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO MOSTLY LIKELY BE PIPE BENDING STRESSES ON THE PIPELINE CAUSING THE WELDS TO CONTINUE TO CRACK OVER A LONG PERIOD OF TIME. LONG TERM ADDITIONAL ACTIONS ARE BEING FOLLOWED THROUGH WITH HOWEVER THESE COST ARE CONSIDERED TO BE COST ASSOCIATED WITH THE LONG TERM INTEGRITY OF THE LINE AND NOT REPAIR COSTS.   SUPPLEMENT TO FINAL REPORT - THIS SUPPLEMENT IS SUBMITTED TO INDICATE THAT THE CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT WAS A WELD FAILURE ON A GIRTH WELD. LABORATORY ANALYSIS AND CONFIRMATION REVIEW BY P-PIC (A CONSULTANT) INDICATE THAT A CONTRIBUTING FACTOR WAS THE QUALITY OF THE WELD AS IT INDICATED INADEQUATE PENTETRATION IN THE ROOT PASS. WHY IT FAILED AFTER 50 PLUS YEARS IS STILL UNCERTAIN BUT NORTHERN IS INSTALLING SOME GROUND MOVEMENT MONITORING DEVICES TO DETERMINE IS THIS COULD BE A CONTRIBUTING FACTOR. 09/18/2012 ADDED INCIDENT COORDINATES AS PER REQUEST OF JIM BUNN, PHMSA"

ON MARCH 29, 2007 A LEAK ON THE SIOUX FALLS 14 INCH MAINLINE, APPROXIMATELY 20 MILES SOUTH OF HARRISBURG, SOUTH DAKOTA, WAS DISCOVERED BY A NORTHERN NATURAL GAS COMPANY EMPLOYEE. THE EMPLOYEE WAS CONDUCTING A LINE LOCATE WHEN HE NOTICED 5-6 BUBBLES IN A CREEK, IMMEDIATELY ABOVE NORTHERN'S PIPELINE. THIS IS SDM-90201 AT APPROXIMATE MILE POST 62.08, SECTION 2 TOWNSHIP 96N, RANGE 50W, LINCOLN COUNTY, S.D.. THE LINE WAS INSTALLED IN 1932 AND IS DRESSER COUPLED AND ACETYLENE WELDED AT DIFFERENT LOCATIONS. THE LINE HAS A 446 PSIG MAOP AND WAS OPERATING AT APPROXIMATELY 400 PSIG WHEN THE LEAK WAS DISCOVERED. THE AREAS IS A CLASS 1 LOCATION AND THIS IS NOT A SAFETY RELATED CONDITION. PRESSURE ON THE LINE WAS REDUCED AND IS BEING MAINTAINED AT 275 PSIG PENDING REPAIRS. THE AREA HAS RECEIVED APPROXIMATELY 3 1/2 INCHES OF RAIN AND HAS INCURRED SOME SNOW. A CONTRACTOR AND MATERIALS HAVE BEEN ASSEMBLED AND HOPE TO BE ABLE TO ACCESS THE AREA TO INVESTIGATE THE LEAK ON APRIL 4, WEATHER PERMITTING. THIS ORIGINAL INCIDENT REPORT IS BEING FILED AS COST ARE EXPECTED TO EXCEED THE $50,000 REPORTING THRESHOLD LEVEL. A FOLLOW UP SUPPLEMENTAL AND FINAL REPORT WILL BE FILED WITH UPDATED FINDINGS AS THEY BECOME KNOWN.  SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT:   REPAIRS WERE COMPLETED ON MAY 15, 2007 BY REPLACING APPROXIMATELY 444 FEET OF 14 INCH OUTSIDE DIAMETER X 0.375 WALL THICKNESS. THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE EXTERNAL CORROSION CAUSED BY LOCALIZED, GALVANIC CORROSION.TOTAL COST OF REPAIRS INCLUDING DAMAGES, LABOR, MATERIALS, ETC ARE $476,430.00. THIS INCIDENT IS CONSIDERED CLOSED WITH NO FURTHER ACTIONS PLANNED."

ALSO, THE ETC COMPRESSOR #1 AT OUR MAYPEARL COMPRESSOR STATION TRIPPED OFF-LINE.  THIS UNIT WAS BEING USED TO MOVE GAS FROM HANDLEY TO MAYPEARL; CONSEQUENTLY THIS CAUSED THE PIPELINE TO START BUILDING PRESSURE.  THE 9500 MERCER SAFETY RELIEF VALVE, LOCATED AT THE HANDLEY STATION OPERATED CORRECTLY AND RELIEVED GAS, AT 753 PSIG, TO THE ETC SILENCER/BLOWDOWN STACK LOCATED IN THE ETC HANDLEY METER STATION YARD.  THE GAS WAS EMITTED TO THE ATMOSPHERE.  THE GAS ENCOUNTERED AN UNEXPECTED IGNITION SOURCE AND IGNITED, CAUSING ENOUGH HEAT SOURCES TO MELT A POWER LINE THAT FELL TO THE GROUND.  AFTER A THOROUGH INVESTIGATION, IT IS BELIEVED THAT THERE WAS ARCHING AROUND THE AREA OF AN INSULATOR IN THE POWER LINE BEFORE THE RELEASE OF GAS, CAUSING THE GAS TO IGNITE.  THE ETC BLOWDOWN STACK IS DESIGNED TO SPECIFICALLY DISPERSE THE RELEASE OF GAS WITHOUT INCIDENT AND DESIGNED TO PREVENT THE POSSIBILITY OF IGNITION.      *  TOTAL TIME UNTIL AREA WAS MADE SAFE INCLUDED TIME FOR ELECTRICITY TO BE DISCONNECTED. GAS OFF AND FIRE OUT @ 7:55 AM      REPORTED TO TRRC @ 8:05 AM ON 4/23/07   REPORTED TO NRC @ 8:50 AM ON 4/23/07  (NRC 833123) OFFICER MALLICK    FINAL UPDATE: 01/04/2010  ADDITIONAL MEASURES TAKEN TO PREVENT SIMILIAR REOCCURRENCES:  1. RELOCATED RV DISTANCES AWAY FROM SIMILIAR POWER SOURCES, AS SECONDARY OPP.  2. INSTALLED INDIVIDUAL PRIMARY PRESSURE CONTROL DEVICES AT EACH PRODUCER TIE-IN (INLETS)THAT WILL SHUT-IN EACH PRODUCER, IF THE LINE PRESSURE APPROACHES MAOP."

PRIOR TO THE INCIDENT, TRANSCANADA HAD RECEIVED DIGGERS HOTLINE NOTIFICATIONS ON MAY 3 (TICKETS #20071818437 & #200711818449) WHEREBY TRANSCANADA REQUESTED A MEETING WITH THE LANDOWNER (C. SCHUMACHER)ON MAY 7 2007. THE ON-SITE DID OCCUR ON MAY 7, WHEREUPON THE PIPELINES & CATHODIC PROTECTION LEAD LINES WERE MARKED AND STAKED CONSISTENT WITH THE WINSCONSIN DIGGERS HOTLINE ONE-CALL TICKETS. TRANSCANADA EMPLOYEES WERE ON-SITE MAY 9  TO MONITOR THE INSTALLATION OF DRAIN TILE ACROSS THE CATHODIC PROTECTION LEAD LINES. TRANSCANADA EMPLOYEES WERE AGAIN ON-SITE MAY 18 2007 TO MONITOR THE INSTALLATION OF 4"" & 6"" DRAIN TILE ACROSS THE PIPELINES.    THE INCIDENT REPORT ADDRESSES THE LINE BREAK THAT OCCURED ON MAY 25 2007 AS INVESTIGATED BY PHMSA'S CARL GRIFFITH'S. ACCORDING TO LANDOWNER, ADDITIONAL DRAIN TILE WAS INSTALLED WITHOUT HAVING SUBMITTED A ONE-CALL, IN THE ADJACENT FIELD NORTH-NORTHEAST OF THE ORIGINALLY IDENTIFIED SITES ON MAY 19, 2007 WHICH RESULTED IN THE 10"" PIPELINE BEING IMPACTED & SUBSEQUENTLY FAILED."

THE REMAINING PRESSURE WAS BLOWN TO ATMOSPHERE, THE PIPELINE WAS DE-PRESSURIZED, AND REPAIRS COMMENCED ON 8 JUNE 2007. A SEVEN FOOT SEGMENT OF PIPE WAS REMOVED AND A NEW SEGMENT OF PRE-TESTED 24"" PIPE WAS INSTALLED TO ELIMINATE THE LEAK.  THE PIPELINE WAS PURGED OF AIR, PRESSURIZED, AND RETURNED TO SERVICE ON 11 JUNE 2007.    THE INCIDENT WAS REPORTED TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER AT 1543 HOURS ON 8 JUNE 2007 WHEN IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE TOTAL COST OF THE REPAIR WOULD EXCEED $50,000, PRIMARILY DUE TO THE VOLUME OF GAS BEING BLOWN TO ATMOSPHERE BETWEEN ADJACENT ISOLATING VALVES.    UPON EXCAVATING THE PIPELINE THE LEAK WAS FOUND ON AN OLD, PREVIOUS REPAIR CONSISTING OF A 2-INCH STEEL COUPLING WELDED OVER A LEAKING GIRTH WELD.  THE COUPLING AND PLUG HAD BEEN INSTALLED AT THE 12 O'CLOCK (TOP) POSITION OF THE PIPELINE OVER THE FIELD GIRTH WELD AND A LONGITUDINAL WELD SEAM OF THE PIPE.  THE COUPLING HAD BEEN PLUGGED WITH A TWO-INCH THREADED STEEL BULL PLUG WHERE THE THREADS HAD THEN BEEN SEALED BY WELDING.  LEAKAGE WAS OBSERVED AT THE WELDED THREADS BETWEEN THE COUPLING AND THE BULL PLUG."

WOOD	4023987396	BYRON.WOOD@NNGCO.COM	4023987606	"UNDERGROUND DEVELOPERS WAS INSTALLING A 24 INCH WATER LINE FOR THE CITY OF SIOUX FALLS, S.D. A ONE-CALL WAS MADE AND RECEIVED. A NORTHERN EMPLOYEE WAS ON SITE AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT WHICH OCCURRED DURING BACKFILLING AND COMPACTING OF DIRT ACTIVITIES. THE PIPELINE WAS STRUCK BY THE COMPACTION DEVICE AND SCRAPED, REMOVING COATING AND SLIGHTLY DENTED THE PIPE. ALL ACTIVITIES WERE STOPPED AND NOT KNOWING THE POTENTIAL EXTENT OF DAMAGE THE PIPELINE PRESSURE WAS REDUCED. THREE HOUSES WERE WITHIN THE CALCULATED POTENTIAL IMPACT RADIUS. ONE HOUSE WAS NEW CONSTRUCTION AND NOT OCCUPIED, A SECOND HOUSE RESIDENTS WERE GONE ON VACATION. A THIRD HOUSE WAS OCCUPIED AND AS A PROCEDURAL PRECAUTION THEY WERE EVACAUATED FROM THE HOUSE WITHT HE ASSISTANCE OF THE LOCAL PUBLIC OFFICIALS. THIS INCIDENT IS BEING REPORTED AS NORTHERN CONSIDERS THE NEED TO EVACUATE THREE PEOPLE FROM A RESIDENCE AS A ""SIGNIFICANT EVENT"". THE INCIDENT IS UNDER COMPANY INVESTIGATION AND ONCE THE ROOT CAUSE AND COST OF REPAIRS IS DETERMINED A SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT WILL BE SUBMITTED.   SUPPLEMENTAL SUBMITTED TO CORRECT DATE OF INCIDENT INSTEAD OF 8/1/07 THE ACTUAL DATE OF INCIDENT WAS 7/26/07.  SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT: A SEGMENT OF THE LINE WAS ISOLATED AND THE PRESSURE REDUCED TO A SAFE LEVEL TO ENABLE INSPECTION FOR ANY DAMAGE. A SMALL AREA WAS FOUND TO HAVE THE COATING DAMAGED AND SOME SCRATHING AND VERY SLIGHT DENTING. THE AREA WAS CHECKED WITH DYE PENTRATANT AND X-RAY'D FOR ANY CRACKS. NONE WERE FOUND. THE SCRATCHED AREA WAS SMOOTHED OUT AND THE PIPE WAS RE-COATED. THE PIPELINE WAS PUT BACK INTO NORMAL SERVICE OPERATION. THIS WAS COMPLETED ON JULY 27, 2007. A FINAL REPORT WILL BE SUBMITTED ON CALCULATION OF TOTAL COST OF REPAIR.  SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT - A TOTAL ESTIMATED COST OF $70,000 WAS CALCULATED TO COMPLETE REPAIRS.   SUPPLEMENTAL OF FINAL REPORT: THE FINAL REPORT IS BEING SUPPLEMENTED AS A FINAL COST OF REPAIRS HAS BEEN CALCULATED TO BE $71,884.00 INSTEAD OF THE PREVIOUSLY REPORTED $70,000. THE NEW FINAL COST INCLUDES OUTSIDE SERVICES PROVIDED BY MIDWEST INDUSTRIAL X-RAY WHICH PREVIOUSLY WERE NOT INCLUDED IN THE $70,000 ESTIMATE."

NORTHERN EMPLOYEES FROM THE ST. CLOUD, MN LOCATION RESPONDED. LOCAL POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENT PERSONNEL ASSISTED. IN WAS FINALLY DETERMINED THAT REDUCTION OF LINE PRESSURE ON THE 4"" SARTELL BRANCH LINE (MNB73101)WAS NECESSARY TO FACILITATE EXTINGUISHING THE FIRE. INTENSE HEAT FROM THE FIRE DETACHED THE FARMTAP METAL FENCING AND RESULTED IN EXTENSIVE DAMAGE TO METERS AND REGULATORS AT THE SETTING. A NEW RISER PIPE FROM THE UNDERGROUND SHUTOFF VALVE TO ABOVE GROUND WAS INSTALLED AS WELL AS NEW METERS AND REGULATORS. TWO CUSTOMERS LOST SERVICE WHILE THE SETTING REPAIRS WERE BEING COMPLETED. THERE WAS A FIRE, THERE WAS NO INJURIES. AN INTERNAL POST INCIDENT INVESTIGATION IS BEING CONDUCTED. IT IS NOT KNOWN AT THIS TIME WHETHER THE COST OF REPAIRS WILL EXCEED THE $50,000 REPORTING THRESHOLD BUT NORTHERN IS REPORTING THIS AS IT IS DEEMED AS A ""SIGNIFICANT EVENT"". SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORTS WILL BE FILED AS ADDITIONAL INFORMATION AND COST ARE CALCULATED.  SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT - A COST OF REPAIR HAS BEEN CALCULATED AND ENTERED FOR THIS INCIDENT. THE COST ESTIMATE IS LESS THAN THE $50,000 THRESHOLD FOR REPORTING. ALTHOUGH IT IS BELIEVED THAT THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT IS LIGHTNING A FINAL INTERNAL INVESTIGATION REPORT IS NOT COMPLETE AS OF YET. THIS REPORT WILL BE FINALIZED AND CLOSED UPON FINAL DETERMINATION OF CAUSE.  SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT - INVESTIGATION INTO THE CAUSE OF THE FARMTAP FIRE INDICATES THAT IT WAS CAUSED BY LIGHTNING. BYRON WOOD	4023987396	BYRON.WOOD@NNGCO.COM	4023987606	"ON AUGUST 10, 2007 NORTHERN NATURAL GAS COMPLETED NSTALLATION OF A 24-INCH PIGABLE BYPASS PIPING TO FACILITATE REMOVAL OF LATERAL LINES TO THE NORTHERN NATURAL GAS COMPRESSION PLATFORM MI 686 C-CMP. ALL WORK WAS COMPLETED AND THE PIPING WAS RE-PRESSURIZED AND LEAK TESTED. LATE THAT DAY PERSONNEL IN AIRCRAFT WITNESSED BUBBLES ON THE OCEAN SURFACE IN THE WORK AREA THAT WERE INDICATIVE OF A GAS LEAK FROM THE PIPING. PRODUCER PLATFORMS WERE NOTIFIED TO SHUT-IN AND THE LINE WAS ISOLATED. THIS WAS REPORTED TO MMS AND THE COAST GUARD. PRESSURE WAS REDUCED ON THE LINE. A REPAIR PLAN WAS SUBMITTED TO & APPROVED BY MMS. INVESTIGATION FOUND THAT THERE WAS A SMALL CRACK ON A 2-INCH BYPASS LINE THAT WENT AROUND A 24-INCH SUB SEA BLOCK VALVE. WHILE WORKING ON REPAIRING THIS LEAK BY REMOVING THE 2 INCH CONNECTION PIPING TO THE 24-INCH LINE AS WELL AS THE SADDLE TO FACILITATE INSTALLATION OF A 24-INCH LEAK CLAMP, IT WAS FOUND THAT THE 2-INCH CONNECTION ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE BLOCK VALVE WAS ALSO CRACKED. A REVISED REPAIR PLAN WAS SUBMITTED AND APPROVED BY MMS. THE REVISED PLAN CALLED FOR REMOVAL OF THE TWO INCH PIPE AND SADDLE IDENTICAL TO WHAT WAS COMPLETED ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE VALVE AND INSTALLATION OF A HIGH PRESSURE, FULL ENCIRCLEMENT, BOLT-ON LEAK CLAMP. BOTH LEAK CLAMPS WERE INSTALLED AND A LEAK TEST AT NORMAL OPERATING PRESSURE WAS CONDUCTED FOR 2 HOURS. THERE WERE NO LEAKS OBSERVED AND THE PIPING WAS WRAPPED AND SANDBAGGED TO ORIGINAL COVER. THIS WAS COMPLETED ON AUGUST 31, 2007. THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE LEAKS IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION AS IT IS THOUGHT THAT THE CONTRACTOR CRACKED THE PIPE WHEN INSTALLING SANDBAGS AFTER THE 24 INCH BYPASS LINE INSTALLATION WAS COMPLETE. A METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS IS BEING CONDUCTED ON THE 2-INCH REMOVED PIPING. A SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT IS BEING FILED WITH UPDATE TO THE COST OF GAS LOSS AND REPAIRS."

ON SEPTEMBER 4, 2007, NORTHERN NATURAL GAS COMPANY (NNG) RECEIVED NOTIFICATION OF A POSSIBLE LEAK IN THE WEST CAMERON, BLOCK 215 AREA. THIS IS THE 16-INCH, LOS11202, SEGMENT 5244 LINE WHICH BEGINS IN WEST CAMERON AREA BLOCK 222 AND CONTINUES TO A PLATFORM IN WEST CAMERON BLOCK 192. INITIAL REPORTS WERE THAT THERE WAS AN APPROXIMATE 6 FOOT AREA OF BUBBLES WITH NO VISIBLE SHEEN. NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE NRC TICKET #847779, THE MMS AND THE COAST GUARD. IMMEDIATE ACTIONS WERE TAKEN TO SHUT IN PRODUCTION AND ISOLATE THE LINE. A BLOW DOWN AND REPAIR PLAN WAS SUBMITTED TO THE MMS FOR REVIEW AND APPROVAL. APPROVAL WAS GRANTED. PRESSURE ON THE LINE WAS REDUCED TO APPROXIMATELY 35 PSIG. THE LEAK AREA WAS EXCAVATED, APPROXIMATELY 48 INCHES OF CONCRETE WAS REMOVED AND REPAIR OF THE LEAK ACCOMPLISHED BY INSTALLATION OF A 16 INCH X 18 INCH PLIDCO HIGH PRESSURE, FULL ENCIRCLEMENT BOLT ON LEAK CLAMP RATED AT 1,500 PSIG. FOLLOWING SUCCESSFUL INSTALLATION OF THE LEAK CLAMP THE LINE WAS BROUGHT BACK UP TO NORMAL OPERATING PRESSURE AND A TWO HOUR LEAK CONDUCTED.  THE PRESSURE TEST WAS COMPLETED AT 1 A.M. ON SEPTEMBER 19.   FOLLOWING VERIFICATION OF NO LEAKS FOR THE TWO HOUR TEST PERIOD THE LINE WAS PROPERLY WRAPPED AND COVER RE-ESTABLISHED BY SANDBAGGING. WHEN A FINAL COST OF REPAIRS IS CALCULATED A SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT WILL BE SUBMITTED.  SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT: CORRECTED THAT THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS LOCALIZED PITTING DUE TO MICROBIOLOGICAL.  SUPPLEMENTAL FINAL REPORT: THIS REPORT HAS BEEN REVISED TO REFLECT THAT CALCULATED COST OF REPAIR. CAUSE OF THE LEAK HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO BE ATTRIBUTED TO A LOCALIZED PIT WHICH WAS DUE TO MICROBIOLOGICAL INFLUENCED CORROSION (MIC). THIS REPORT IS CLOSED WITH NO FURTHER ACTIONS PENDING."

THE PIPELINE WAS A SECTION OF THE MAIN LINE BETWEEN THE COMPRESSOR STATION AND THE STORAGE FIELD.  THE LINE WAS BEING USED AS A STORAGE FIELD INJECTION LINE OPERATING AT 1,467 PSIG WHEN THE INCIDENT OCCURRED.  THE LINE RUPTURED, IGNITED AND WAS SHUT IN BY STORAGE FIELD PERSONNEL BY CLOSING SYSTEM VALVES.  THE SYSTEM WAS SHUT IN AND THE FIRE WAS EXTINGUISHED IN 27 MINUTES FROM THE TIME OF RUPTURE.     POOR SEAM QUALITY AND CORROSION WERE IDENTIFIED AS THE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE. SEAM DEFECTS, SEAM POSITION, EXPANSION AND CONTRACTION ASSICIATED WITH NORMAL OPERATING PRESSURES, AND CREVICE CORROSION WERE CONTRIBUTING FACTORS TO THE FAILURE.        THE TELEPHONIC REPORT WAS SUBMITTED ON OCTOBER 8, 2007 TO MR. SNOWDEN AND THE REPORT NUMBER WAS 851071. BYRON H. WOOD	4023987396	BYRON.WOOD@NNGCO.COM	4023987606	"ON NOVEMBER 3, 2007 @ APPROXIMATELY 8:51 A.M. THE TEXAS OCHILTREE COUNTY SHERIFF'S DEPARTMENT RECEIVED A 911 CALL REPORTING A FIRE AT NORTHERN'S PERRYTON-BARLOW FIELD COMPRESSOR STATION. NORTHEN WAS IMMEDIATELY NOTIFIED AN PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED. UPON ARRIVAL IT WAS CONFIRMED THAT THE GLYCOL DEHYDRATOR UNIT, LOCATED AT THE PERRYTON-BARLOW COMPRESSOR STATION WAS ON FIRE. AFTER ASSESSING THE SITUATION, AND TAKING INTO CONSIDERATION THE PROXIMITY OF THE FIRE TO THE EMERGENCY BLOW-DOWN PIPING, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE EMERGENCY SHUTDOWN SYSTEM FOR THE STATION COULD SAFELY BE ACTIVATED. THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT EXITINGUISHED THE FIRE. INVESTIGATION INTO THE INCIDENT FOUND THAT THE FIRE HAD OCCURRED ON THE DEHYDRATOR SKID WITH MOST OF THE DAMAGE CENTERED AT THE VARIABLE FREQUENCY DRIVE (VFD) FOR THE GLYCOL PUMPS, WHICH IS BELIEVED TO BE THE ORIGIN OF THE FIRE. IT APPEARS THE FIRE WAS FUELED BY HYDROCARBON CONDENSATE AND GLYCOL SPILLING OUT THE OVERFLOW VENT STACK, LOCATED ON THE DEHYDRATOR SKID, ONTO THE VFD CONTROLS FOR THE VFD. THE POSITIONING OF THE VFD AS IT RELATED TO THE OVERFLOW VENT STACK WAS A CONTRIBUTING FACTOR. ADDITIONAL INVESTIGATION INDICATES THAT AS SOME POINT THE GLYCOL RECIRCULATING PUMPS MUST HAVE STOPPED WORKING WHICH ALLOWED THE MIXTURE OF HYDROCARBON CONDENSTATE AND GLYCOL TO DRAIN BACK TO THE OVERFLOW TANK RESULTING IN A SPILL FROM THE OVERFLOW PIPING ONTO THE VFD CONTROLS. NORTHERN IS CURRENTLY WORKING WITH EQUIPMENT VENDORS TO ACQUIRE COST AND AVILABILITY OF REPLACING THE DEHYDRATOR UNIT. A CURRENT ESTIMATE OF REPLACEMENT IS ESTIMATED AT APPROXIMATELY $140,000.  SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT FILED TO INDICATE/CLARIFY PART A, ITEM G CLASS LOCATION DESCRIPTION IS: ONSHORE, CLASS 1.  SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT - A FINAL COST OF $152,907 HAS BEEN DETERMINED TO REPLACE THE DAMAGED DEHY UNIT AND THE ASSOCIATED ELECTRICAL AND CONTROL PANELS. THIS ITEM IS CONSIDERED CLOSED WITH NO FURTHER ACTIONS PLANNED."

GAS WAS BLOWING FROM THE DAMAGED PIPELINE. IT WAS DETERMINED THAT IT WAS THE 6 INCH BROOKINGS BRANCHLINE, SDB91901. PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO THE SITE. THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT EVACUATED APPROXIMATELY 20 PEOPLE WITHIN 1,000 FEET OF THE LINE HIT. THE LINE WAS ISOLATED AND BLOWN DOWN. AN APPROXIMATE 3 TO 4 INCH PUNCTURE AND A DENT WAS FOUND. A 10 FOOT SECTION OF PIPE HAD TO BE REPLACED. THERE WAS BLOWING GAS BUT NO FIRE AND NO INJURIES. THERE WAS NO LOSS OF SERVICE TO ANY TOWNS. THE EXCAVATION CONTRACTOR HAD MADE A 1 CALL TO THE SOUTH DAKOTA ONE CALL CENTER ON 11/6/07. IT STATED THAT WORK WAS SCHEDULED TO COMMENCE ON 11/08/07 AT APPROXIMATELY 10:37 A.M.. NORTHERN PERSONNEL WERE SCHEDULED TO LOCATE THE LINE THE MORNING OF 11/8/07. THE CONTRACTOR DID NOT WAIT THE REQUIRED 48 HOURS AND INSTEAD COMMENCED CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES ON 11/7/07, ONE DAY PRIOR TO THE DAY AND TIME REQUESTED FOR LOCATION OF THE LINE.THERE WERE PERMANENT PIPELINE MARKER SIGNS IN THE AREA OF THE PIPELINE. THE EXCAVTOR WAS PREPARING A ROAD BED AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT. HE REMOVED APPROXIMATELY 30 INCHES OF COVER FROM OVER THE PIPELINE THAT ORIGINALLY HAD APPROXIMATELY 42 INCHES OF COVER. HE WAS IN THE PROCESS OF UTILIZING A ""RIPPER"" TO MIX THE WET SOIL THAT WAS IN THE AREA OF THE PIPELINE TO PROVIDE DRAINAGE FOR THE ROAD THEY WERE INSTALLING WHEN THE RIPPER TEETH STUCK AND PUNCTURED THE PIPELINE. NORTHERN FOLLOWED UP WITH MEETINGS WITH THE CONTRACTOR ON EXCAVATION SAFETY AND WILL BE FOLLOWING UP WITH NOTIFICATION OF A VIOLATION OF THE SOUTH DAKOTA STATE ONE CALL. A SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT WILL BE FILED WHEN FINAL COST OF GAS LOSS AND DAMAGE IS DETERMINED. IT IS EXPECTED THAT THE COST WILL EXCEED THE $50K REPORTING THRESHOLD.  SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT - A TOTAL COST OF REPAIR FOR THIS LINE DAMAGE HAS BEEN CALCULATED AT $45,135.00. ALL THOUGHT THE FINAL COST IS LESS THAN THE $50,000 REPORTING THRESHOLD THIS INCIDENT WAS/IS STILL REPORTABLE AS THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT CONDUCTED PRECAUTIONARY EVACUATION OF APPROXIMATELY 20 PEOPLE WITH APPROXIMATELY 1,000 FEET OF THE LINE HIT SITE.   SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT - THIS REPORT IS BEINGING UPDATED TO REFLECT THE FINAL SUMMARY OF THIS INCIDENTS COSTS WHICH HAS BEEN CALCULATED AS $48,015.00."

BYRD MANAGER NORTHERN AREA	3186195662	WILLIAM.BYRD@CROSSTEXENERGY.COM	3186195719	"ON OCTOBER 30, 2007, AT 0927 HOURS, CROSSTEX LIG, L.L.C. (CROSSTEX), A SUBSIDIARY OF CROSSTEX ENERGY SERVICES, L.P. REPORTED A NATURAL GAS AND CONDENSATE RELEASE FROM THEIR 6-INCH UNDERGROUND TRANSMISSION PIPELINE IN DE SOTO PARISH, LOUISIANA. THE RELEASE WAS CAUSED BY A  BACKHOE STRIKING AND DAMAGING THE PIPELINE DURING EXCAVATION. CROSSTEX REPORTED THE UNAUTHORIZED RELEASE TO THE LOUISIANA EMERGENCY HAZARDOUS MATERIALS HOTLINE (INCIDENT NO. 07-06604), AND THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER (NRC) WAS ALSO NOTIFIED OF THE EVENT (INCIDENT NO. 853067).    AFTER THE INITIAL EMERGENCY RESPONSE, IT WAS DETERMINED DURING THE INVESTIGATION THAT THE CAUSE OF THE RELEASE AND SUBSEQUENT CONDENSATE SPILL WAS FROM AN UNIDENTIFIED TAP VALVE THAT WAS INADVERTENTLY BROKEN OFF BY A CONTRACTOR UTILIZING EXCAVATION EQUIPMENT DURING CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES, CREATING AN APPROXIMATE 2-INCH HOLE IN THE PIPELINE. CROSSTEX PERSONNEL WERE PREVIOUSLY UNAWARE OF THE PRESENCE OF SUCH TAP VALVE AS IT WAS NOT INDICATED ON FACILITY DRAWINGS. CROSSTEX PERSONNEL ON THE SCENE OF THE INCIDENT QUICKLY ISOLATED THE AFFECTED PIPELINE SEGMENT, AND CAREFULLY EXCAVATED AROUND THE DAMAGED TAP VALVE GAINING ACCESS TO THE DAMAGED PORTION OF THE PIPELINE. REPAIRS TO THE PIPELINE AND PURGING ACTIVITIES WERE FINALIZED BY 1645 HOURS AND GAS SERVICE TO THE TOWN OF LOGANSPORT WAS RESTORED BY 1750 HOURS THE DAY OF THE INCIDENT.    THERE WAS ONE INJURY ASSOCIATED WITH INCIDENT WHICH OCCURRED WHEN THE CONTRACT BACKHOE OPERATOR EXITED THE EXCAVATOR AND TWISTED HIS KNEE. HE WAS TAKEN TO A LOCAL HOSPITAL FOR A DOCTOR'S EXAMINATION AND WAS RELEASED THE SAME DAY. HOWEVER IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT ADDITIONAL TREATMENT WILL BE REQUIRED DUE THE NATURE OF THE INJURY.    200 MCF (THOUSAND CUBIC FEET)OR APPROXIMATELY 9,341 POUNDS OF SWEET NATURAL GAS AND LESS THAN TWO (2) BARRELS OF CONDENSATE WERE RELEASED. A CLEANUP CREW TRAINED IN EMERGENCY RESPONSE WAS SUMMONED BY CROSSTEX TO REMOVE SOILS IMPACTED BY CONDENSATE. THE EXCAVATED MATERIALS WERE PROPERLY STORED IN THE COVERED ROLL-OFF BINS PENDING TRANSPORTATION TO AN OFF-SITE LOCATION FOR PROPER DISPOSAL. SUBSEQUENT TO THE CLEANUP ACTIVITIES, A NUMBER OF CONFIRMATORY SOIL SAMPLES ARE SCHEDULED FOR COLLECTION BY 11/09/07. UPON RECEIPT OF THE ANALYTICAL DATA DEOMONSTRATING NO PRESENCE OF CONDENSATE IN THE AFFECTED AREA, CLEAN FILL WILL BE PLACED OVER THE EXCAVATED AREA."

THE PIPE INSPECTION SHOWED COATING DAMAGE TO THE TOP OF THE PIPE AND CORROSION PITTING AT THE 12 OCLOCK POSITION.  IT WAS ESTIMATED THAT THE DAMAGE TO THE COATING MAY HAVE TAKEN PLACE IN SUMMER 2003 WHEN THE CORP OF ENGINEER HAD A BARAGE IN THE AREA DOING WORK.  BOTH LEAKS WERE REPAIRED WITH BOLT-ON CLAMPS AND THE LINE RETURN TO NORMAL SERVICE ON JANUARY 8, 2008."

EAST BUILDING2ND FLOOR (PHP-10) ROOM E22-321WASHINGTON D.C. 20590RE: INCIDENT REPORT #861109, CONSUMERS ENERGY ATTACHMENT TO RSPA FORM F7100.0 AND F7100.2 INCIDENT REPORTSTHIS NARRATIVE PROVIDE AS PER INSTRUCTION FOR PART G OF THE ABOVE REFERENCE FORMS.OVER PRESSURES OF MINGO/HARVESTER GAS TRANSMISSION AND DISTRBUTION SYSTEMSON JANUARY 31, 2008 AT 1215AM AN OVER PRESSURE ALARM, FROM THE ELECTRONIC METERING, WAS RECEIVED BY NORTHERN NATURAL GAS AND CALLED TO CONSUMER ENERGY FROM OUR MINGO TBS, LOCATED AT 12359 NORTH 59TH AVENUE WEST MINGO, IOWA 50168. CONSUMERS ENERGY PERSONNEL RESPONDED AND FOUND THAT TWO EZR REGULATORS IN A WORKER MONITOR CONFIGURATION HAD FAILED IN THE OPEN POSITION AND THE PRESSURE TO BE 475PSI.AT 1:15AM. THIS TBS FEEDS 6 INCH PE PIPE 3408 SDR 11 PIPE WITH AN MAOP OF 100PSI.CONSUMER'S PERSONNEL SHUT DOWN THE REGULATOR STATION AND BEGAN TO VENT THE GAS. AFTER VENTING WAS STARTED A SECOND CREW WAS CALLED TO CHECK OUR REGULATOR STATION AT THE HARVESTER DEVELOPMENT, LOCATED NEAR THE CORNER OF W100TH STREET NORTH AND HIGHWAY 330. THE PRESSURE AT THIS STATION HAD PEGGED THE PRESSURE GAGE AT 16PSI. CREW 2 BEGAN VENTING GAS FROM THE DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM AT 2AM. THIS SYSTEM CONSISTS OF 4 INCH, 2 INCH, AND 1 INCH PE PIPE3408 SDR 11 WITH AN MAOP OF 60PSI. DURING VENTING HOUSE REGULATORS WERE CHECKED TO SEE IF ANY WERE VENTING AND AL REGULATORS APPEARED NORMAL.CREW 3 WAS DISPATCHED AT 6:30AM AND BEGAN VENTING GAS AT A FARM TAP CENTRALLY LOCATED ALONG THE TRANSMISSION LINE.CRE 4 ARRIVED AT 8AM AND BEGAN VENTING GAS AT THE DISTRIBUTION TBS AT HARVESTER. GAGES THAT HAD BEEN PEGGED WERE CHANGED.WITH THE PRESSURE IN THE TRANSMISSION SYSTEM AT 300PSI CONSUMERS CHECKED ALL FARM TAP METERS DOWN STREAM SIDES AND FOUND PRESSURES TO THE HOUSES TO BE NORMAL. SPOT CHECKS WERE TAKEN ON THE DOWN STREAM SIDE OF METERS ON OUR DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM AND ALL CHECKS WERE NORMAL FOR PRESSURE GOING INTO HOUSES.WHEN PRESSURE REACHED 75PSI AT THE TBS AT HARVESTER THE STATION WAS LOCKED IN AND LIKE PACK WAS USED TO FEED THE CONSUMERS.3PM PRESSURE WAS DOWN TO 100PSI AT THIS TIME A SHUT IN TEST WAS PERFORMED ON THE TRANSMISSION SYSTEM FOR ONE HOUR WITH NO LOSS OF PRESSURE DURING THAT HOUR. GAS WAS TURNED BACK ON AND SHUT IN TEST WERE PERFORMED ON THE HOUSES.4PM PRESSURE WAS RESTORED TO HARVESTER TBS AND REGULATORS CHECKED. GASKETS WERE DAMAGED ON ONE SIDE OF THE DUAL FEED WORKER MONITOR SYSTEMS FISHER 299H REGULATORS. THIS SIDE WAS LOCKED OUT AND THE SYSTEM WAS OPERATED OFF OF THE ALTERNATE SIDE.5PM MINGO TBS CREWS RESTORED HIGH PRESSURE FEED TO MINGO STATION LEAVING MALFUNCTIONING REGULATORS LOCKED OUT. CREWS CHECKED FUNCTION OF FISHER EZR REGULATORS ON OPPOSITE SIDE OF DUAL RUN AND IT WAS DECIDED THAT REGULATORS ON THE OPPOSITE SIDE WOULD ALSO BE LOCKED OUT AND THAT A FISHER 627 THAT FEEDS THE VORTEX HEATER WOULD FEED SYSTEM FOR THE NIGHT.FEBRUARY 1, 2008 AN INFRARED LEAK SURVEY WAS PERFORMED BY IOWA ASSOCIATION OF MUNICIPAL UTILITIES. THESE SURVEYS ARE PLANNED TO BE CONDUCTED MONTHLY FOR A MINIMUM OF THE NEXT 90 TO 120 DAYS.REGULATORS AT HARVESTER TBS WERE REPAIRED. EZR REGULATORS AT MINGO WERE ALSO TAKEN APART FOR REPAIR. THERE WAS A LARGE AMOUNT OF FOREIGN MATTER IN THE REGULATORS. DIAPHRAGMS APPEARED INTACT BUT WERE REPLACED.CONTACT WAS MAD WITH EAGLE PIPE, MANUFACTURES OF 3408 SDR 11 PIPE. MINIMUM BURST FOR THIS PIPE IS 504 PSI. EAGLE INFORMED CONSUMERS THAT THE PIPE REGAINS ITS STRENGTH WHEN EXCESSIVE PRESSURE IS RELIEVED FROM THE PIPE AND PIPE IS OPERATED AT NORMAL PRESSURES. EAGLE DECLINED TO PUT THIS IN WRITING.FEBRUARY 2, 2008 CONSUMERS PERFORMED A SHUT IN TEST ON OUR DISTRIBUTION SYSTEM FOR ONE HOUR. STARTING AND ENDING PRESSURES WAS 19.2PSI.AT THIS TIME CONSUMER PLANS TO ADD RELIEF TO OUR MINGO STATION AND CHANGE REGULATORS AND CONTINUE INFRARED LEAK SURVEYS."

IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE PITS WERE THE RESULT OF INTERNAL CORROSION CAUSED BY ELECTROCHEMICAL ACTIVITY."

"			JOHNNY CAVITT	3184293606	JOHNNY.CAVITT@CENTERPOINTENERGY.COM	3184293927	"2/27/08-5:30PM, FOUND LEAK IN PASTURE IN CLASS 1 LOCATION AT STATION 750+43, OF UNKNOWN CAUSE ON JM-30 BY LOCATING ODORIZED GAS SMELL.  THERE WAS NO SOUND OF GAS ESCAPING OR HOLE IN THE GROUND OR VISIBLE INDICATIONS OF A SEVERE LEAK.  MONITORED LEAK THROUGH OUT THE NIGHT BY MANNING SITE WITH EMPLOYEES TO PROVIDE PUBLIC SAFETY.    2/28/08  7:30AM, DISPATCHED PERSONNEL TO BLOCKGATES AT EACH END OF SECTION AND BEGIN LOWERING PRESSURE FROM 950 #S TO EQUALIZE WITH SOUTHERN SECTION OF JM-30 AT 500 #S BEFORE DIGGING.  ISOLATED SECTION AND BEGAN FEEDING SOUTHERN END OF JM-30 WITH ALTERNATE PIPELINE BT-14.  ONCE PRESSURE WAS AT 500 #S WE BEGAN DIGGING UP LOCATION OF LEAK TO DETERMINE CAUSE AND EXTENT OF LEAK.  WHEN PIPE WAS EXPOSED WE FOUND A LONGITUDAL CRACK OF APPROX. 1 INCH.  AT THAT TIME WE LOWERED SAID SECTION DOWN TO 320#S BY BLOWING GAS TO THE ATMOSPHERE.  FROM THAT TIME FORWARD WE BEGAN PROCESS OF REPLACING SECTION OF PIPE WITH CRACK.  WE CONTINUED TO MONITOR THE LEAK SITE ON A 24HR SHIFT, WE MANNED THE BLOCK VALVES AT EACH END ON 24 HR SHIFT AND MANUALLY FED THAT SECTION TO KEEP AT 320 #S AND MAINTAIN CUSTOMERS.  2/29/08 7:30AM, WE PROCCURED FITTINGS AND BEGAN INSTALLING STOPPLE FITTINGS ON EACH SIDE OF SECTION OF PIPE LEAKING.  CONTINUED MONITORING EFFORTS ON 24 HR SHIFT AT BLOCKGATES AND LEAK SITE.  3/01/08-7:30AM, BEGAN UTILIZING STOPPLE EQUIPMENT TO ISOLATE LEAKING SECTION OF PIPE FOR REPLACEMENT SAME DAY.  LATE EVENING HOURS APPROX 20:00 HRS WE WILL PUT PIPELINE BACK IN SERVICE,  WILL UPDATE THIS REPORT WITH ACTUAL TIME OF INSERVICE ON SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT.    WE ARE SENDING 6 FT OF LEAKING SECTION WITH CRACK TO: KEIFNER AND ASSOCIATES, INC.  MATERIALS TEST FACILITY, 6384 PROPRIETORS RD., WORTHINGTON, OHIO,  43085.  PHONE # 614-888-8275, THEY WILL HELP US IDENTIFY THE TRUE CAUSE OF THIS LEAK.    THE METALLURGICAL REPORT FROM KIEFNER & ASSOCIATES CONCLUDED THAT THE CAUSE FOR THIS LEAK WAS DUE TO A COMBINATION OF TWO THINGS.  ONE, THE PIPE EXHIBITED A PROMINENT LAYER OF CONTAMINATION AT THE CENTER OF THE WALL THICKNESS, CAUSED BY THE SELL MANUFACTURING PROCESS. SECOND, HIGH STRESSES (DUCTILE OVERLOAD) OCCURRED IN THE SEPARATED LIGAMENTS OF THE PIPE WHERE HYDROGEN BLISTERS FORMED.  THE SOURCE OF THE HYDROGEN IS SUSPECTED TO BE FROM THE CATHODIC PROTECTION SYSTEM.    A COPY OF THE REPORT WAS SENT TO OPS."

PETERS	2053257554	KEN.PETERS@ELPASO.COM	2053253729	"A THIRD PARTY NOTICED HOLE IN GROUND AND HISSING SOUND IN THE VICINITY OF SOUTHERN NATURAL GAS (SNG) COMPANY'S 18"" SOUTH MAIN PIPELINE.  HE REPORTED THIS TO SNG AND COMPANY PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO THE SITE.  UPON ISOLATION AND BLOWDOWN OF THE VALVE SECTION, THE LINE WAS EXCAVATED AND A CRACK IN THE CIRCUMFERENTIAL WELD OR WELD AREA WAS FOUND TO BE THE SOURCE OF THE LEAKING GAS.  METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS REVEALED POORLY COMPLETED WELDING DURING THE ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION THAT FAILED DUE TO TENSILE STRESSES ALONG THE PIPE IN A LONGITUDINAL DIRECTION.  FURTHER INVESTIGATION SHOWED THAT THE BACKFILL SURROUNDING THE PIPELINE HAD BEEN DISTURBED FOR CONSTRUCTION ON A PARALLEL PIPELINE.  THE FAILED PIPELINE MAY NOT HAVE BEEN ADEQUATELY SUPPORTED BEFORE ITS COVER WAS RESTORED, RESULTING IN THE EXTRA TENSILE STRESSES.  ABOUT 80 FEET OF PIPE WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED WITH NEW PIPE.  THE PIPELINE SEGMENT IS BACK IN SERVICE."

GRAY JR.	9858578002	NGRAY@EPROD.COM	9858579797	"GAS BUBBLES WERE DETECTED AT THE SURFACE OF MC 920.  AFTER INVESTIGATION, IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE FLEX JOINT SEAL RING WAS LEAKING.  PIPELINE WAS SECURED AND REPAIR PROCEDURES HAVE BEEN IMPLEMENTED AND WORK IS ONGOING.    THE OFFSHORE REPLACEMENT OPERATION OF THE 20 FLEX-JOINT O-RING WAS PERFORMED IN THREE (3) PHASES:     PHASE I, DETAILED INSPECTION AND INITIAL BOLT TIGHTENING APRIL 9, TO APRIL 23, 2008   PHASE II, FLEX-JOINT O-RING REPLACEMENT APRIL 24, TO JUNE 16, 2008   PHASE III, FINAL BOLT TIGHTENING, UT VERIFICATION, TESTING JULY 28, TO AUGUST 8, 2008      ENTERPRISE CONFIRMS THE 20 INCH FLEX-JOINT O-RING REMEDIATION WAS SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE WORK PLAN, AND ON AUGUST 9, 2008 NORMAL PRODUCTION WAS RESUMED IN THE GAS EXPORT PIPELINE. FOR THE POST INSPECTION PERIOD, AUGUST 8, TO SEPT 8, 2008, REMOTE CAMERAS WERE USED TO MONITOR THE FLEX-JOINT.     ENTERPRISE AND OIL STATES HAVE WORKED CLOSELY TO ANALYZE AND EVALUATE BOTH HISTORIC AND PROJECT DATA ON THE FLEX-JOINT AND INCIDENT TO BEST DETERMINE THE DIRECT CAUSE OF THE LEAK.      THERE WAS NO IDENTIFIED SINGLE ITEM OR CLEAR DIRECT CAUSE FOR THE LEAK.  HOWEVER, THE EVALUATION AND ANALYSIS POINTS TO A SERIES OF EVENTS THAT TOGETHER MOST LIKELY CONTRIBUTED TO THE CAUSE OF THE LEAK.  THE FACTORS IDENTIFIED INCLUDED POSSIBLE INCORRECT ATTACH FLANGE BOLT TORQUE VALUE READINGS DURING THE FINAL MANUFACTURING SHOP ASSEMBLY, WHICH COULD ALLOW EXCESS ATTACH FLANGE DEFLECTION, AND SLIGHT BOLT RELAXATION DURING HYDROTESTING.  THE O-RING DESIGN, DIMENSION, AND DISSIMILAR MATERIALS WERE ALSO A FACTOR.  AFTER OFFSHORE INSTALLATION OF THE FLEX-JOINT AND DURING PIPELINE OPERATIONS, FRETTING BEGAN TO TAKE PLACE WITHIN THE O-RING SEAL SYSTEM.  THIS DEVELOPMENT THEN LED TO THE PROGRESSION OF MINOR CORROSION, AND INDUCTION OF SEA WATER, WHICH AFTER A PERIOD OF TIME PROGRESSED UNTIL THE LEAK STARTED.    DURING THE OFFSHORE REPAIR PHASES, CORRECTIVE ACTIONS WERE IMPLEMENTED TO ADDRESS EACH OF THE POTENTIAL CAUSES, WHICH INCLUDED A NEWLY DESIGNED LARGER O-RING WHICH IS NOW THE SAME MATERIAL AS THE ATTACH FLANGE, AND ACCURATE BOLT TORQUING MEASURED AND VERIFIED BY UT STUD ELONGATION PROCESS.  THIS UT PROCESS ELIMINATES ANY UNKNOWN FRICTION FACTORS WHICH AFFECT BOLT TORQUE VALUES."

WOOD	4023987396	BYRON.WOOD@NNGCO.COM	4023987606	"ON MAY 18, 2008, AT APPROXIMATELY 5:30 P.M., NORTHERN'S OPERATIONS COMMUNICATION CENTER (OCC), RECEIVED A CALL FROM DANA ELIKER, A TECHNICIAN WITH AQUILA, REPORTING THAT THERE WAS A LEAK ON NORTHERN'S TWO-INCH CLATONIA, NE BRANCH LINE (NEB42201)IN A CORNFIELD APPROXIMATELY 1/4 MILE NORTHWEST OF THE TOWN OF CLATONIA, NE. THE LEAK SITE IS LOCATED IN SECTION 21, TOWNSHIP 6N, RANGE 5E, GAGE COUNTY, NE. NORTHERN PERSONNEL UTILIZED A BOTTLE TRUCK AT THE CLATONIA TOWN BORDER STATION TO PROVIDE GAS SERVICE TO THE TOWN WHILE THE BRANCH LINE WAS SHUT OFF FROM THE TAKE OFF TO THE TBS TO SAFELY ASSESS AND REPAIR THE LINE. THIS LINE'S CONSTRUCTION INCLUDES DRESSER COUPLING, ELECTRIC WELDS AND SCREWED COUPLINGS. UPON ASSESSMENT, IT WAS FOUND THAT THE THREADS ON THE PIPE GOING INTO A TWO-INCH SCREWED COUPLING HAD FAILED RESULTING IN LEAKING GAS. LINE PRESSURE WAS REDUCED TO ZERO AND REPAIRS WERE MADE BY CUTTING OUT THE FAILED COUPLING ALONG WITH SMALL PIECES OF THE LINE, ON EACH SIDE OF THE COUPLING, AND INSTALLING APPROXIMATELY 10 FEET OF NEW, TESTED TWO-INCH, .218 WALL THICKNESS PIPE. PRESSURE WAS RESTORED TO 100 PSIG AND THE COMPLETE 1.26 MILES OF LINE WAS INSTRUMENT LEAK DETECTED. THE PRESSURE WAS THEN INCREASED TO NORMAL OPERATING PRESSURE AND THE FULL LENGTH OF THE LINE WAS AGAIN INSTRUMENT LEAK DETECTED. UPON SUCCESSFUL LOADING OF THE LINE TO NORMAL PRESSURE AND NO LEAKS DISCOVERED NORMAL GAS SERVICE WAS RESTORED TO THE TOWN BORDER STATION OF CLATONIA. THE SMALL PIECES OF PIPE AND THE FAILED COUPLING ARE BEING SENT TO A LABORATORY FOR FAILURE ANALYSIS TO ASSIST WITH DETERMINING THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE FAILURE. THERE WAS NO FIRE, NO INJURIES AND NO LOSS OF SERVICE AS THERE ARE NO FARM TAP CUSTOMERS ON THE LINE AND THE CLATONIA TOWN BORDER STATION SERVICE WAS MAINTAINED WITH A BOTTLE TRUCK. THIS REPORT IS BEING FILED AS IT IS EXPECTED THAT REPAIRS, INCLUDING GAS LOSS, WILL EXCEED THE $50,000 REPORTING THRESHOLD.  SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT - TOTAL FINAL COST OF REPAIRS, INCLUDING GAS LOSS, ETC IS $283,192. BASED UPON A OUTSIDE SERVICES FAILURE ANALYSIS LABORATORY REPORT, THE ROOT CAUSE OF THIS FAILURE IS BELEIVED TO BE FRACTURING OF THE PIPE BY CLEAVAGE (A FORM OF BRITTLE CRACKING) ORIGINATING IN THE THREAD ROOT IMMEDIATELY ADJACENT TO THE CONNECTION COUPLING. THIS EVENT IS CONSIDERED CLOSED WITH NO FURTHER ACTIONS PENDING OR PLANNED. NORTHERN IS SCHEDULUED ADDITION PRECUATIONARY EQUIPMENT LEAK TESTING OF OTHER SMALL DIAMTER PIPELINES OF THIS SAME VINATAGE AND CONSTRUCTION TO ENABLE EARLY DETECTION OF LEAK SHOULD A SIMILAR CONDITION OCCUR ON ANY OF THESE FACILITIES. ADDED INCIDENT COORDINATES PER REQUEST OF JIM BUNN, PHMSA."

WOOD	4023987396	BYRON.WOOD@NNGCO.COM	4023987606	"ON MAY 25, AT APPROXIMATELY 0630 A.M., NORTHERN'S OCC RECEIVED A CALL FROM THE SIBLEY COUNTY SHERIFF REPORTING THAT A PASSER-BY HAD REPORTED GAS BLOWING IN A FIELD NEAR GAYLORD, MN. OPERATIONS PERSONNEL RESPONDED TO THE SITE AND CONFIRMED A LEAK ON THE MNB69801, 3-INCH WINTHROP, MN BRANCH LINE. LINE PRESSURE AT THE TIME WAS APPROXIMATELY 800 PSIG. PRESSURE WAS LOWERED TO 350 PSIG. BOTTLE TRUCKS AND STOPPLE PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO THE SITE. STOPPLE FITTINGS WERE WELDING ON BY APPROXIMATELY 10 P.M. ON MAY 26 THE BOTTLE TRUCKS WERE CONNECTED TO SUPPLY GAS TO THE TOWN OF WINTHROP, MN TBS # 1. THE STOPPLE WAS SET IN PLACE AND APPROXIMATELY 4 MILES OF 3-INCH BRANCH LINE WERE BLOWN DOWN TO ZERO PRESSURE. THE LEAK SITE WAS EXCAVATED TO EXPOSE THE PIPELINE. THE LINE WAS FOUND TO BE DENTED AND LEAKING, APPARENTLY AS A RESULT OF BEING HIT BY A TILING MACHINE. A 30 FOOT SEGMENT OF PIPE WAS REPLACED WITH NEW, TESTED PIPE. DUE TO THE COATING APPEARING TO BE DISBONDED AND CRACKED A MAGNETIC PARTICLE INSPECTION WAS CONDUCTED ON AREAS OF THE PIPE. A FOUR FOOT PIECE OF THE PIPE WAS REMOVED AND TRANSPORTED TO A LABORATORY FOR ANALYSIS. THE REPAIRED, DAMAGED AREA WAS RE-COATED AND BACK FILLED. THE LINE WAS PURGED AND PRESSURE WAS RESTORED TO THE LINE TO BE MAINTAINED, NOT TO EXCEED 699 PSIG, PENDING RETURN OF LAB ANALYSIS AND FINALIZATION OF INVESTIGATION OF THE INCIDENT. AN INTERNAL POST INCIDENT INVESTIGATION IS BEING CONDUCTED. AN NRC REPORT WAS FILED AND THIS 7100 REPORT IS BEING FILED AS THIS IS CONSIDERED AS A SIGNIFICANT EVENT AND IT IS LIKELY THAT COST OF REPAIRS WILL EXCEED THE $50K REPORTING THRESHOLD. ADDITIONAL SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORTS WILL BE FILED REGARDING LAB ANALYSIS AND FINAL CALCULATION OF TOTAL COST OF REPAIR.  SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT: AN INVESTIGATION INDICATES THAT THE ROOT CAUSE OF THIS EVENT WAS THAT THE LANDOWNER INTALLED DRAINAGE TILE, WITHOUT MAKING A ONE CALL REQUEST, SOMETIME DURING 2006, AND IN THE PROCESS THE PIPLINE WAS STRUCK. THE COATING AND PIPE WAS DAMAGED WHICH RESULTED IN THE GAS LEAK. AN APPROXIMATE 30 FEET OF NEW, TESTED, COATED PIPE WAS INSTALLED TO COMPLETE THE REPAIRS. LABORATORY ANALYSIS WAS COMPLETED AND NO OTHER FACTORS WERE FOUND TO HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO THE LEAK BEYOND THE DAMAGED SUSTAINED DURING THE DRAINAGE TILE INSTALLATION IN 2006. THIS INCIDENT IS CONSIDERED CLOSED WITH NO FURTHER ACTIONS PLANNED OR PENDING. CIRCUMSTANCES/PARTICULARS OF THE INCIDENT AND COST HAVE BEEN TURNED OVER TO NORTHERN'S LEGAL DEPARTMENT FOR APPROPRIATE FOLLOW-UP ACTIONS.  09/18/2012 ADDED INCIDENT COORDINATES AS PER REQUEST OF JIM BUNN, PHMSA."

DUE TO NUMEROUS PIPELINES AT THE LOCATION AND NO PRESSURE DROP SEEN ON THE SNG SYSTEM, A SUBSTANTIAL EFFORT WAS MADE TO CONFIRM THE OWNERSHIP OF THE LEAK. WOOD	4023987396	BYRON.WOOD@NNGCO.COM	4023987606	"ON MAY 23, AT APPROXIATELY 14:57 THE CARLTON LOCATION WAS NOTIFIED BY ANGEL SERVICE ITT CORP, THAT THEY HAD COMPLETED THEIR AERIAL LEAK SURVEYING. UPON REVIEW OF THE INFORMATION IT APPEARED THAT THERE WAS A DETECTION OF A SINGLE METHANE INDICATION IN LAKE COUNTY, MN ON THE 16-INCH RESERVE (MNB69801) BRANCH LINE ON THE PIPELINE RIGHT OF WAY APPROXIMATELY 1.1 MILES WEST OF LAX LAKE ROAD @ APPROXIMATE MILEPOST 59.5. NORTHERN PERSONNEL PROCEEDED TO REDUCE THE PRESSURE FROM 405 TO 300 PSIG AND SENT PERSONNEL TO THE SITE TO UTILIZE PORTABLE LEAK DETECTION EQUIPMENT TO VERIFY IF THERE WAS A LEAK. A LEAK WAS DETECTED @ THE APPROXIMATE LOCATION INDICATED. A STRONG HYDRO CARBON SMELL WAS DETECTED, A READING OF 5% LEL WAS INDICATED AND A PATCH OF DEAD VEGETATION APPROXIMATELY 15 FT IN DIAMETER WAS NOTED. ACTIONS WERE TAKEN TO ACQUIRE THE SERVICES OF A CONTRACTOR AND ARRANGE FOR NORTHERN'S STOPPLE CREW TO PROCEED TO THE SITE. AN 8-INCH STOPPLE AND BYPASS WAS INSTALLED AROUND THE LEAK AREA, THEN THE SECTION OF LINE WAS BLOWN DOWN AND EXCAVATED. A ROCK WAS FOUND TO HAVE IMPINGED ON THE PIPELINE AT THE 6 O'CLOCK POSITION. THE IMPINGMENT RESULTED IN A DENT MEASURING APPROXIMATELY 11 INCHES LONGITUDINALLY, SEVEN INCHES CIRCUFERENTIALLY AND 0.903 INCHES DEEP. THERE WAS A CRACK LOCATED AT THE BOTTOM OF THE DENT MEASURING APPROXIMATELY 1-INCH LONG. IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE LEAK COULD BE REPAIRED BY INSTALLATION OF A 2-FOOT BY 16-INCH TYPE B PRESSURIZED CONTAINING SLEEVE. INSTALLATION OF THE SLEEVE WAS COMPLETED ON JUNE 3. ALL WELDS WERE INSPECTED USING MAGNETIC PARTICLE AND ULTRASONIC THICKNESS METHODS. THE PIPELINE BETWEEN THE STOPPLE FITTINGS WAS PURGED, PRESSURE TESTED AND RETURNED TO NORMAL 405 PSIG SERVICE. THERE WAS NO FIRE, NO INJURIES AND NO LOSS OF SERVICE TO ANY CUSTOMERS. THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS A ROCK IMPINING ON THE LINE AND GROUND SUBSIDENCE. A FINAL REPORT WILL BE COMPLETED UPON DETERMINATION OF THE TOTAL COST OF REPAIRS.   SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT: IN THE NARRATIVE IT WAS INDICATED THAT THE LINE NUMBER WAS MNB69801, WHICH IS INCORRECT AND SHOULD INSTEAD BE MNB72701.  SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT: TOTAL COST OF REPAIRS ESTIMATES, INCLUDING GAS LOSS HAVE BEEN UPDATED. THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE THAT GROUND SUBSIDENCE RESULTING IN A ROCK IMPINGING ON THE LINE, WHICH RESULTED IN DAMAGE TO COATING AND A DENT IN THE LINE AND AN APPROXIMATE ONE INCH CRACK IN THE BOTTOM OF THE DENT WHICH ALLOWED GAS LEAKAGE TO THE ATMOSPHERE. THIS EVENT IS CONSIDERED CLOSED."

WOOD	4023987396	BYRON.WOOD@NNGCO.COM	4023987606	"ON JUNE 12, 2008, NORTHERN WAS NOTIFIED OF WHAT APPEARED TO BE A LAZY FLAME TYPE FIRE COMING FROM THE GROUND NEAR THE OWASA, IOWA BRANCH LINE. PERSONNEL RESPONDED AND CONFIRMED THAT THE FIRE WAS COMING FROM THE GROUND ON WHAT WAS THE OWASA, IOWA 2-INCH BRANCH LINE (IAB47201) IN SECTION 20, TOWNSHIP 88N, RANGE 19W, HARDIN COUNTY, IOWA. THE OWASA BRANCH LINE IS APPROXIMATELY 0.932 MILES LONG AND ORIGINATES FROM A SIDE VALVE ON THE 6-INCH IOWA FALLS BRANCH LINE. THE POINT OF FIRE WAS LOCATED AT APPROXIMATE MILE POST .49. THE NRC, IUB AND PHMSA OFFICES WERE NOTIFIED. THE AREA OF THE LEAK AND FIRE HAD INCURRED HEAVY RAIN AND THUNDERSTORMS. IT WAS DETERMINED THAT A BOTTLE TRUCK WOULD BE PUT IN SERVICE AT THE OWASA TBS SO THAT THE LINE COULD BE TAKEN OUT OF SERVICE AND THE FIRE EXTINGUISHED. A CONTRACTOR WITH HEAVY EQUIPMENT AND MATS WAS OBTAINED TO ASSIST WITH REPAIRS. DIRT WAS BERMED TO ENABLE PUMPING OUT WATER TO ALLOW EXCAVATION OF THE SITE. UPON EXCAVATION OF THE SITE ALL INDICATIONS WERE THAT THE LEAK WAS CAUSED BY HIGH VOLTAGE ELECTRIC CURRENT DISCHARGE OFF THE PIPE WALL. THERE WAS DISBONDED COATING AT THE DISCHARGE POINT ON AN OTHERWISE WELL COATED LINE. THE PIPE WALL WAS SHINY AND HAD NOT EVEN FLASH RUSTED YET. THERE WERE NO SIGNS OF CORROSION OR PITTING AND NO CORROSION DEPOSITS OR SCALE. A SINGLE HOLE, APPROXIMATELY 3/8 INCH IN DIAMETER WAS LEAKING THE GAS. ALL INDICATIONS WERE THAT FEATURE CHARACTERISTICS WERE CONSISTENT WITH HIGH VOLTAGE DISCHARGE IN A RAPID EVENT. THE PIT CRATER WAS SMOOTH, NO DEPOSITS, ALMOST PERFECTLY SYMMETRICAL AND ALL METAL SURFACES APPEARED CLEAN AND SHINY. REPAIRS WERE MADE BY INSTALLING APPROXIMATELY 10 FEET OF NEW TESTED, COATED PIPE. IT IS POSSIBLE THAT THE LIGHTNING STRUCK AT OR NEAR THE TBS OR TAKE OFF AS THE BLACK BOX FOR THE PHONE LINE WAS ALSO DAMAGED BY THE LIGHTNING STRIKE. THIS INCIDENT IS NOT EXPECTED TO REACH THE $50,000 THRESHOLD LEVEL FOR REPORTING, HOWEVER DUE TO THE FACT THAT THERE WAS A FIRE THIS REPORT IS BEING FILED. A FINAL REPORT WILL BE FILED WHEN ALL COST HAVE BEEN ACCUMULATED.    SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT: A TOTAL COST OF REPAIRS,INCLUDING GAS LOSS, WAS CALCULATED AT $23,947. THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS DETERMINED TO BE CAUSED BY A LIGHTNING STRIKING NEAR OR AT THE TBS/TAKEOFF VALVE RESULTING IN A HIGH VOLTAGE ELECTRIC CURRENT DISCHARGE OFF THE PIPE WALL WHICH CAUSED AN APPROXIMATE 3/8 INCH DIAMETER HOLE IN THE LINE FROM WHICH GAS WAS LEAKING. REPAIRS WERE COMPLETED BY REPLACING APPROXIMATELY 10 FEET OF PIPE WITH NEW TWO-INCH, TESTED, COATED PIPE. THIS INCIDENT DID NOT EXCEED THE $50,000 REPORTING THRESHOLD BUT WAS REPORTED DO TO THE IGNITION OF LEAKING GAS. THIS EVENT IS CONSIDERED CLOSED WITH NO FURTHER ACTIONS PENDING OR PLANNED. 09/18/2012 ADDED INCIDENT COORDINATES AS PER REQUEST OF JIM BUNN, PHMSA."
