RYAN	8154675412	JIM_R_RYAN@PRAXAIR.COM		"VALERO REFINERY, TEXAS CITY CALLED AT ~22:40 TO REPORT A HYDROGEN LEAK FROM PRAXAIR'S SYSTEM IN THE VICINITY OF THEIR ADMIN. BUILDING.  FOLLOW-UP COMMUNICATIONS INDICATED THE LEAK INVOLVED A FIRE AS WELL, WHICH SEEMED TO CONFIRM THE POTENTIAL FOR A REAL HYDROGEN LEAK.  VALERO REFINERY CONTACTED LOCAL EMERGENCY RESPONDERS (TEXAS CITY PD AND FD) WHO CAME TO THE SITE.    FIVE OF PRAXAIR'S PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED TO THE SITE, INCLUDING THE PIPELINE MANAGER AND PIPELINE SUPERINTENDENT WHO WAS FIRST ON THE SCENE).  THE PRAXAIR PERSONNEL DID NOT SEE ANY FIRE, BUT COULD HEAR LEAKING GAS FROM THE VICINITY OF THE HIGH-PRESSURE H2 METER STATION/LETDOWN STATION (THERE ARE ALSO N2 AND O2 PIPELINES IN THE VICINITY AS WELL AS AN O2 METER STATION).  NEITHER THE HIGH-PRESSURE H2 METER STATION, NOR THE LETDOWN STATION WERE IN ACTIVE USE AT THE TIME (IN FACT, THE METER STATION WAS ISOLATED DOWNSTREAM AT THE PSA INSIDE THE VALERO REFINERY).  THE EMERGENCY RESPONDERS BLOCKED OFF LOOP 197 IN FRONT OF THE REFINERY AND MADE PREPARATIONS TO PUT WATER ON THE STATION IN CASE OF AN ENERGY RELEASE AS INSTRUCTED BY PX PERSONNEL.    AT 00:30, ALL PX PERSONNEL WERE ON-SITE.  THE TEXAS CITY FD WAS PUTTING WATER ON THE STATION.  A PLAN WAS FORMULATED TO SEND TWO 2-MAN TEAMS TO INVESTIGATE AND ISOLATE THE LEAK.  MULTI-USE ANALYZERS AND RAGS FASTENED TO THE END OF PROBING BARS WOULD BE USED TO INDENTIFY THE PRESENCE OF A LEAK AND/OR BURNING H2.  THE TEAMS WOULD UNLOCK, OPEN, AND ENTER THROUGH DIFFERENT GATES.  PRIOR TO ENTRY, 110V POWER WAS ISOLATED FROM THE STATION.  THE PLAN WAS COMMUNICATED TO PRAXAIR OPERATIONS MANAGEMENT, THE PIPELINE CONTROL CENTER, AND PERSONNEL ON-SITE.  HWP WAS ISSUED.  UPON ENTERING THE GATE, THE TEAM ENTERING THE NORTH GATE NOTED THAT THE LEAK WAS COMING FROM A KUNKLE PRV ON THE INSTRUMENT (N2) GAS PANEL.  THE PRV WAS MANUALLY CLOSED AND THE STATION WAS SNIFFED FOR ANY H2 LEAKS.  NONE WERE FOUND.  110V POWER WAS RESTORED TO THE STATION.    THE FINDINGS WERE COMMUNICATED TO THE VALERO REFINERY AND THE EMERGENCY RESPONDERS, AND THE EMERGENCY WAS CLOSED AT 01:05.  INVESTIGATION INTO THE CAUSE OF THE LIFTING OF THE PRV IS ONGOING."

MMS REPORTED THAT DURING A FLY BY OF THE WEST CAMERON FIELD NEAR THE WC45 PLATFORM, AN OIL SHEEN WAS REPORTED TO BE FLOATING IN THE FIELD AND BUBBLES COMING UP TO THE SURFACE FROM WHAT APPEARED TO BE A LEAKING PIPELINE.   STONE ENERGY CORPORATION TOOK IMMEDIATE ACTION TO HAVE THE ONLY PIPELINE IN THE AREA AT WC45 SHUT IN, AND WE ACTIVATED THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE TEAM. WE CONDUCTED AN IMMEDIATE FLY BY FROM THE WC45 FACILITY TO THE BEACH FACILITY AT JOHNSON BAYOU. STONE ENERGY CORPORATION WAS TRANSPORTING HYDROCARBONS TO THE BEACH IN A 16 PIPELINE WHICH IS REGISTERED AS A DOT LINE.   STONE ENERGY CORPORATION DISPATCHED A JACK- UP BOAT, DIVE BOAT WITH DIVERS, AND SENT A FIELD BOAT INTO THE AREA TO WARN MARINERS OF THE POSSIBLE HAZARD. AT THIS TIME IT WAS STILL UNDETERMINED THAT THE LEAK WAS COMING FROM OUR PIPELINE, ACTIVATION OF A SKIMMER UNIT TO ENSURE THAT NO HYDROCARBONS WOULD REACH THE BEACH IF THE LEAK BECAME WORST. WHEN ARRIVING ON LOCATION WE JUMPED THE DIVERS AND THEY LOCATED A SMALL CRACK IN THE PROTECTIVE CONCRETE COVERING ON THE PIPELINE, THEY COULD NOT FIND THE LEAK WITH OUT REMOVING THE COVERING. DIVERS MECHANICALLY REMOVED THE COVERING AND LOCATED A SMALL PINHOLE LOCATED AT THE 6 O CLOCK POSITION. AREA WAS PREPARED FOR A SPLIT CLAMP REPAIR KIT AND DIVERS INSTALLED IT ON THE PIPELINE AND SEALED THE LEAKING AREA.   STONE ENERGY CORPORATION HAS CHOSEN TO REMOVE THE 16 PIPELINE FROM SERVICE, THE LINE HAS BEEN FLUSHED AND PICKLED AND IS PREPARED FOR REMOVAL AT THE BEACH AREA. AT THIS TIME WE HAVE NO FURTHER INFORMATION ON THE DOT LINE."

WOOD	4023987396	BYRON.WOOD@NNGCO.COM	4023987606	"ON JULY 18, 2008, AT APPROXIMATELY 1 A.M., A PRESSURE DROP ON THE BEATRICE A LINE (NEM40101) MAINLINE WAS NOTED BY NORTHERN'S GAS CONTROL DEPARTMENT. PRESSURE ON THE LINE HAD BEEN CONSISTENTLY OPERATING IN THE 490 PSIG PRESSURE RANGE. THIS PIPELINE IS A DRESSER COUPLED PIPELINE. THE BEATRICE AREA HAD BEEN SUBJECT TO VERY HEAVY RAIN AND THUNDERSTORMS AND WARNINGS OF POTENTIAL FLASH FLOODING ON RIVERS AND  WATERWAYS. AN ALL-CALL WAS ISSUED TO THE BEATRICE REGION TEAMS. BASED ON  THE PRESSURE DROP STEPS WERE TAKEN TO IMMEDIATELY IDENTIFY TOWNS THAT COULD BE ADVERSELY IMPACTED  AND THEY WERE SWITCHED OVER TO OTHER GAS SOURCE SERVICES. ONCE THIS WAS COMPLETED STEPS WERE TAKEN TO ISOLATE AN APPROXIMATE 13 MILES OF THIS LINE BY CLOSING BLOCK A  BLOCK VALVES ON THE LINE AT THE BEATRICE COMPRESSOR PLANT AND BLOCK VALVE # 6 ON THE MAINLINE. FIVE SMALL VOLUME CUSTOMERS WERE IDENTIFIED AND NOTIFIED. FOUR WERE DOMESTIC  USE FARM TAPS AND ONE WAS AN IRRIGATION SETTING. AS THERE WAS NO OUTSIDE NOTIFICATION OF A POTENTIAL DAMAGE SITE APPROPRIATE STEPS WERE TAKEN FOR TWO PEOPLE TEAMS TO VISUALLY CHECK THE 13 MILE SEGMENT OF PIPE FOR POTENTIAL SIGNS OF BLOWING GAS AND/OR DAMAGE.IT WAS FOUND THAT A JOINT OF PIPE APPROXIMATELY 25 FEET LONG, IN A WATERWAY, HAD BLOWN OUT OF THE GROUND. THIS SITE IS LOCATED APPROXIMATELY 500 FEET NORTH OF MILEPOST 50.67 IN SECTION 32, TOWNSHIP 3N, RANGE 6E, ALL IN GAGE COUNTY NEBRASKA. THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER AND PHMSA CENTRAL REGION WAS NOTIFIED. THERE WAS NO FIRE, NO INJURIES AND NO LOSS OF SERVICE TO ANY TOWNS. NORTHERN IS CURRENTLY TAKING APPROPRIATE ACTIONS TO MAKE REPAIRS TO THE LINE. THIS EVENT WAS REPORTED TO THE NRC AND PHMSA AND A 7100 REPORT IS BEING FILED AS THE COST OF THE FAILURE, INCLUDING GAS LOSS WILL EXCEED THE $50,000 REPORTING THRESHOLD LEVEL. A FINAL CAUSE FOR THE FAILURE IS UNDER INVESTIGATION, HOWEVER IT IS CURRENT BELIEVED THAT THE HEAVY RAINS AND FLOODING OF THE  WATERWAY RESULTED IN EROSION OF SUPPORTING DIRT AROUND THE PIPELINES DRESSER COUPLING WHICH RESULTED IN ADDITIONAL FORCE OF WATER FLOW ON THE DRESSER COUPLINGS WHICH   ULTIMATELY LEAD TO THE FAILURE OF A DRESSER COUPLING. APPROPRIATE SUPPLEMENTAL INFORMATION SUCH AS TOTAL COST OF REPAIRS AND MATERIALS REQUIRED TO EFFECT REPAIRS WILL  BE REPORTED.  SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT: AN INVESTIGATION INTO THE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE DETERMINED THAT THE CAUSE WAS HEAVY LOCALIZED RAIN FALL WASH OUT THE DIRT ON THE BANKS AROUND DRESSER COUPLING WHICH ALLOWED THE WATER FORCE TO SEPARATE THE PIPE FROM A DRESSER COUPLING. APPROXIMATELY 269 FEET OF NEW 24 INCH TESTED PIPE WAS INSTALLED TO COMPLETE THE REPAIR PROCESS. AN UPDATED ESTIMATE OF TOTAL COST HAS BEEN ENTERED ON THIS FINAL REPORT. THIS EVENT IS CONSIDERED COMPLETE AND CLOSED WITH NO FURTHER ACTIONS PENDING OR PLANNED.  09/18/2012 ADDED INCIDENT COORDINATES AS PER REQUST OF JIM BUNN, PHMSA."

AT APPROXIMATELY 1100 HRS. ON SEPTEMBER 10, 2008 OUR SYSTEM CONTROL CENTER RECEIVED A CALL THAT OUR ABOVE GROUND BLOCK VALVE SETTING ON LINE R IN SOUTH SHREVEPORT, LA  HAD BEEN STRUCK BY AN OUTSIDE FORCE (LOG SKIDDER).  THE COLLISION RESULTED IN DAMAGE TO THE BARRICADE AND TO THE 2 INCH BLOWDOWN ON THE ABOVE GROUND BLOCK VALVE CAUSING A RELEASE OF NATURAL GAS.  OUR EMERGENCY  RESPONSE PLAN WAS INITIATED AND OUR FIELD PERSONNEL AND EMERGENCY RESPONDERS RESPONDED TO THE LOCATION. EMERGENCY RESPONDER CLOSED LASSO LANE AND PUEBLO LANE, AS WELL AS STOPPING SERVICE ON THE KCS RAILWAY WHICH WAS 100 YARDS WEST OF THE LOCATION.  THE LINE WAS ISOLATED AND REPAIRS STARTED.  BY 1300 HRS. THE AREA WAS SECURED AND THE ROADS WERE RE-OPENED.  BY 1342 THE EMERGENCY RESPONDERS RE-OPENED THE KCS RAILWAY.  THE BLOWDOWN VALVE WAS REPAIRED AND LINE R BACK IN SERVICE ON 1845  HRS. SEPTEMBER 11, 2008."

NEWMAN	3047228475	MNEWMAN@NISOURCE.COM	3047228420	"THIS COMPRESSOR STATION WAS EXPERIENCING ELECTRICAL POWER SURGES WHEN THE STATION ESD SYSTEM WAS ACTIVATED. THE 8"" FIRE VALVE CONNECTED TO THE STATION ESD SYSTEM FAILED TO CLOSE WHICH WOULD HAVE ISOLATED THE SUCTION SIDE OF THE COMPRESSOR STATION FROM THE PIPELINE. THE VALVE BLEW FOR 19 MINUTES RESULTING IN APPROXIAMTELY 6734 MCF OF GAS LOST.     DURING OUR INVESTIGATION IT WAS DISCOVERED THAT THE SHAFER CONTROLS (MANUFACTURED AND INSTALLED IN 1970) TO VALVE 7SH-1D WAS NOT OPERATING PROPERLY. THE CONTROLS TO THE VALVE WERE CLEANED AND THE O-RING, POPPET'S SPRINGS, AND VALVE PACKING WERE REPLACED OR REINSTALLED. THE CONTROLS TO THE VALVE WERE TESTED TO MAKE SURE THE VALVE AND ESD SYSTEM WERE FUNCTIONING PROPERLY."

DURRETT CONSTRUCTION DID A LA ONE CALL ON 9/24/08 (#80402646).  THIS LOCATE WAS UPDATED 2 TIMES (#80417509 AND #80435865). ON ALL LOCATES, THE TYPE OF WORK LISTED WAS STATED AS CLEARING TO INSTALL A COMPRESSOR PAD.  A NEW LOCATE WAS ISSUED ON 10/17/08 AND UPDATED ON 10/29/08 WHICH ALSO STATED TYPE OF WORK AS CLEARING TO INSTALL A COMPRESSOR PAD (#80441251 AND #80459406).   THE LOCATES DID NOT INDICATE THAT DURRETT WOULD BE DIGGING TO BURY DEBRIS.   ON 9/25/08, IN RESPONSE TO THE ORGINAL ONE CALL LOCATE, JIM NASS AND TODD WOODWARD (REGENCY EMPLOYEES) MARKED THE S ELM GROVE 12 PIPELINE WITH YELLOW PIN FLAGS AND THE ROW WAS MARKED BY SURVEYOR STAKES.  DURING THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE COMPRESSOR STATION PAD, DURRETT CONSTRUCTION PILED DEBRIS (TREES, LIMBS, ETC) ON THE S ELM GROVE 12 ROW.     TODD WOODWARD CONTACTED PETROHAWK 3 TIMES DURING THE WEEK PRIOR TO THIS INCIDENT (ED LARY ON 10/30/08, LANE JOHNSON ON 10/31/08 AND JEFF MOODY ON 11/4/08) AND REQUESTED TO HAVE THIS DEBRIS REMOVED FROM OUR ROW. AT NO TIME DURING HIS CONVERSATIONS WITH ANY OF THE PETROHAWK EMPLOYEES, WAS BURYING THE DEBRIS MENTIONED. DURRETT CONSTRUCTION RECEIVED INSTRUCTIONS FROM LANE JOHNSON (PETROHAWK) TO BURY THE DEBRIS.     WILLIAM RABO (DURRETT EMPLOYEE) WAS SENT TO THE LOCATION TO BURY THE DEBRIS ON 11/5/2008.  HE WAS USING A TRACKHOE, WORKING ALONE AND DID NOT HAVE A SPOTTER OR SUPERVISOR. BY THIS TIME, THE MAJORITY OF THE YELLOW PIN FLAGS AND ROW STAKES HAD BEEN DISTURBED AND WERE NO LONGER VISIBLE ON THE PIPELINE OR ROW IN THE IMMEDIATE DIGGING AREA DUE TO THE CLEARING AND PILING OF DEBRIS ON THE ROW.  REGENCYS PIPELINE MARKER AT THE ROAD (100 FEET FROM INCIDENT) WAS KNOCKED DOWN AND PARTIALLY COVERED IN DIRT. RABO WAS AWARE THAT THERE WAS A PIPELINE NEAR THE LOCATION. THE ONLY PIPELINE MARKERS THAT WERE STILL VISIBLE WERE YELLOW PIN FLAGS ON THE NORTH SIDE OF THE LOCATION AND A ROW STAKE ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE LOCATION. HE ASSUMED THAT THE PIPELINE WAS IN A STRAIGHT LINE BETWEEN THESE MARKERS. THIS WOULD HAVE PLACED THE PIPELINE ON THE EAST SIDE OF THE DEBRIS PILE. IN REALITY, THE PIPELINE CURVED BETWEEN THESE MARKERS. RABO DUG A HOLE AND BURIED SOME DEBRIS TO THE WEST OF THE PIPELINE. HE THEN MOVED EAST OF HIS ORIGINAL HOLE AND BEGAN TO DIG. AT THIS POINT, HE WAS DIGGING DIRECTLY OVER THE S ELM GROVE 12 PIPELINE. AT 8:52 AM RABO HIT THE PIPELINE WITH THE TRACKHOE BUCKET AND RUPTURED THE PIPELINE. HE IMMEDIATELY JUMPED FROM THE TRACKHOE AND RAN EAST (LEAVING THE TRACKHOE RUNNING). THE BUCKET ON THE TRACKHOE DEFLECTED THE GAS AWAY FROM THE TRACKHOE. RABO WAS NOT INJURED. THE GAS DID NOT IGNITE."

ALL EQUIPMENT WAS SHUT OFF AND EMPLOYEES EVACUATED THE AREA AT AROUND 9:30 AM.  DOMINION TRANSMISSION INC. (DTI) MANAGEMENT IN CLARKSBURG WAS CONTACTED ABOUT THE ACCIDENT AND BEGAN KEEPING CONSTANT CONTACT WITH STAFF AT COVE POINT BY PHONE UNTIL GARY BAKER; DTIS CONSTRUCTION SUPERVISOR ARRIVED ON SITE.  AFTER LOWERING THE PRESSURE TO GET A BETTER LOOK AT THE DAMAGED AREA IT WAS DETERMINED THAT A ONE-INCH TAP WAS BROKEN OFF OF TL-522, AS YOU COULD SEE A ONE-INCH HOLE IN THE PIPE. LYING OFF TO THE SIDE WAS A SHORT PIECE OF ONE-INCH PIPE, A ONE-INCH VALVE, AND THEN ANOTHER PIECE OF ONE-INCH PIPE SEVERAL FEET LONG WITH PART STILL COVERED BY DIRT.  BASED ON RECORDS FROM WHEN COLUMBIA GAS OWNED THE PIPELINE 30 YEARS AGO, DTI DETERMINED THAT COLUMBIA PUT THE TAP ON THE PIPELINE AS PART OF A LEAK DETECTION SYSTEM THAT WAS ONLY UTILIZED FOR A SHORT TIME.      THE PIPELINE SECTION TO WHICH THE ONE-INCH TAP WAS CONNECTED IS APPROXIMATELY 7 MILES IN LENGTH AND ONLY ONE CUSTOMER TAP WAS CONNECTED IN THIS SECTION BEING A FEED TO WASHINGTON GAS & LIGHT (WGL) CALLED THE PATUXENT METER STATION.  BY REDUCING THE PRESSURE FROM 910 PSIG TO 350 PSIG, DTI WAS ABLE TO KEEP FEEDING THE PATUXENT METER STATION TO KEEP WGL IN SERVICE.  AFTER SEVERAL CONFERENCE CALLS ON HOW TO REPAIR THE BROKEN TAP AND STILL MAINTAIN 100% SERVICE TO WGL AT PATUXENT, DTI DECIDED TO CONTRACT IN LNG TANK TRUCKS TO FEED WGL WHILE THE TL-522 LINE WAS BLOWN DOWN AND THE BROKEN TAP REPAIRED. DTI FINISHED REPAIRING THE TAP AND PLACED TL-522 BACK IN SERVICE AT 6:30 A.M., ON SUNDAY MORNING THE 16TH OF NOVEMBER.  NO SERVICE INTERRUPTIONS WERE EXPERIENCED BY WGL OR ITS CUSTOMERS BECAUSE OF THE LNG USED TO KEEP WGLS SYSTEM WHOLE."

GLAZE	3083246800	DOUGLASG@CORNHUSKERENERGY.COM	3083247006	"MULTIPLE REGULATOR MALFUNCTION INVOLVING PRESSURE CONTROL REGULATORS AND MONITOR REGULATORS.  THE REGULATOR STATION WAS INSPECTED AND SERVICED AFTER THE INCIDENT BY RON FICHTNER WITH KAL INC. UTILITY OPERATIONS SERVICE AND HIS REPORT STATES THE FOLLOWING:  ""THE FAILURE OF THE REGULATORS AT CORNHUSKER ENERGY WAS CAUSED BY FREEZE OFF IN THE PILOT REGULATORS CAUSING THE OPERATING RUN REGULATORS TO FAIL OPEN AND OVER PRESSURING THE PLASTIC PIPELINE.   THE INSPECTION OF THE FIRST CUT OPERATING REGULATOR RUN FOUND THE WORKING REGULATOR'S PILOT REGULATOR COMPLETELY FULL OF LIQUIDS CAUSING THE FREEZE OFF.  THE PILOT REGULATOR SEAT WAS TORN WHICH COULD ALSO CAUSE THE REGULATOR TO FAIL IN AN OPEN POSITION.  THE PILOT FILTER WAS ALSO INSPECTED AND IT TOO HAD LIQUIDS IN IT.  THE MONITOR REGULATOR PILOT, IN THE FIRST CUT OPERATING REGULATOR RUN, HAD SOME LIQUID IN IT AND ALSO THE PILOT FILTER HAD TRACES OF LIQUID IN IT.  THE DIAPHRAM OF THE MONITOR REGULATOR HAD SOME SEPARATION SPOTS AROUND THE CAGE SLOTS WHICH WOULD PREVENT 100% LOCK UP OF THE MONITOR REGULATOR.     THE STAND BY REGULATORS OF THE FIRST CUT REGULATOR RUN HAD TRACES OF LIQUIDS IN TEH PILOTS OF BOTH THE WORKING AND MONITOR REGULATOR WITH TRACES OF LIQUID FOUND IN BOTH OF THE PILOT FILTERS.  WELDING SLAG WAS FOUND IN THE CAGE SLOTS OF BOTH TEH OPERATING AND MONITOR REGULATORS WHICH WOULD PREVENT 100% LOCK UP OF THE REGULATORS.  THERE WERE ALSO SMALL SPOTS OF DIAPHRAGM SEPARATION IN THE DIAPHRAGMS OF BOTH REGULATORS WHICH CAN PREVENT 100% LOCKUP.   THE STRAINERS FOR THE FIRST CUT REGULATOR RUNS WERE ALSO INSPECTED.  THEY WERE MODERATELY CLEAN WITH SOME PLUG GREASE FOUND ALONG WITH TRACES OF LIQUID IN THEM.  THE INSPECTION OF THE SECOND CUT OPERATING REGULATOR RUN FOUND BOTH THE WORKING AND THE MONITOR REGULATOR PILOTS COMPLETELY FULL OF LIQUIDS CAUSING THE FREEZE OFF.  THE FILTERS FOR BOTH OF THE PILOT REGULATORS WERE ALSO COMPLETELY FULL OF LIQUIDS.  THE BODIES OF BOTH OF THE WORKING AND MONITOR REGULATORS HAD ICE CRYSTALS IN THE CAGE SCREEN.  THERE WERE ALSO SMALL SPOTS OF SEPARATION IN BOTH REGULATORS WHICH CAN PREVENT 100% LOCKUP.  THE STRAINER FOR THIS RUN WAS INSPECTED AND FOUND TO CONTAIN QUITE A BIT OF PLUG GREASE IN IT ALONG WITH TRACES OF LIQUID.  THE INSPECTION OF THE SECOND CUT STAND BY REGULATOR RUN SHOWED NO GAS FLOW WHICH IS EXACTLY AS IT SHOULD HAVE BEEN.  THE REGULATOR BODIES OF BOTH TEH WORKER AND MONITOR WERE CLEAN AND DRY AS WERE THE PILOTS AND THE PILOT FILTERS.  THE STRAINER FOR THIS RUN WAS ALSO INSPECTED AND FOUND TO BE CLEAN AND DRY.""    FOLLOWING THE INSPECTION BY KAL INC. ALL REGULATORS WERE SERVICED AND REPAIRED.    IN CONSIDERATION OF THE FINDINGS OF KAL INC., CORNHUSKER ENERGY HAS ADDED SAFETY MEASURES TO PREVENT SIMILAR INCIDENTS IN THE FUTURE.  A FULL RELIEF POP-OFF HAS BEEN INSTALLED FOLLOWING THE REGULATOR STATION AND THE RELIEF IS SET TO A VALUE EQUAL TO THE MAOP OF THE PLASTIC LINE.  IN THE EVENT OF OVERPRESSURIZATION DUE TO MULTIPLE REGULATOR FAILURE THE RELIEF WILL LIFT AND RELIEVE PRESSURE TO THE MAOP VALUE.  IN ADDITION, WITH CONSIDERATION OF THE FINDINGS OF KAL INC., CORNHUSKER ENERGY HAS INITIATED COMMUNICATIONS WITH KINDER MORGAN IN AN EFFORT TO EXPLAIN THE FINDINGS OF THE REPORT."

NOTIFICATION WAS MADE TO THE NRC (TICKET # 897807 DTD 2/18/09). ADDITIONAL NOTIFICATIONS WERE MADE TO THE COAST GUARD, MMS AND SW OPNS OF PHMSA. IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THE LEAK WAS ON NORTHERN'S 24-INCH PIPELINE (TOS80631). ACTIONS WERE TAKEN TO SHUT IN THE LINE AND MAKE SURE THAT ALL PLATFORMS WERE ISOLATED FROM THE LINE. PRELIMINARY INDICATIONS ARE THAT A MECHANICAL COUPLING ON A 24 INCH BYPASS PIPING, THAT WAS INSTALLED PRIOR TO REMOVAL OF PLATFORM 686, HAD SEPARATED FROM THE PIPELINE. THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE EVENT IS STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION. PLANS ARE CURRENTLY UNDERWAY TO EVALUATE NECESSARY REPAIRS AND DEVELOP A REPAIR PLAN. THIS REPORT IS BEING FILED AS THE COST OF REPAIRS AND GAS LOSS ARE DEFINATELY GOING TO EXCEED THE $50,000 REPORTING THRESHOLD LEVEL. THERE WAS NO FIRE, NO INJURIES, NO EXPLOSIONS AND NO EVACATIONS EXPERIENCED DURING THIS EVENT. ADDITIONAL SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORTS WILL BE FILED UPON COMPLETION OF THE INVESTIGATION AND FINAL COST OF REPAIRS IS DETERMINED.    SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT - APRIL 27, 2009: A REPAIR PLAN HAS BEEN SUBMITTED AND APPROVED BY THE MINERALS MANAGEMENT SERVICE (MMS). BIDS HAVE BEEN RECEIVED FROM CONTRACTORS TO COMPLETE THE REPAIRS AND ARE CURRENTLY BEING EVALUATED. TO DATE IT HAS NOT BEEN DETERMINED WHAT WAS THE ROOT CAUSE. THE INTENT, DURING THE REPAIR PROCESS, IS TO BRING BACK TO SHORE ALL MATERIALS OF THE BYPASS PIPING AND TO CONDUCT A FAILURE ANALYSIS. IT IS EXPECTED THAT THIS WILL BE COMPLETED SOME TIME IN JUNE 2009, CONTINGENT UPON CONTRACTOR, MATERIALS AND WEATHER CONDITIONS. A FINAL REPORT WILL BE SUBMITTED UPON PROJECT AND FAILURE ANALYSIS COMPLETION.  SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT: THE TOTAL ESTIMATED COST FOR GAS LOSS AND OPERATOR DAMAGE HAS BEEN UPDATED. COMPLETION OF THIS REPAIR WAS INCLUDED WITH TWO OTHER MMS APPROVED PROJECTS. AVAILABILITY OF CONTRACTORS, MATERIALS AND WEATHER CONDITIONS HAVE HAMPERED EXPEDITED COMPLETION OF REPAIRS. CURRENTLY PIPING IS BEING DE-WATERED AND BARRING ADVERSE WEATHER CONDITIONS IT IS POSSIBLE THAT THIS PROJECT WILL BE COMPELTED BY SEPTEMBER 1ST. THE PIPING WITH THE FAILED MECHANICAL COUPLING HAS BEEN RETREIVED AND IS BEING ANALYZED BY AN OUTSIDE LABORATORY TO ASSIST WITH DETERMINING THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE EVENT. A FINAL REPORT ON THIS EVENT WILL BE FILED UPON COMPLETION OF PROJECT AND CONCURRENCE ON THE ROOT CAUSE.    FINAL REPORT: REPAIRS WERE COMPLETED AS OUTLINE IN A REPAIR PLAN THAT WAS SUBMITTED AND APPROVED BY THE MINERALS MANAGEMENT SERVICES (MMS). THE LINE WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE EFFECTIVE AUGUST 13, 2009. A FAILURE ANALYSIS WAS COMPLETED BY STORK TESTING & METALLURGICAL CONSULTING, INC. AFTER EXTENSIVE ANALYSIS AND TESTING IT APPEARS THAT THE FAILURE IS LIKELY TO BE ATTRIBUTABLE TO A COMBINATION OF FACTORS WHICH ARE AN INCOMPLETE ENGAGEMENT BY THE SLIP ANCHOR AROUND ITS CIRCUMFERENCE ON THE MECHNAICAL COUPLING, PIPE OVALITY AND IT'S STRENGHT. ALL BYPASS PIPING, THE FAILED COUPLING AND ANOTHER MECHANICAL COUPLING WERE REMOVED AND REPAIRS WERE COMPLETED BY INSTALLATION OF APPROXIMATELY 133 FEET OF NEW 24-INCH, PREFABRICATED, WELDS RADIOGRAPHED, COATED PIPING, WHICH WAS HYDRO TESTED ON SHORE TO A PRESSURE BETWEEN 2,150 AND 2,300 PSIG, WHICH IS 1.5 TO 1.6 OF MAOP WITH WATER PRIOR TO INSTALLATION/COMPLETION OF REPAIRS. NO FURTHER ACTIONS ARE PENDING OR BEING CONSIDERED."

2009	15350	20090022		DOMINION PEOPLES	501 MARTINDALE	PITTSBURGH	ALLEGHENY	PA	15212	1420	1/15/2009	ELIZABETH	ALLEGHENY	PA	15037			40.21474	-79.86105	N	3				NO	NO	N	INTRASTATE	2	RUPTURE					2	LONGITUDINAL-TEAR/CRACK	40	6	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	2455333	81333	2374000	0	NO	NO	NO	NO	0			1	20	1/16/2009	895016	660	1000	NO	NO	YES	NO	NO	N	1	TRANSMISSION	2	PIPE SEAM		1	STEEL		NO	NO	NO	1	PIPELINE		1949	12.75	0.31	B	35000	ERW LF	N/A	UKNOWN	1948	7	OTHER	CREEK BED	36	2/19/2009	19	MATERIAL AND/OR WELD FAILURES									NULL		NULL																	NULL						NULL			NULL			NULL																		1	LF ERW		2	MATERIAL DEFECT			NO	NO																									PAUL R SEKINGER - SENIOR LEAD ENGINEER	4122442582	PAUL.R.SEKINGER@PEOPLES-GAS.COM		"THE PORTION OF THE PIPELINE THAT FAILED IS COMPRISED OF A BARE 12.75 INCH DIAMETER BY 0.312-INCH NOMINAL WALL THICKNESS LINE PIPE THAT CONTAINS A LONGITUDINAL SEAM WELD. THE FAILURE OCCURRED AT A LOW POINT IN THE UNPIGGABLE PIPELINE. THE PIPE WAS INSTALLED IN 1948 AND HAS AN IMPRESSED CURRENT CATHODIC PROTECTION (CP) SYSTEM THAT WAS ENERGIZED IN 1961.    A TEN-FOOT SECTION OF PIPE THAT INCLUDED THE RUPTURED JOINT AND A PORTION OF THE ADJACENT UPSTREAM JOINT WAS SHIPPED TO DNV FOR ANALYSIS. THE OBJECTIVES OF THE FAILURE ANALYSIS WERE TO DETERMINE THE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE AND IDENTIFY ANY CONTRIBUTING FACTORS.    THE FOLLOWING IS A SUMMARY OF THE FINDINGS:     THE RUPTURE OCCURRED AT A GROOVE LOCATED AT THE          LONGITUDINAL SEAM WELD.   INTERNAL CORROSION WAS PRESENT IN THE VICINITY OF THE GROOVE.   THE MORPHOLOGY OF THE GROOVE AND ASSOCIATED CORROSION ATTACK IS CONSISTENT WITH SELECTIVE SEAM CORROSION ASSOCIATED WITH ELECTRIC RESISTANCE WELD (ERW) SEAMS.   THE WELD MICROSTRUCTURE IS CONSISTENT WITH AN ELECTRIC RESISTANCE WELD (ERW) SEAM.   THE RESULTS OF THE CHEMICAL ANALYSIS ARE CONSISTENT WITH COMPOSITION SPECIFICATIONS FOR API 5L GRADES B AND C LINE PIPE STEEL IN PLACE AT THE TIME OF MANUFACTURE.   THE RESULTS OF THE MECHANICAL ANALYSIS ARE CONSISTENT WITH THE SPECIFICATIONS FOR API 5L GRADES B AND C LINE PIPE THAT WERE IN PLACE AT THE TIME OF MANUFACTURE.   THE CHARPY V-NOTCH RESULTS INDICATE THAT THE BASE METAL AND WELD METAL EXHIBITED LOW TOUGHNESS VALUES, WHICH IS CONSISTENT WITH THE VINTAGE AND GRADE OF PIPE.    THE RESULTS OF THE ANALYSIS INDICATE THAT THE FAILURE OCCURRED DUE TO INTERNAL SELECTIVE SEAM CORROSION. THE SYNERGISTIC EFFECT OF THE SELECTIVE SEAM CORROSION, THE ORIENTATION OF THE SEAM WELD (5:30 OCLOCK ORIENTATION), AND THE LOW TOUGHNESS OF THE BASE AND WELD METALS WERE THREE OF THE MAIN CONTRIBUTING FACTORS TO THE FAILURE.    THE PIPELINE HAS BEEN REPLACED IN ITS ENTIRETY."

COMPLIANCE COORDINATOR"	2184645743	RON.CARLBERG@ENBRIDGE.COM		"WITH THE JOLIET COMPRESOR STATION OFF LINE AND ISOLATED, STAFF WERE INSTALLING A FACTORY REPAIRED ETHERNET AND CENTRAL PROCESSING UNIT (CPU) CARD TO VERIFY THE RELIABILITY OF THE CARDS.  THE JOLIET COMPRESSOR STATION IS EQUIPPED WITH A REDUNDANT EMERGENCY SHUTDOWN PROGRAMMABLE LOGIC CONTROLLER WHICH AFFORDS THE OPPORTUNITY FOR THIS TYPE OF FIELD TESTING.    REPLACEMENT OF THESE BOARDS INVOLVED REPROGRAMMING OF THE ERASABLE PROGRAMMABLE READ ONLY MEMORY (EPROM) ON EACH BOARD AND CARD WITH THE CURRENT CUSTOM INSTRUCTION SETS SUITED TO VECTOR OPERATIONS.  DURING THE ETHERNET CARD REPROGRAMMING PROCESS; AN EMERGENCY SHUTDOWN (ESD) WAS INADVERTENTLY TRIGGERED, SENDING GAS TO THE SILENCER, AS DESIGNED.  THE GAS WAS THEN IGNITED (STATIC CHARGE) AND A FIRE PLUME FROM THE TOP OF THE SILENCER ENSUED.  OPERATIONS PERSONNEL IMMEDIATELY CONTACTED THE CONTROL ROOM AND MANAGEMENT TO INFORM THEM THAT THE EVENT HAD OCCURRED (CONTROL CENTRE WAS ALREADY AWARE VIA SCADA LINK) AND THAT THE SYSTEM WAS FUNCTIONING AS DESIGNED, WITH THE EXCEPTION OF THE RESULTANT FIRE.  ONCE EVACUATION OF THE GAS WAS COMPLETED, THE FIRE DISSIPATED.  NO INJURIES OCCURRED AND DAMAGE WAS LIMITED TO PORTIONS OF THE SILENCER AND SOME NEARBY TREES (ON VECTOR PROPERTY) WERE SINGED."

CLAY BEAN - SUPERVISOR HAMPSHIRE GAS	3048225664	CBEAN@WASHGAS.COM	3048223994	"WHILE PERFORMING PIPELINE CLEANING WITH A SCRAPER PIG, THE PIG ARRIVED IN THE PIG RECEIVER. RECEIVER ISOLATION VALVES WERE CLOSED. PRESSURE IN THE RECEIVER WAS RELEASED THROUGH MANUALLY OPERATED BALL VALVES (4) LOCATED IN FRONT AND BEHIND THE PIG. AFTER VENTING GAS STOPPED, AND WITH VENT VALVES IN THE OPEN POSITION, THE SAFETY INTERLOCK DEVICE WAS REMOVED FROM THE HINGED CLOSURE TO PERMITE OPENING OF THE MAIN DOOR. WITH NO FURTHER GAS ESCAPING FRO EITHER THE VALVES OR THE PRESSURE WARNING INTERLOCK DEVICE, PERSONNEL BEGAN REMOVING THE CLAMP WHICH SECURES THE MAIN DOOR. AS THE CLAMP WAS LOOSENED, THE 14"" NOMINAL DIAMETER MAIN DOOR OPENED ABRUPTLY AND WITH FORCE DUE TO UNVENTED GAS PRESSURE TRAPPED IN THE VESSEL BEHIND THE BLOCKED VENT VALVES AND SAFETY INTERLOCK. THE DOOR STRUCK AN EMPLOYEE IN THE ABDOMEN AS IT SWUNG OPEN.    THE ESTIMATED PRESSURE IN SECTION A.8.A IS BASED IN THE NATURE OF THE BLOCKAGE, TYPE OF DEBRIS, ARE OF THE DOOR, AND RELTIVELY MINOR INJURY TO THE EMPLOYEE."

WOOD	4023987396	BYRON.WOOD@NNGCO.COM	4023987606	"ON MAY 6, 2009, AT APPROXIMATELY 4 P.M., EARTH MOVING EQUIPMENT OPERATED BY A KEVIN BITES AND OWNED BY A COMPANY CALLED DOANE LTD, STRUCK NORTHERN'S BLACK RIVER FALLS 8-INCH DIAMETER BRANCHLINE (WIB18601) NEAR MILE POST 49.15 IN THE EAST 1/2 OF THE NE 1/4 OF SECTION 36, T25N, R14W PEPIN COUNTY, WISCONSIN. THIS 8-INCH LINE HAS AN MAOP OF 895 AND WAS OPERATING AT APPROXIMATELY 706 PSIG AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT. THERE WAS ESCAPING GAS TO ATMOSPHERE BUT IT DID NOT IGNITE AND THERE WAS NO FIRE, EXPLOSION OR INJURIES. EMEREGENCY RESPONDERS EVACUATED RESIDENCES WITHIN A 1/2 MILE RADIUS, WHICH AFFECTED 24 BUILDINGS. RESPONDERS ALSO BLOCKED ROADS NEAR THE INTERSECTION OF SILVER BIRCH ROAD AND ROUND HILL ROAD. FOLLWING REPAIRS, THE PIPELINE WAS RETURNED TO NORMAL SERVICE AT APPROXIMATELY 7:20 P.M., MAY 7, 2009. REPRESENTATIES FROM THREE UTILITIES, ST. CROIX VALLEY NATURAL GAS, MIDWEST NATURAL GAS, AND WE ENGERGIES ASSISTED WITH GAS LOAD REDUCTIONS AND FACILITY MANAGEMENT DURING THE PIPELINE REPAIRS. FIVE NORTHERN NATURAL GAS CO. BOTTLE TRUCKS WERE UTILIZED IN MAINTAINING SERVICE. APPROXIMATELY 70 NORTHERN EMPLOYEES AND 20 CONTRACTOR EMPLOYEES WORKED NON-STOP PERFORMING EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AND PIPELINE REPAIRS, WHICH CONSISTED OF REPLACING 83 FEET OF 8-INCH DIAMETER PIPE WITH NEW TESTED/COATED PIPE AND THE INSTALLATION OF A REPAIR SLEEVE.  INITIAL INVESTIGATION INDICATES THAT NORTHERN'S PIPELINE WAS DENTED IN ONE LOCATION AND SEVERED IN ANOTHER BY EQUIPMENT OPERATED BY THE CONTRACTORS EMPLOYEE. IT APPEARS THAT THERE WAS NO ONE-CALL LINE LOCATE REQUEST MADE PRIOR TO COMMENCING EXCAVATION ACTIVITIES. THE PIPELINE WAS MARKED AT BOTH SIDES OF THE PROPERTY WITH PIPELINE MARKERS AND AN ADDITIONAL MARKER WAS VISIBLE APPROXIMATELY 121 FT WEST OF THE LINE HIT LOCATION, IN A TREE ROW. AN IN-DEPTH INVESTIGATION OF THE INCIDENT IS IN-PROGESS AND ADDITIONAL SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORTS WILL BE FILED AS THE ROOT CAUSE & TOTAL COST OF REPAIRS INFORMATION IS COMPLETE. THERE WAS NO LOSS OF SERVICE TO CUSTOMERS. SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT: AN INVESTIGATION INTO THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT DETERMINED THAT THERE WAS NO ""ONE CALL"" MADE TO DIGGERS HOTLINE INCORPORATED (WISCONSIN) PRIOR TO MOVING SOIL AND EXCAVATION ACTIVITIES AT THE SITE, WHICH RESULTED IN REMOVAL OF SOIL FROM OVER THE PIPELINE TO THE EXTENT THAT THE PIPELINE WAS STRUCK AND SEVERED.  SUPPLEMENTAL UPDATE OF FINAL REPORT:  CORRECTED ESTIMATED COSTS FROM $287120 TO $316630 (GAS LOSS $87375; OPERATOR DAMAGE $229,255). NO OTHER MODIFICATION OR CORRECTIONS MADE.  09/18/2012 ADDED INCIDENT COORDINATES AS PER REQUEST OF JIM BUNN, PHMSA."

PETERS	2053257554	KEN.PETERS@ELPASO.COM	2053253729	"A TENNESSEE GAS PIPELINE EMPLOYEE FOUND, THROUGH ROUTINE OPERATIONS & MAINTENANCE WORK, INDICATIONS OF A GAS LEAK EVIDENCED BY WATER BUBBLING ABOVE A PIPELINE AT THE SURFACE OF WET GROUND.  THE PIPELINE IS TGP'S 30"" 800-1 LINE.  EXCAVATION REVEALED WHAT APPEARED TO BE A CRACK IN A FILLET WELD WHERE A 12"" PIPE TAPPED THROUGH A FULL ENCIRCLEMENT SLEEVE INTO THE 30"" CARRIER PIPE.  REPAIRS WERE COMPLETED AROUND APRIL 27, 2009 BY INSTALLING A WELD TEE. THE RESULTS FROM INVESTIGATION CONFIRM THAT THE BRANCH-TO-CARRIER PIPE FILLET WELD UNDER THE FULL ENCIRCLEMENT SADDLE CONTAINED A CRACK EXTENDING THROUGH THE WELD CAP AND STOPPING JUST BEFORE THE ROOT BEAD LEAVING A SMALL LIGAMENT OF METAL PREVENTING THROUGH-WALL PENETRATION. BASED ON THE LAB RESULTS, THE CRACK APPEARED TO HAVE PROPAGATED RAPIDLY MANY YEARS AGO AND THEN REMAINED STABLE FOR AN EXTENDED PERIOD OF TIME THEREAFTER. MINOR STRESS APPEARS TO HAVE CAUSED A DUCTILE FAILURE IN THE REMAINING METAL LIGAMENT BETWEEN THE OLD EXISTING CRACK AND THE INADEQUATELY FUSED ROOT BEAD WHICH RESULTED IN THE GAS LEAK."

THIS LEAK TRIGGERED THE RED STROBE LIGHT AT THE TOP OF THE UNITS BUILDING.  THE STATION OPERATOR SAW THE LIGHT AND MANUALLY ACTIVATED THE ESD SYSTEM. AFTER THE ESD SYSTEM ACTIVATED, THE OPERATOR OBSERVED THAT THE VENT VALVES CONTINUED TO VENT GAS AT A HIGH RATE.  THE STATION WAS THEN MANUALLY ISOLATED FROM THE PIPELINE SYSTEM AND SECURED WITHIN 1HR AND 30 MINUTES.      A ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS FOLLOWED THIS EVENT AND IT IDENTIFIED THAT A FAILED GASKET ON HEAD-END HEAD GASKET AT UNIT NO. 3 CAUSED A LEAK, LEADING TO THE MANUAL ACTIVATION OF THE ESD SYSTEM.  WATER IN THE AIR SYSTEM REDUCED THE AMOUNT OF AVAILABLE SUPPLY AIR PRESSURE TO THE VALVE OPERATORS FOR FOUR VALVES IN THE ESD SYSTEM, INCLUDING THE STATION ISOLATION VALVES.     TO PREVENT A RE-OCCURRENCE OF THIS INCIDENT, THE WORK MANAGEMENT SYSTEM WAS MODIFIED TO INCLUDE INSPECTIONS OF THE AIR SYSTEM FOR WATER INTRUSION.     AFTER REPAIRS WERE MADE, THE ESD SYSTEM WAS TESTED TO ENSURE THAT THE SYSTEM WOULD FUNCTION AS DESIGNED. THE TEST WAS SUCCESSFUL."

EASTSIDE IS A BOOSTER COMPRESSION STATION SITUATED AT APPROXIMATELY THE MIDPOINT OF THE RIGS PIPELINE SYSTEM, WITH NO GAS PROCESSING OR TREATMENT TAKING PLACE ONSITE.  THE STATION WAS UNATTENDED WHEN THE FIRE STARTED.  THE FIRE BURNED FOR APPROXIMATELY 1 HOUR 45 MINUTES BEFORE BEING COMPLETELY EXTINGUISHED AND DAMAGED 2 OF THE 3 UNITS LOCATED AT THE FACILITY.      THE FIRE IGNITED WHEN A WELD UNDER A RELIEF VALVE ON #1 COMPRESSOR BROKE.   THE CUMULATIVE EFFECT OF CYCLIC STRESS AS A RESULT OF PRESSURE CONTAINMENT, AXIAL TORQUE AND VIBRATION CAUSED THE PSV CONNECTION SERVING COMPRESSOR THROWS 2, 4 & 6 TO FAIL IN A WELDED JOINT.  COMPRESSOR PULSATION BOTTLE SUPPORT DESIGN, PIPING SUPPORT DESIGN, DISCHARGE RELIEF VALVE CONNECTION SIZE AND PIPING CONFIGURATION ALL CONTRIBUTED TO THE UNITS PROPENSITY TO SHAKE. 2009	13750	20090071		NORTHERN NATURAL GAS CO	1111 SOUTH 103RD STREET	OMAHA	DOUGLAS	NE	68124	1100	6/23/2009	BESSEMER	GOGEBIC	MI	49911	121.26	"SE1/4,SEC3,T47N,R46W"	46.4941417	-90.0177625	N	1				NO	NO	Y	INTERSTATE	2	RUPTURE					2	LONGITUDINAL-TEAR/CRACK	792	66	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	692449	310000	382449	0	NO	NO	NO	YES	10	1	PRECAUTIONARY	1	30	6/23/2009	909472	923	1090	NO	YES	NO	NO	NO	N	1	TRANSMISSION	2	PIPE SEAM		1	STEEL		NO	NO	NO	1	PIPELINE		1965	16	0.2	API	60000	ERW		YOUNGSTOWN	1965	4	UNDER GROUND		45	6/30/2009	1	CORROSION	2	COATED	3	OTHER	LOCALIZED SCC	5	STRESS CORROSION CRACKING		YES	1965	NO																	NULL						NULL			NULL			NULL																									NULL	NULL																									BYRON WOOD	4023987396	BYRON.WOOD@NNGCO.COM	4023987606	"ON JUNE 23, 2009, AT APPROXIMATELY 11:54 A.M. CDT, NORTHERN'S OPERATION COMMUNICATION CENTER, IN OMAHA, NE RECEIVED AN EMERGENCY CALL REPORTING THAT THERE WAS GAS BLOWING TO ATMOSPHERE AND A POSSIBLE RUPTURE OF THE PIPELINE APPROXIMATELY 1 1/4 MILES NORTH OF THE TOWN OF BESSMER, MICHIGAN. PERSONNEL WERE IMMEDIATELY DISPATCHED TO THE AREA AND IT WAS DETERMINED THAT A PIPE RUPTURE HAD OCCURRED ON THE M432B (MIM10101) 16-INCH CARLTON-WAKEFIELD B LINE @ APPROXIMATE MILEPOST 121.26. LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT EVACUATED APPROXIMATELY 15 HOME SITES AND ESTABLISHED A 1/2 MILE SAFE ZONE. THE INCIDENT OCCURRED IN THE SE1/4 OF SECTION 3, T47N, R46W IN GOGEBIC COUNTY, MICHIGAN. LINE PRESSURE AT THE TIME OF THE INCIDENT WAS APPROXIMATELY 923 PSIG. THE EVENT WAS IMMEDIATELY REPORTED TO THE NRC (TICKET # 909472), PHMSA, MICHIGAN PUBLIC SAFETY, EPA AND LOCAL AND STATE AGENCIES. INITIAL INVESTIGATION INDICATED THAT APPROXIMATELY 66 FEET OF PIPE HAD BLOWN OUT OF THE GROUND. IMMEDIATE ACTIONS WERE TAKEN TO ISOLATE THE SEGMENT OF LINE AND ATTEMPT TO MAINTAIN AS MUCH SERVICE TO CUSTOMERS AS POSSIBLE. NORTHERN'S BOTTLE TRUCKS WERE BROUGHT IN AND PLACED IN SERVICE FOR THE TOWN OF BESSEMER AND RAMSAY. GAS SERVICE TO APPROXIMATELY 380 HOMES IN RAMSAY WAS LOST AND HAD TO BE RESTORED BY XCEL ENERGY. SERVICE TO INTERRUPTIBLE BUSINESSES IN BESSEMER WAS INTERRUPTED. THE PIPE IN THE FAILED SEGMENT WAS MANUFACTURED BY YOUNGSTOWN AND INSTALLED IN 1965. IT IS 16-INCH X 0.203 AND 0.250 INCH WALL THICKNESS, GRADE X-60 ELECTRIC RESISTANCE WELDED (ERW) PIPE.  REPAIRS WERE MADE BY INSTALLING APPROPRIATE STOPPLE FITTINGS TO ENABLE REPLACEMENT OF APPROXIMATELY 219 FEET OF NEW 16-INCH TESTED, X-60, 0.312 WALL THICKNESS PIPE. THE NEW PIPE WAS PRESSURE TESTED TO A MINIMUM TEST PRESSURE OF 1620 PSIG. A RETURN TO SERVICE PLAN WAS DEVELOPED AND SUBMITTED TO THE CENTRAL REGION OFFICE OF PHMSA FOR REVIEW. PHMSA DID NOT IDENTIFY ANY CONCERNS WITH THE PLAN THEREFORE NORTHERN WAS AUTHORIZED TO RE-START THE CARLTON TO MARQUETTE LINE AT A REDUCED PRESSURE AS REQUIRED BY A CORRECTIVE ACTION ORDER ISSUED BY THE ASSOCIATE ADMINISTRATOR FOR PIPELINE SAFETY. THE CORRECTIVE ACTION ORDER REQUIRES THAT THE PRESSURE AT THE FAILURE SITE AND DOWNSTREAM OF THE FAILURE SITE IS NOT TO EXCEED 80% OF THE OPERATING PRESSURE IMMEDIATELY PRIOR TO THE FAILURE. SPECIFICALLY, THE PRESSURE AT THE FAILURE SITE IS NOT TO EXCEED 739 PSIG. THIS PRESSURE RESTRICTION WILL REMAIN IN EFFECT UNTIL WRITTEN APPROVAL TO INCREASE THE PRESSURE OR RETURN THE PIPELINE TO ITS PRE-FAILURE OPERATING PRESSURE IS OBTAINED FROM THE REGIONAL DIRECTOR, PHMSA. PIECES OF THE FAILED PIPE HAVE BEEN SENT TO BRYAN LAB IN HOUSTON, TX FOR FAILURE ANALYSIS. AN ADDITIONAL SECTION OF PIPE WERE SENT TO KEIFNER & ASSOCIATES LABORATORY IN OHIO. KEIFNER AND BRYAN LABS WILL ASSIST NORTHERN WITH IDENTIFYING THE CAUSE OF THE FAILURE AND THE INSPECTION TECHNIQUES NORTHERN WILL USE TO IDENTIFY OTHER RISKS TO THE PIPELINE SYSTEM. ADDITIONAL SUPPLEMENTAL REPORTS WILL BE FILED AS THE ROOT CAUSE AND FINAL, ACCURATE COST OF GAS LOSS/REPAIRS ARE DETERMINED.  SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT: THIS REPORT IS BEING SUBMITTED TO UPDATE THE COTS INCURRED IN THE REPAIR PROCESS OF THIS INCIDENT. IN ADDITION, THE ROOT CAUSE HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED AS STRESS CORROSION CRACKING (SCC). A CORRECTIVE ACTION ORDER (CAO) WAS ISSUED BY PHMSA, RE; CPF NO.3-2009-1010H. ADDITIONAL ACTIONS AND COST ARE BEING INCURRED TO COMPLY WITH THE CAO, AND MUST BE COMPLETED PRIOR TO RESTORATION OF THE LINE PRESSURE BACK TO IT'S CAPABILITY PRIOR TO THE RUPTURE. THESE ACTIONS AND COST ARE BEING ADDRESSED VIA QUARTERLY REPORTS TO THE DIRECTOR, CENTRAL REGION OF OPS. AS FAR AS COST AND REPAIR ACTIONS TAKEN TO ADDRESS THE RUPTURE EVENT, PER THIS 7100 REPORT, THERE ARE CONSIDERED COMPLETE.  SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT: DO TO THE IDENTIFICATION OF ADDITONAL COST, FROM EMPLOYEE EXPENSE AND OUTSIDE SERVICES, THIS SUPPLEMENTAL REPORT IS BEING SUBMITTED TO CORRECT THE PREVIOUS TOTAL COST OF $674,379 TO $692, 449.   09/18/2012 ADDED INCIDENT COORDINATES AS PER REQUEST OF JIM BUNN, PHMSA."

SINCE NO IGNITION OR FIRE OCCURRED AT THIS INCIDENT, THE CHARRED TIMBERS ARE POSSIBLY THE RESIDUAL FROM AN OLD BURN PILE. SINCE THE 70 INCH LONGITUDINAL SPLIT IN THE PIPE WAS NOT ALONG THE SEAM OF THE PIPE AND WAS ON A DENT AND LONGITUDINAL GOUGE, THE FAILURE WAS PROBABLY THE RESULT OF THE DAMAGE (DENT AND GOUGES) IN THE PIPE WALL."

ENERGY-DISPERSIVE X-RAY SPECTROSCOPY (EDS) ANALYSIS SHOWED A SIGNIFICANT PRESENCE OF COPPER IN THE INTERGRANULAR CRACKS.    3. THE LEAK IN THE PIPE WAS CAUSED BY COPPER CONTAMINATION ORIGINATING IN THE INTERNAL WELD PASS OF THE DSAW PIPE. THE CRACKING PRODUCED A SMALL DEFECT THAT APPARENTLY EITHER DID NOT PENETRATE TO THE OUTSIDE SURFACE ON THE WELD OR WAS NOT DETECTED FOR MANY YEARS."

KEMPSKI	7168272131	KEMPSKIB@NATFUEL.COM	7168275521	"ON SEPTEMBER 29, 2009 AT APPROXIMATELY 11:55 AM NATIONAL FUEL SUPPLY CORPORATION (""NFGSC"") PERSONNEL RECEIVED AN EMERGENCY WARNING NOTIFICATION FROM ITS SCADA SYSTEM THAT AN INCIDENT HAD OCCURED AT DERBY COMPRESSOR STATION LOCATED AT 7393 VERSAILLES PLANK ROAD, DERBY, NEW YORK. ON ARRIVAL, NFGSC PERSONNEL OBSERVED DAMAGE TO THE INGERSOLL-RAND MODEL #4XVG 75HP COMPRESSOR, THE COMPRESSOR STATION BUILDING, AND THE FOUR-INCH BURIED DISCHARGE PIPING. THERE WAS NO FIRE NOR WERE THERE ANY INJURIES OR FATALITIES. NFGSC PERSONNEL ISOLATED THE DAMAGED FACILITY BY CLOSING THREE VALVES. THE FACILITY WAS SHUT-IN AND MADE SAFE AT APPROXIMATELY 12:45 PM THE SAME DAY. FURTHER INVESTIGATION INTO THE INCIDENT REVEALED A RUPTURE IN THE BURIED FOUR-INCH DISCHARGE PIPING.    PART G: NARRITIVE DESCRIPTION OF FACTORS CONTRIBUTING TO THE EVENT - CONTINUED: INVESTIGATION UPDATE: THE FAILED SECTION WAS DELIVERED TO BATTELLE, COLUMBUS OHIO FOR A COMPLETE METALLURGICAL AND FAILURE ANALYSIS TO DETERMINE THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE FAILURE. BATTELLE CONCLUDED: ""A STRONG GRADATION IN WALL THICKNESS WAS FOUND FROM REMOTE TO THE ENDS OF THE CASING TOWARD THE MIDLENGTH OF THE CASING WHERE THE RUPTURE OCCURRED. THIS GRADATION AND THE SLIGHTLY DIFFERING CORROSION PRODUCTS FOUND WITHIN THE AREA OF THE CASING SUGGEST THAT THE SLIGHTLY MORE STAGNANT CONDITIONS AND POTENTIALLY COOLER TEMPERATURE (AND INCREASED POTENTIAL FOR CONDENSATION DUE TO ITS PROXIMITY TO THE INGROUND CONDITIONS) OPENS THIS AREA TO SOMEWHAT FASTER CORROSION. THE CAUSE OF THE FOCALIZED CORROSION THUS APPEARS TO TRACE TO THE TYPE OF FOUNDATION PENETRATION EMPLOYED."

A TILING CONTRACTOR TILING IN SECTION 12 OF HOLLAND TOWNSHIP, T-95N, R44W, IN SIOUX COUNTY, IOWA STRUCK THE 2-INCH NEWKIRK BRANCH LINE (IAB48601)SEVERING THE 2-INCH GAS LINE. THERE WAS BLOWING GAS, NO FIRE, NO EXPLOSION, NO INJURIES. THE SEVERING OF THE LINE RESULTED IN THE LOSS OF GAS SERVICE TO THE COMMUNITY OF NEWKIRK, IOWA IN WHICH THERE WERE APPROXIMATELY 17 METER SETTINGS THAT WERE SERVICED BY MIDAMERICAN ENERGY COMPANY. AN INVESTIGATION AND INTERVIEW WITH THE TILER DETERMINED THAT THERE WAS NO 1-CALL REQUEST MADE BY THE TILER. THE FAILURE TO MAKE A ONE-CALL LOCATE REQUEST WAS THE ROOT CAUSE FOR THE PIPELINE BEING STUCK. THE IOWA ATTORNEY GENERALS OFFICE HAS BEEN NOTIFIED OF THE ONE CALL VIOLATION. REPAIRS WERE MADE BY INSTALLING APPROXIMATELY 12 FEET OF NEW TESTED, COATED TWO-INCH PIPE. A FOLLOW UP REPORT WILL BE SUBMITTED ONCE ALL COST HAVE BEEN DETERMINED. EVEN THOUGH THIS INCIDENT MAY NOT REACH THE $50K REPORTING THRESHOLD NORTHERN CONSIDERS THE LOSS OF SERVICE TO THE COMMUNITY OF NEWKIRK, IA AS A SIGNIFICANT EVENT.   SUPPLEMENTAL/FINAL REPORT: A FINAL TOTAL COST OF REPAIRS OF $8,965, WHICH INCLUDES GAS LOSS HAS BEEN CALCULATED. AS PREVIOUSLY INDICATED THE ROOT CAUSE WAS THE FAILURE OF THE CONTRACTOR/LANDOWNER TO MAKE A ONE-CALL LINE LOCATE REQUEST PRIOR TO COMMENCING WORK ACTIVITIES. THIS INCIDENT IS CONSIDERED CLOSED WITH NO FURTHER ACTIONS PENDING."

THE PRESSURE WAS STABILIZED AT 16:00 ON OCTOBER 9, 2009. MICHCON MADE AN EXCAVATION AT THE VALVE SITE, INTENDING TO REPAIR WHAT WAS BELIEVED TO BE A LEAKING VALVE BODY BLEED FITTING. ONCE THE BURIED VALVE WAS EXPOSED, NATURAL GAS WAS FOUND TO BE LEAKING NOT FROM A BODY BLEED BUT FROM THE UPPER BONNET AND BEARING HOUSING, INDICATING A POSSIBLE BODY SEAL FAILURE. MICHCON TECHNICIANS ATTEMPTED TO STOP THE LEAK BY TIGHTENING THE SEAL PACKING, BUT THIS EFFORT WAS INEFFECTIVE. AT 08:45 ON OCOTBER 13, 2009 MICHCON MADE THE DECISION TO HALT EFFORTS TO REPAIR THE VALVE AND PROCEEDED TO PLAN FOR A SHUT-DOWN OF THE PIPELINE SEGMENT TO FACILITATE COMPLETE REPLACEMENT OF THE VALVE. NATURAL GAS WAS BLOWN TO THE ATMOSPHERE COMMENCING AT 14:30 ON OCTOBER 13, 2009 UNTIL THE 13.9 MILES OF 24"" PIPELINE BETWEEN MAIN VALVE 5 AND MAIN LINE VALVE 6 WAS AT NOMINAL ATMOSPHERIC PRESSURE. ON OCTOBER 15, 2009 MICHCON REPLACED THE LEAKING 12"" GATE VALVE WITH A NEW BALL VALVE. THE 24"" PIPELINE SEGMENT WAS RETURNED TO SERVICE AT LINE PRESSURE AT 13:00 ON OCTOBER 13, 2009. THE EVENT WAS REPORTED TELEPHONICALLY TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER AND TO THE MICHIGAN PUBLIC SERVICE COMMISSION SOLELY ON THE BASIS OF THE COST OF REPAIR, NOT ON ACCOUNT OF ANY INJURY, FATALITY, OR PUBLIC ATTENTION."

CADORIN	2482057669	ROBERT_CADORIN@TRANSCANADA.COM	2482055369	"PRELIMINARY RESULTS RECEIVED ON OCTOBER 26, 2009, FROM AN MFL TOOL RUN ON SEPTEMBER 29, 2009, ON ANR PIPELINE COMPANYS 237 LINE INDICATED AN ANOMALY AT APPROXIMATE MP 13.74 IN VALVE SECTION 2 WITH A POSSIBLE 86% PIPE WALL LOSS.  PLANNING TO EXCAVATE AND INSPECT THIS ANOMALY, FIELD PERSONNEL WERE DISPATCHED ON OCTOBER 28, 2009, TO CONDUCT A LEAK SURVEY AT THE SITE.  THE SURVEY INDICATED THAT THERE WAS LEAKING GAS.  AFTER SHUTTING IN THE VALVE SECTION, PIPELINE PRESSURE WAS LOWERED FROM 732 PSIG TO APPROXIMATELY 200 PSIG.  THE FOLLOWING DAY, PRESSURE WAS LOWERED TO ATMOSPHERIC AND THE SITE WAS EXCAVATED.  THE ANOMALY WAS INSPECTED AND WAS DETERMINED TO BE A PIN-HOLE-SIZED LEAK WITHIN AN APPROXIMATE ONE-INCH DIAMETER PIT.  ON EXAMINATION, THE PIT APPEARED TO HAVE CHARACTERISTICS CONSISTENT WITH THE THOSE CAUSED AS A RESULT OF A LIGHTNING STRIKE.  THE PIPE SEGMENT CONTAINING THE ANOMALY WAS REMOVED AND REPLACED.  FURTHER METALURGICAL ANALYSIS CONCLUDED THAT CAUSE OF THE LEAK WAS A LIGHTNING STRIKE THAT CREATED A METAL LOSS AREA ON THE OUTSIDE SURFACE APPROXIMATELY 1-INCH IN DIAMETR WITH A THROUGH-WALL PINHOLE LEAK AT THE DEEPEST PORTION OF THE MELTED AREA."

PETERS	2053257554	KEN.PETERS@ELPASO.COM	2053253729	"ON NOVEMBER 5, 2009, EL PASO NATURAL GAS COMPANY'S 24"" 1102 LINE RUPTURED AT APPROXIMATE MILEPOST 42+4250 IN POTTER COUNTY, TEXAS, NEAR BUSHLAND. THE NATUAL GAS PIPELINE RUPTURE RESULTED IN A FIRE. A HOME NEAR THE RUPTURE SITE WAS DESTROYED BY FIRE AND THREE INDIVIDUALS RESIDING IN THE HOME WERE INJURED AND HOSPITALIZED. OTHER NEARBY STRUCTURES SUFFERED PROPERTY DAMAGE. FINDINGS IN THE METALLURGICAL ANALYSIS REPORT OF THE RUPTURED 24"" LINE INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING:  -THE ORIGIN OF THE RUPTURE WAS NEAR THE SADDLE AREA OF THE ABANDONED BRANCH CONNECTION TAP. FRACTURE ORIGINATED IN THE CARRIER PIPE AT THE APPROXIMATE 7:30 POSITION ON THE UNDERSIDE OF THE TAP.  -BENDING STRESSES ON THE ABANDONED BRANCH CONNECTION TAP PLACED TENSILE STRESSES ACROSS THE THICKNESS OF THE CARRIER PIPE.  -THERE WAS NO INDICATION OF PROGRESSIVE CRACK GROWTH, SUCH AS ENVIRONMENTAL CRACKING OR FATIGUE IN THE FRACTURE.  -THERE WAS NO EVIDENCE OF A LEAK PRESENT IN THE PIPE PRIOR TO THE OVERLOAD EVENT THAT CAUSED THE RUPTURE.  -CORROSION DAMAGE WAS NOT INVOLVED IN THE RUPTURE OF THE PIPE.  -NO DEFECTS WERE OBSERVED IN THE SADDLE TO CARRIER PIPE WELD THAT CONTRIBUTED TO THE RUPTURE OF THE PIPE.    THE FINITE ELEMENT ANALYSIS OF THE PIPELINE RUPTURE WAS INCONCLUSIVE IN DETERMINING THE CAUSE OF FAILURE.    HOWEVER, THE ANALYSIS WORK ALLOWS FOR THE FOLLOWING CONCLUSIONS TO BE REACHED:   X PRESENCE OF LAMINATIONS IN THE CARRIER PIPE MID-WALL WAS NOT A CONTRIBUTING FACTOR.  X WEIGHT OF THE ABANDONED STUB AND SOIL ON TOP OF IT WERE INSUFFICIENT TO CAUSE THE FAILURE.  X LACK OF SUPPORT UNDER THE ABANDONED STUB WAS NOT A CONTRIBUTING FACTOR.  X THE SADDLE BEING OF A DIFFERENT SIZE (6-INCH X 20-INCH) WAS NOT A CONTRIBUTING FACTOR.  X SOIL EXPANSION UNDERNEATH THE BRANCH PIPE WAS NOT A CAUSATIVE FACTOR.  X ABNORMAL GAS OR AMBIENT TEMPERATURE CONDITIONS WERE NOT CONTRIBUTING FACTORS."

GEORGE HAMATY	3043573728	GHAMATY@NISOURCE.COM	3043573804	"ON NOVEMBER 14, 2009 AT 08:11 AM, A FIRE WAS REPORTED IN AN ETHYLENE GLYCOL DEHYDRATION UNIT IN THE ADALINE COMPRESSOR STATION IN MARSHALL COUNTY, WV.  GAS WAS EVACUATED FROM THE STATION PIPING AND THE COMPRESSOR STATION SHUT DOWN BY A COMPANY EMPLOYEE WHO ACTIVATED THE EMERGENCY SHUT DOWN (ESD) SYSTEM. THE EMPLOYEE RESPONDED TO THE SITE WITHIN 15 MINUTES FROM THE TIME HE WAS CALLED.  THE FIRE WAS EXTINGUISHED BY THE LOCAL FIRE DEPARTMENT IN LESS THAN AN HOUR. SPILL KITS WERE USED TO CONTAIN THE ETHYLENE GLYCOL.      THERE ARE THREE DEHYDRATION UNITS AT THIS LOCATION.  TWO UNITS WERE COMPLETELY DESTROYED, AND THE THIRD ONE WAS DAMAGED.  NEW UNITS ARE IN THE PROCESS OF BEING INSTALLED.      THE MAIN CAUSE THAT LED TO THE FAILURE OF THE DEHYDRATION UNIT AND INITIATED A FIRE WAS IDENTIFIED AS FOLLOWS:    THE EXCESSIVE FLUIDS IN THE SYSTEM OVERLOADED THE REBOILER AND CAUSED THE RELIEF VALVES TO OPEN, VENTING THE VAPORS AND LIQUIDS.  THE VAPORS IGNITED AND THE ENSUING FIRE DAMAGED FUEL LINES ON THE REBOILERS.  THE QUALITY OF THE GAS TO THE COMPRESSOR STATION WAS OUTSIDE OF COMPANY STANDARDS. THERE WERE NO FLUID HANDLING FACILITIES IN PLACE CAPABLE OF REMOVING THE HYDROCARBON FLUIDS IN A SAFE AND EFFICIENT MANNER.      IN THE ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS (RCA) REPORT, A LIST OF RECOMMENDATIONS WERE PROVIDED TO AVOID SIMILAR INSTANCES FOR ANY FLUID (HYDROCARBON) TO BACK-UP AND  CAUSE A SIMILAR EVENT THAT LEAD TO THE FIRE IN THE DEHYDRATION UNITS.    A NEW DEHYDRATION SYSTEM WAS INSTALLED.  A NEW PIPELINE HAS BEEN INSTALLED AND IS NOW IN SERVICE FROM THE POINT OF RECEIPT (FROM THE PRODUCER) TO THE EXTRACTION PLANT. TEMPORARY LAUNCHERS/RECEIVERS WERE INSTALLED ON THE PIPELINES TO ENSURE THAT THE PIPELINE SYSTEM IS PERIODICALLY CLEARED FROM EXCESS FLUIDS TO AVOID SIMILAR OCCURRENCE.  A RCA REPORT WAS SUBMITTED TO THE WV PSC."

PETERS	2053257554	KEN.PETERS@ELPASO.COM	2053253729	"CLEBURNE COUNTY (ALABAMA) EMA REPORTED A SUSPECTED NATURAL GAS RELEASE IN THE VICINITY OF SOUTHERN NATURAL GAS (SNG) COMPANY'S 24"" NORTH MAIN LOOP PIPELINE ON DECEMBER 31, 2009. DISPATCHED SNG PERSONNEL CONFIRMED THE EXISTENCE OF THE GAS RELEASE AT APPROXIMATE PIPELINE MILEPOST 399.631, ABOUT 835 FEET EAST OF CLEBURNE COUNTY ROAD 488.  THE 24-INCH NORTH MAIN LOOP LINE LEAKED DUE THE CUMULATIVE EFFECTS OF STRESSES (TENSILE AND TORSIONAL) ACTING ON A WRINKLE BEND CONTAINING A LONGITUDINAL WELD SEAM. THE FAILURE CONSISTED OF A 2- 7.5 LONG CIRCUMFERENTIAL CLEAVAGE FRACTURE ALONG THE APEX OF THE CONVOLUTION OF AN UNDER BEND.  STRUCTURAL CAPACITY WAS EXCEEDED DUE TO THE FOLLOWING FACTORS: (A) NATURAL SOIL MOVEMENT DUE TO THE GEOLOGICAL CHARACTERISTICS COMBINED WITH THE PRESENCE OF WATER (B) GEOMETRICAL STRESSES INHERENT IN THE BENDING OF THE PIPE MATERIAL AND PROPERTIES OF THE LONGITUDINAL WELD METAL (C) NORMAL INTERNAL PRESSURES ASSOCIATED WITH THE OPERATION OF THE NATURAL GAS PIPELINE (D)  EXCAVATIONS AND SOIL DISTURBANCES NEARBY THE PIPELINES RIGHT-OF-WAY.   THE WRINKLE BEND WAS INSTALLED DURING THE PIPELINE'S ORIGINAL CONSTRUCTION AND WAS USED IN A SAG BEND WITH THE PIPE'S LONGITUDINAL SEAM HAVING BEEN PLACED IN THE INSIDE PORTION OF THE BEND.  THE FAILURE SITE WAS REPAIRED BY REPLACEMENT WITH A NEW PIPELINE SEGMENT."

IN NORTH COLLINS, ERIE COUNTY, NY. DISPATCHER DETERMINED FROM SCADA AND OTHER PHONE CONTACTS, THAT LINE KNY WAS EXPERIENCING GAS LOSS. A REGULATOR CREW WAS DISPATCHED TO CLOSE BLOCK VALVE NCE-5 IN NORTH COLLINS AND SEND A SUPERVISOR TO NORTH BOSTON STATION TO CLOSE VALVES BNE-193 AND 195.VALVES BNE-193 & 195 WERE CLOSED AT 12:12 PM AND THE VALVE NCE-5 WAS CLOSED AT 12:32. AT THAT TIME THE LINE WAS ISOLATED.WHEN THE SITUATION WAS UNDER CONTROL IT WAS DETERMINED THAT A RUPTURE HAD OCCURRED ON LINE KNY APPROXIMATELY 641 SOUTH OF LOWER KNOLL RD, AND NORTH OF NEW OREGON RD. FURTHER INVESTIGATION REVEALED THAT NO PERSONAL INJURIES OR DEATHS RESULTED FROM THE INCIDENT. THERE WAS SOME PROPERTY DAMAGE AT 9999 NEW OREGON RD. THE PIPELINE WAS PAIRED BY REPLACING APPROXIMATELY 4 FEET OF 20 OD, 0.375"" WALL, X-52 GRADE, PRETESTED STEEL PIPE.     PART G: NARRATIVE DESCRIPTION OF FACTORS CONTRIBUTING TO THE EVENT - CONTINUED:INVESTIGATION UPDATE: THE FAILED SECTION WAS DELIVERED TO BATTELLE, COLUMBUS OHIO FOR A COMPLETE METALLURGICAL AND FAILURE ANALYSIS TO DETERMINE THE ROOT CAUSE OF THE FAILURE. BATTELLE CONCLUDED:""THE ORIGIN FOR THE FAILURE WAS IDENTIFIED AS A PAIR OF PITS COINCIDENTALLY LOCATED WITHIN THE CROWN OF THE PIPE IN THE VICINITYOF MAXIMUM AXIAL STRESS. THE UNUSUAL LOCAL AXIAL LOADING ACTED ON THIS PAIR OF COINCIDENTALLY LOCATED PITS CAUSING FAILURE, WHICH WAS FACILITATED BY WINTER TEMPERATURES WORKING IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE INHERENTLY HIGH DBTP' LEADING TO REDUCED FRACTURE TOUGHNESS. DBTT - DUCTILE BRITTLE TRANSITION TEMPERATURE. BATTELLE ALSO CONCLUDED: ""THE FAILURE WAS DUE TO A UNIQUE COMBINATION OF FACTORS THAT INVOLVED LOCALLY HIGH BENDING AND AXIAL STRAINS UNIQUE TO THE VICINITY OF OVER BEND ACROSS THE RIDGE WHERE THE FAILURE OCCURRED, FREE OF OTHER CONTRIBUTORY OR CAUSATIVE FACTORS."""	
2006	4060	20090142		DOMINION EAST OHIO	1201 EAST 55TH STREET	CLEVELAND	CUYAHOGA	OH	44101	2042	9/26/2006	CANTON	STARK	OH	44718			41.51834	-81.27896	N	3				NO	NO	N	INTRASTATE	4	OTHER									0	0	0	0	0	0	0	0	78995	2095	76900	0	YES	NO	YES	NO	0			0	6	9/27/2006	812854	1472	1600	NO	NO	YES	NO	NO	N	1	TRANSMISSION	4	COMPONENT		3	OTHER	BRASS SEAL	NO	NO	NO	3	COMPRESSOR		1998									6	INSIDE/UNDER BUILDING			4/19/2013	22	EQUIPMENT									NULL		NULL																	NULL						NULL			NULL			NULL																									NULL	NULL																									"PAMELA MICHALSKI, PROGRAM AMANGER"	2167366849	PAM.MICHALSKI@DOM.COM	2167366636	"ON SEPTEMBER 26, 2006 AT APPROXIMATELY 8:42 PM A FIRE/EXPLOSION OCCURED AT DOMINION EAST OHIO'S ROBINSON COMPRESSOR FACILITY LOCATED AT 5433 WEST BLVD IN CANTON, OH. EMERGENCY SHUTDOWN DEVICES WERE ACTIVATED AUTOMATICALLY BY STATION FIRE ALARMS AND MAUALLY BY DOMINION EASTOHIO GAS PERSONNEL ON SITE AT APPROXIMATELY 8:48 PM SHUTTING DOWN ALL FOUR RECIPROCATING COMPRESSORS AT THE FACILITY.  A COURTESY CALL WAS MADE TO THE PUBLIC TILITIES COMMISSION OF OHIO AT 9:30 PM ON SEPTEMBER 26,2006 UNTIL DAMAGE ASSESSMENT COULD BE CONDUCTED TO DETERMINE THE ORIGIN OF THE EXPLOSION AND AMOUNT OF PROPERTY DAMAGES.  PRELIMINARY DAMAGE ASSESSMENT INDICATED DAMAGE TO THE #4 COMPRESSOR UNIT AIR INTAKE, SCAVENGING UNITL LOWER CONVERS ON #4 AND #5 COMPRESSOR CYLINDERS AND THE TURBO-CHARGER. ALL FOUR COMPRESSOR UNITS REMAINED SHUT-DOWN FOR THE NIGHT UNTIL FURTHER INVESTIGATION.  AN INVESTIGATION WS CONDUCTED BY DOMINION EAST OHIO AND THE PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION OF OHIO ON SEPTEMBER 27, 2006 AT APPROXIMATELY 3:00 PM TO THE NATIONAL RESPONSE CENTER AND TO THE PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION OF OHIO BY TELEPHONE. NRC #812542 WAS ASSIGHNED TO THIS EVENT AT THAT TIME.  FURTHER INVESTIGATION REVEALED THAT THE #4 COMPRESSOR UNIT HAD SHUT DOWN ON SEPTEMBER 26, 2006 AT APPROXIMATELY 6:58 PM DUE TO AN OVER-SPEED CONDITION.  THE COMPRESSOR OPERATOR ATTEMPTED TO RE-START THE UNIT, THE UNIT BACKFIRED.  THE COMPRESSOR OOPERATOR SUSPECTED FUEL IN THE AIR INTAKE, PURGED THE INTAKE WITH AIR AND RE-STARTED THE UNIT.  JACKSON TOWNSHIP FIRE DEPARTMENT RESPONDED TO AN EXPLOSION CALL FROM A LOCAL RESIDENT AT APPROXIMATELY 7:30 PM.  FIRE DEPARTMENT PERSONNEL SPOKE WITH THE COMPRESSOR OPERATOR AND DETERMINED THE RESIDENT HAD HEARD THE BACK-FIRE OF #4 COMPRESSOR UNIT.  ALL FOUR COMPRESSORS OPERATING NORMAL AT THIS TIME.  AT APPROXIMATELY 8:32 PM ON SEPTEMBER 26, 2006, #4 COMPRESSOR UNIT SHUTS-DOWN FOR A SECOND TIME DUE TO AN OVER-SPEED CONDITION.  COMPRESSOR OPERATOR PURGES AIR INTAKE AND ATTEMPTS TO RESTART THE COMPRESSOR UNIT WHEN THE EXPLOSION OCCURRED.  EMERGENCY SHUTDOWN DEVICES WERE ACTIVATED AUTOMATICALLY BY STATION FIRE ALARMS AND MANUALLY BY DOMINION EAST OHIO GAS PERSONNEL ON SITE AT APPROXIMATELY 8:48 PM.  JACKSON TOWNSHIP FIRE DEPARTMENT ARRIVED ON SCENE WITHIN MINUTES AND NOTED A SMALL FIRE IN THE AIR INTAKE AND AROUND THE BASE OF #4 COMPRESSOR UNIT ENGINE.  INVESTIGATION ON SEPTEMBER 27, 2006 INDICATED THE #3 COMPRESSOR CYLINDER OF #4 COMPRESSOR UNIT HAD LEAKAGE THROUGH THE INNER HEAD PISTON SEAL CAUSING GAS TO BE RELEASED THROUGH THE 2"" VENT LINE.  THE AIR INTAKE AND 2"" VENT ARE BOTH LOCATED ON THE SOUTH SIDE OF THE COMPRESSOR BUILDING.  DURING THE RESTART, GAS WAS PULLED INTO THE AIR INTAKE AND CREATED AN EXPLOSIVE MIXTURE IN THE INTAKE SYSTEM.  THE FOLLOWING STEPS HAVE BEEN TAKEN BY DOMINION EAST OHIO TO PREVENT RECCURRENCE.  AN IGNITON LOCK-OUT TIMER HAS BEEN INSTALLED TO PREVENT IGNITION FROM BEING OPERATED PRIOR TO A TEN-SECOND PURGE OF THE AIR INTAKE, THIS IS AN INCREASE FROM A MANUAL 3-5 SECOND COUNT PRIOR TO IGNITION.  AN ADDITIONAL 3 OF 2"" PIPE HAS BEEN INSTALLED ON THE VENTS TO PROVIDE ADDITIONAL SAFETY FOR GAS BEING VENTED FROM THE COMPRESSORS.  OPERATING PROCEDURES HAVE BEEN MODIFIED TO INCLUDE A COMPLETE BLOW-DOWN OF INLET AND OUTLET GAS AT COMPRESSORS DURING SHUTDOWN AND PRIOR TO RESTART."

THE STRIKE PRODUCED A HOLE APPROXIMATELY 4 BY 6 IN THE MAIN RESULTING IN THE RELEASE OF NATURAL GAS. THIS INCIDENT RESULTED IN THE  EVACUATION OF MORE THAN 20 HOMES IN THE 1000 AND 1100 BLOCKS OF COOKS LANE AND THE 1100 BLOCK OF WEDGEWOOD ROAD. BGE HAD TO SHUT OFF ELECTRICITY TO APPROXIMATELY 1500 HOMES WHEN THEY DE-ENERGIZED THE FEEDER THAT WAS NEARLY DIRECTLY OVER THE STRIKE (FOR SAFETY).    BGE MET WITH CONTRACTOR REPRESENTATIVES AND THE BALTIMORE CITY PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT AT THE WORK SITE SEVERAL TIMES (ON AUGUST 16,17 AND 18) PRIOR TO THE INCIDENT. THE MARKINGS OF EACH UTILITYS UNDERGROUND FACILITIES MET ALL THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE MARYLAND PUBLIC UTILITY ARTICLE (PUC),  12-110. FURTHER, BGE REQUESTED THAT IT BE NOTIFIED BEFORE ANY EXCAVATION TOOK PLACE NEAR THE NATURAL  GAS TRANSMISSION LINE. THE CONTRACTOR DID NOT NOTIFY BGE OF THEIR INTENT TO START EVACUATION OF THE SITE ON AUGUST 23.    * NOTE: THIS REPORT IS A REPLACEMENT TO THE ORIGINAL REPORT SUBMITTED IN 2004. THE ORIGINAL REPORT WAS INCORRECTLY SUBMITTED AS A DISTRIBUTION INCIDENT, HOWEVER THE INCIDENT ACTUALLY OCCURRED ON A TRANSMISSION MAIN. OTHER THAN THE RECLASSIFICATION FROM DISTRIBUTION TO TRANSMISSION ALL THE INFORMATION ON THE THIS INCIDENT REMAINS THE SAME, NO DETAILS HAVE BEEN CHANGED. THIS RECLASSIFIED REPORT WAS APPROVED AND SIGNED IN MAY, 2013 BUT WILL REMAIN AS A 2004 TRANSMISSION INCIDENT  REPORT."
